PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Harold Young) took the chair at 10.30 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister representing the Minister for Transport will recall that I recently asked a question relating to ridiculous air timetables which give scant, if any, regard to the needs of the travelling public. Is the Minister aware that on most days an air traveller from Brisbane to Canberra who leaves Brisbane at 7 a.m. cannot arrive in Canberra until after midday? If the airlines show such lack of regard for their potential passengers, should they be given any consideration when asking for fare increases?

—I recall the earlier question from Senator Colston in connection with timetables. I have drawn to the attention of the Minister for Transport the concerns of Senator Colston and other honourable senators on this matter. As yet I have not received a response from him. I think Senator Colston would understand that the suggestion which he has advanced as a means of perhaps improving timetabling is a matter of policy which the Government would have to consider. I will bring that part of his question to the attention of the Minister as well.

—Did the Minister for National Development and Energy note a report in the Adelaide Advertiser of 2 March in which the Assistant General Manager of the giant South African-based Sasol group stated that the direct liquefaction of coal could be still 10 years or more away? Is that the view of the Government? In view of the fact that the Government is contributing this year a further $2. 77m to coal liquefaction research under the umbrella of the National Energy Research, Development and Demonstration Council in addition to the substantial sums of previous years, would it not be wise to provide a better balance and fund such demonstration and development projects as the gasification of the Wakefield coal deposit in South Australia rather than concentrate on direct liquefaction, which might still be said to be at the stage of pure research?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —This whole question of deriving petroleum products from coal is receiving very considerable study in Australia and widely throughout the world, particularly in Germany, amongst its coal chemists, in the United States of America and in Japan. Australia is closely in touch with many of these aspects. For example, several years ago I visited a hydrogenation process in Kentucky where in the order of $300m is being spent on a pilot plant and something like $70m a year for maintenance. The general belief was that within four or five years the project ought to be a practical commercial proposition. I do not have the most up to date knowledge. The important thing is that it was looking at getting something like three to 3 1/2 barrels of oil per tonne of coal, and yield is very important. I may not have the most up to date knowledge on the direct hydrogenation process. There are various processes, including the Fischer-Tropsch process.

ANSWER.PARA: I have not seen the Sasol statement. Sasol, of course, operates in South Africa under particular conditions, including, I think, government subsidy, because of the nature of the country. But the general belief around the world is that other more direct projects are likely to be so much better. NERDDC is aware of the various projects. NERDDC, which contains a number of very expert technical people, is advising us in the distribution of our research funds. Australia has a high technological ability in coal and coal chemistry. I believe that we are well advised in terms of world thinking. Nevertheless, I will look at the article and see whether any further comments should be made.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs to the question asked by my colleague Senator Tate yesterday concerning Australia's relations with South Africa. I ask: After 24 hours opportunity for consultation with the Foreign Minister, Mr Street, is the Government now in a position to reprimand the South African Ambassador for sending crudely racist and untrue propaganda to members and senators and to dissociate itself from and repudiate the actions of 20 Government back benchers who sent a congratulatory message on the creation by the white minority Government of South Africa of a fourth tribal homeland as a so-called independent state?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I referred Senator Tate's question to the Foreign Minister. I have a response to that question which I think comprehends the matters raised today by Senator Button. The Foreign Minister states that he is aware that the Information Counsellor of the Embassy of South Africa has written to a number of Government Ministers and parliamentarians concerning Australian Government policy towards South Africa. The Foreign Minister states that he has not yet seen a copy of the letter and is not conversant with its details.
—He had only to ask.

— Please let me finish. Copies have been referred to the Department of Foreign Affairs for examination. The Foreign Minister has directed officials, in addition to addressing the substance of the letter, to give consideration to the propriety of the action taken by the Counsellor. The Foreign Minister states that although he has not read the letter he is aware from media and other reports of its general tenor. It would seem to be based on a totally misguided view of our relations with South Africa. It contains, moreover, references and assumptions which are offensive. To suggest that Australians and South Africans derive largely from common stock ignores the reality of Australia's multiracial society and the racial composition of South Africa and would be considered an insult by many Australians.

ANSWER.PARA: The letter, as understood by the Foreign Minister, suggests that Australia and South Africa should co-operate to form a common southern alliance to protect the interests of the Western world. The Government rejects this proposition. It believes that South Africa's policy of apartheid is inimical to Western interests and that instead of combating communism apartheid encourages its spread. Unless there is a change of direction and steps are taken swiftly to dismantle apartheid it is inevitable that the instability already so sadly evident in South Africa will increase, with fearful implications extending far beyond the region. The Foreign Minister reiterates that the policy of apartheid is a major obstacle to peace and progress in South Africa and in the region. There can be no change in Australia's approach to South Africa until that policy is altered.

The Australian Government's opposition to apartheid and to the concept of independent homelands is well known and clearly on record. Australia, along with the rest of the international community, does not recognise the so-called homelands. Following the declaration on 4 December 1981 of the so-called independence of the Ciskei the United Nations Security Council condemned that development and called upon all governments to deny any form of recognition to the bantustans. The Australian Government has complied fully with that appeal. The Foreign Minister realises that there are some who may have been persuaded to the view that the creation of the so-called homelands is akin to the extension of land rights for the black people of South Africa. Regrettably, this is not so .

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask the Minister to table the document from which she read.
— The document from which I read is the brief from the Minister for Foreign Affairs and I am perfectly happy to table it.

—I refer the Leader of the Government in the Senate to a statement made in the Canberra Times early this week, indicating that the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation will conduct a review of environmental problems in the one million square kilometre Murray- Darling Basin. Can the Minister inform me what interaction will take place between the CSIRO, the River Murray Commission and the Department of National Development and Energy, having regard to the expanding interest in water resources announced by the Minister recently? I further ask whether this will lead to a speeding up of government action to deal with the devastating salinity problems of this great Australian water resource.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Commonwealth Government is moving rapidly towards a better integration and impetus for the overall research and development of water usage in Australia. Firstly, an overview is being developed to try to determine as quickly as we can Australia's water needs to the end of the century. Those discussions are going on with the States. In the background so that, the CSIRO has been asked to look at all the work it is doing in many ways in terms of water to see whether within itself it can get a better co-ordination of water usage both in the aquifer situation and in the qualitative situation, including salinity which is of very great interest, particularly to South Australians. In that regard my Department is endeavouring to pull together the work being done by the Atomic Energy Commission, the Bureau of Mineral Resources and the Department so that we can get a basic overview. The CSIRO in this context will be working closely with us all and there will be a close link with the River Murray Commission. I have a responsibility for it and I will ensure that that is so.

ANSWER.PARA: I am very well aware that whilst there has been some improvement in relation to salinity because of the spring and summer flush down the Murray there are still some worries in this regard. One of the hopeful things is that the Dartmouth Dam has continued to fill-I do not know its present level, but it is between 60 per cent and 70 per cent of capacity-which will offer some hope that salinity can be abated in the future. We are, as honourable senators may know, working with the Victorian Government to get better practices of irrigation by the irrigators along the Victorian border of the Murray because the major contribution to salinity is the lifting of the salt water table by unnecessary floodings and bad water practices. All these things are happening, including the implementation of the Maunsell report. We are setting up through the River Murray Commission a computer model of the whole system in order to develop it. The Government regards this matter as of very serious consequence and is doing everything it can to implement the new policies.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister representing the Minister for Science and Technology inform the Senate whether the Government has cut from $50m to $33.3m the funding to more than 120 Australian companies for industrial research and development? Can the Minister inform the Senate of the types of projects which will be affected by the funding cuts? Can the Minister confirm that such technology will have to be imported and paid for by Australian exports if technology is not developed in Australia?
—I will refer that question to the Minister for Science and Technology and ask him to provide an early answer.

—My question to the Minister representing the Minister for Health relates to Dr T.H. Hurley's report on the family medicine program which was to be available to the Government at the end of this month. Has the Minister received the report? If not, when will it be received? Will it be made public?

—I am aware that Dr Hurley and others are doing a report on the family medicine program and that the report is being awaited with more than usual interest because those who are associated with the program realise that it is needed for certain important decisions. The report is unlikely to be available by the end of March, as had been intended. As is the way with some of these studies, I think this report will require some more weeks before it is completed. It is expected that it will probably reach the Minister some time during April. A decision will then have to be made by the Government as to how the report will be handled and whether and, if so, when it will be made public.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, concerns the repeal of section 49 of the Repatriation Act in legislation which has been through the House of Representatives and which shortly will be in the Senate. I ask the Minister: Is he aware of the concerns of the totally and permanently incapacitated veterans' organisation about the results of this repeal? Has he consulted with it? Is it a fact that at a conference only a week before the legislation was introduced he was asked directly about the repeal of this section and he either denied that it was to be repealed or failed to answer? Has he consulted with any other organisation apart from the Returned Services League about this repeal? Should he not consult the organisations which directly represent those who will be affected by this repeal ?

—This is a rather surprising question from Senator Grimes, as this matter has been an issue of public notice for 12 months or so. It has been discussed at very many meetings of ex-service organisations across Australia over that period. Nevertheless, in connection with the particular meeting to which Senator Grimes referred, I discussed this issue with the TPI association at the national level about a week or so before the introduction of the Bill. I certainly did not refuse to answer or fail to answer any questions on this matter. In fact, I discussed it very fully. There was some confusion, I think, in the minds of those in the association as to precisely what was happening with the Bill. I sought to explain that. Consultation has been undertaken with as many ex-service organisations as have a concern in this matter. I cannot see that there would be any complaint from that point of view. Nevertheless, I am quite prepared to meet with the TPI association again and to discuss the details of the legislation with it in an attempt to settle the problem.

—I ask the Attorney-General: Has he been given notice of the decision by the Victorian Liberal Government to create a State human rights commission for Victoria? Can the Attorney-General tell us whether there are any indications of any other States having made any announcements in this regard? Can he tell us also to what extent it will contribute to the work of the Federal Human Rights Commission if such bodies are set up in Victoria and in other States?

—I noted with very great interest and satisfaction the intention of the Victorian Government to establish its own human rights commission. Unfortunately, I am not able to say that I have heard that any other State is contemplating taking such a positive action in regard to the protection of human rights along the lines of what this Parliament and Government have done. However , as I have indicated, we are hopeful that there will be a fair amount of co- operation with the States in the administration of matters affecting human rights. It is hoped that specific co-operative arrangements will be established. I have no doubt that with the establishment of a human rights commission in Victoria, it will be much easier to achieve those co-operative arrangements.
—You will have to move quickly. It has only a week left.

—I do not think that it is such an urgent matter as the honourable senator seems to think. I am sure that we will be able to make the arrangements with the Victorian Government in a proper and ordered manner. I will be looking forward to having such further discussions in the light of this new development.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Transport aware of a serious fault in the public address system at the new Coolangatta airport which allows the public to hear announcements clearly in the car park, gate lounges and toilets but which renders them totally garbled in the main public area inside the terminal? Is it a fact that numerous complaints about the faulty system have been made to the Department of Transport by passengers and terminal staff? Is it a fact that Ansett Airlines of Australia has erected signs in the terminal which state: 'Due to the ineffective PA system, Ansett requests passengers who have obtained seat allocation to proceed to gate lounges where announcements can be understood'? Will the Minister ensure that the fault is rectified urgently as Coolangatta is one of Queensland's, and indeed one of Australia's, major tourist terminals and will be a gateway to airports in Australia for the forthcoming Commonwealth Games?

—Unfortunately I have not had the good fortune to go to Coolangatta recently, as Senator Jones perhaps has. I am afraid that I have absolutely no knowledge of the matters he raised. I will undertake to raise them with the Minister and seek early rectification of the problem.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications. I understand that Australia's first public television preview broadcasts were recently transmitted in Sydney and Melbourne. Is the Government examining audience response to the broadcasts, and what is its timetable for licensing permanent public television services?

—I understand Senator Teague was correct when he said that the trial broadcast took place. Apparently the public response to the broadcast has been very favourable. Open Channel apparently is undertaking research into the potential for retail advertising. It is assessing the audience response in some detail. The results of this work will be the subject of further consultation between public television groups and the Government. Senator Teague asked about the further development of public television. Before the Government can examine the question of issuing licences for public television a number of other issues need to be resolved. These include: Completing the policy guidelines which are still under consideration within the Department of Communications; the place and role of public television, particularly in the context of the Government's consideration of the Dix report on the Australian Broadcasting Commission; and the provision of channel sharing which the Department of Communications is shortly to consider in consultation with industry bodies. Consideration will also have to be given to the impact of new technologies-for example, cable and subscription television-and the use of the planned new satellite. However, there is the opportunity for public television groups to continue to seek the use of spare time not only on Channel 0-28 in Sydney and Melbourne, but also with other telecasters, so there is still some limited capacity for experimentation to take place.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, follows the answer which he gave to Senator Teague. In view of his answer, does he recall that it was a firm promise of the Fraser Government prior to the 1980 election that public television would be established in Australia by the middle of 1981? Does he recall that promise? In view of his answer, has the promise been completely abandoned?

—Clearly the answer I gave to Senator Teague indicated that some progress is being made in the provision of public television. Everything I told Senator Teague is an indication of forward progress. I am not aware of the particularities of what Mr Fraser said at any particular time. Because of that I cannot answer the remainder of the honourable senator's question.

—Is the Minister representing the Treasurer aware that a number of tax exempt organisations such as local councils and schools are very concerned about changes to the sales tax arrangements announced by the Treasurer in December last year? Is it true, as some of them suppose, that organisations which are exempted from sales tax can no longer purchase goods free from sales tax by means of a sales tax exemption certificate obtainable from the Taxation Office? Under the present arrangements do these organisations have recourse to tax reimbursement only upon application to the Taxation Office after first purchasing items and paying the sales tax at the time of purchase? Can the Minister clarify the present arrangements for sales tax exemption for these organisations, since there appears to be widespread confusion on the matter?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —There must have been a number of misconceptions about this matter because I recall having had other representations on it made to me. But the facts are that it is not true that exempt organisations can no longer obtain goods free of sales tax on the production of a sales tax exemption certificate. The possibility of such organisations paying the sales tax on goods purchased at retail and then claiming a rebate directly from the Taxation Office is an option which was introduced by the Government in order to provide more flexibility in the sales tax payment system.

ANSWER.PARA: The amendment merely extended to schools, to tertiary education institutions, to government departments, to municipal councils and to public authorities a provision in the regulations which already permitted public hospitals and some benevolent institutions to claim a rebate from the Taxation Office after they had bought goods from retailers at tax inclusive prices. This is an option which is now open to schools and the other tax exempt institutions mentioned. However, there is no compulsion upon these organisations to alter their previous arrangements under which they obtained sales tax exemption certificates from the Taxation Office and were invoiced ex-sales tax by their suppliers.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN BROADCASTING COMMISSION: REGIONAL NEWS BULLETINS

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a question of the Minister representing the Minister for Communications. Is the Australian Broadcasting Commission planning to shift its regional news bulletins on non-metropolitan television stations from 6.55 p.m. to 5.55 p.m.? If so, when and why, in view of the fact that this would separate the regional bulletin from the main news bulletin and put it into children's viewing time? While acknowledging the ABC's programming independence, will the Minister check whether this decision is intended to increase or decrease the audience for the regional news and/or the national bulletin at 7 p.m.?

QUESTION.PARA: Is the change planned only for Tasmania or will it apply in every State? Was it a matter for management or for the Commission, and have the advisory committees been consulted? Does the Minister not expect that it will have a negative effect on the morale of those providing the ABC's news service, not to mention its being inconvenient for non-metropolitan Australians? Will he take the matter up with the ABC to ensure that it is not the beginning of the end of the ABC's regional news service?

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to pick up the point made by Senator Coates in his question, namely, his acknowledgment of the programming independence of the ABC. I think that is the important point from which to start. It will be necessary to check the facts and the accuracy of the points he made. I think that until that is done any comment upon his editorial additions-as to what it might mean or whether it is good or bad-really will have to wait.

—I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Science and Technology to the data acquisition facility at Alice Springs and the Canberra data processing facility which are part of the Australian Landsat Station. This project has proved to be most successful in receiving scientific data from Landsat satellites. With recent technical advances in new sensor data equipment and the fact that Landsat-D is scheduled for launching in mid-1982, is it the intention of the Government to upgrade Australia's receiving and processing facilities to ensure the full utilisation of available Landsat data?

—The Government is examining options for a possible upgrading of the Australian Landsat Station to receive Landsat-D and other remote sensing satellites. The Australian Liaison Committee on Remote Sensing by Satellite provides information on user needs through the Department of Science and Technology. Industry, including mining companies, is represented on that body through its own committee. The Australian Liaison Committee has set up a working party which investigated the need for updating the Australian Landsat Station and recommended that that upgrading should go ahead. Funding for an upgrading of the Station will be decided in the Budget deliberations. The mining industry has suggested a scheme of possible joint operation. This proposal is also being currently evaluated by the Government.

—Is the Minister for Social Security aware that recent changes to procedures for receiving unemployment benefit, namely, the requirement that monthly income statements must be received no later than four weeks after they are sent out, are creating serious problems for Aboriginals in remote areas? Does the Minister know how many Aboriginals have lost their benefit because of this new arrangement? Will the Minister consider reinstating, at least in remote areas, the previous provision for a six-week period to return statements?

—The requirements relating to income statements for Aboriginals in remote areas have been given consideration from time to time because of difficulties experienced by Aboriginal communities. My most recent contact with this area was when there had been an extension of the time provided for returns to be lodged. I am not aware of any serious problems which have emerged recently which would suggest that further attention is required. However, it is a matter of continuing concern to my Department which employs Aboriginal liaison officers and others to try to ensure that these difficulties do not occur. I will examine the point which has been raised by Senator Ryan. If she has knowledge of particular areas of difficulty which she can draw to my attention that will speed up my consideration of the matter. I will certainly do what is required to be done to ensure that the difficulties are removed.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Housing and Construction. It is about the Commonwealth matching the funds for housing in the States. I ask: Is it a fact that New South Wales home prices are, on the average, the highest by any means for any State? Is it as a result of this or as a result of the stamp duty which is imposed by the New South Wales Government that stamp duty in New South Wales on home mortgages has risen by more than 50 per cent in the past 12 months? Is this the highest of any State? How much of this stamp duty is the New South Wales Government channelling into the building of low cost homes or to building societies?

—It is true that, generally speaking, the average price of housing in New South Wales is about double that of some other States; I mention Victoria, in particular, and also South Australia. In those cases I will--
—There are a lot of homes for sale in Victoria going very cheap.

—I will come to that point. I have access to information on this matter in my capacity as Minister for Veterans' Affairs and my control of the Defence Service Homes operation. We do have access to information of this kind. It is clear that one of the very serious problems associated with housing in New South Wales does stem from the difficulties of house and land prices. Particular problems are affected, of course, by the State Government's attitude towards stamp duty. It is true that in South Australia the State Government, on coming to power in 1979, abolished stamp duty on first homes up to an amount of about $ 500. Apparently Mr Wran does not see any need to follow that kind of example to help the young home buyers in New South Wales. I will have to seek further information on Senator Lewis's particular point with regard to the amount of money that is collected from stamp duty in New South Wales. I will be able to provide him at some later time with more detail as to the scheme available in New South Wales for the distribution of help to young home buyers in that State. It remains, as is evident from the cries of the Opposition, that the New South Wales Government feels fairly tender on this point. Senator Lewis does us a service in bringing this matter to the attention of all Australians who have a real interest in the housing needs of young people in the Commonwealth.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. By way of preface I refer to the proceedings late last year of the high powered Estimates Committee D. The officers from the Department of Foreign Affairs were very pessimistic about tightening up and combating forged Australian passports. With the more serious evidence given at the Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drugs by the Australian Federal Police about how to use a steam iron and nail polish to forge and deface Australian passports, I ask: Does the Department still stand by its pessimistic posture of last year that nothing can be done? Will it make an effort to take away the tools of heroin couriers?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I recall the discussion referred to by Senator Mulvihill last year. These deficiencies were brought to light following an examination of the security of Australian passports which was conducted by the Australian Federal Police at the request of the Department of Foreign Affairs in May 1981. Since the release of the police report on 14 January 1982, the Government Printer, in consultation with the Department of Foreign Affairs and the Australian Federal Police, has been conducting extensive investigations into measures to overcome these deficiencies. For obvious reasons the measures under consideration cannot be disclosed at this stage. I will again refer Senator Mulvihill's interest in this matter to the Minister. If there is any further information that he is able to provide, I will see that the honourable senator is advised.
—I ask a supplementary question. In the face of the Minister's response can I take it that when the Estimates committees meet in three weeks time we might get a further fleshing out of this topic?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — It will be appropriate at that time for Senator Mulvihill to address his questions through the Committee. If there is any information that can be provided, I am sure that is an opportune time to have the matter discussed.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, concerns delays in the clearance of goods through Customs. Can the Minister advise what action the Government could take to reduce what are claimed to be inordinate delays in clearance through Customs of overseas goods, particularly medical, biomedical and pharmaceutical supplies?

—It is true that there have been delays in the clearance of goods , in some places and at various times, but in the majority of cases goods have been handled and cleared to the satisfaction of importers and the public generally. Where there have been delays, frequently it is found that most of the causes relate to incomplete documentation or the non-completion of the detailed information required to be presented to Customs officers. As regards importers in these situations which Senator Bjelke-Petersen mentions, it is clear that some of the goods involved may require special attention, as they may be specialised kinds of equipment or drugs of certain kinds which need detailed examination. In that event, I understand, special services are available. It would therefore behove each importer to make known his presence and intention with regard to this kind of import by bringing it to the attention of the authorities in order that special procedures might be utilised. Therefore, I urge all people who have this kind of difficulty to liaise more closely with the Bureau of Customs and with officers on duty in Customs offices around Australia, to make known their particular problem and to ensure that they get co-operation to their satisfaction from Customs officers.

—Does the Leader of the Government in the Senate agree with the honourable member for Kooyong, Mr Peacock, who said this morning on the 3AW Derryn Hinch show that the statement issued last night by Sir Phillip Lynch, the Deputy Leader of the Liberal Party, was 'ill-timed and ill-considered'? Does he agree with Mr Peacock's implication that the statement was made to damage Mr Peacock's standing with the Victorian Liberal Party? Does he agree that, as Mr Peacock said in the interview, he was entitled to be 'damned annoyed' with Sir Phillip Lynch? Does he also agree with Mr Peacock's response, when asked whether there was a Fraser camp and a Peacock camp involved in the fight for the Liberal Party leadership, that there were 'camps all over the place'?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not hear the broadcast from 3AW this morning and, therefore, I am at a disadvantage in that regard. I will assume that the Leader of the Opposition has made a correct precis, although I am at a disadvantage in doing that. It was essential that a statement be made to disabuse the propaganda attempts in the media stating that there is a destabilisation in the Government. The propaganda attempts were aimed at doing damage in Victoria. So rather than that statement being ill-timed, the only ill-timed statements were those which were made at the time of a Victorian election and which could have done damage to Victoria. It is a sad thing that such a misrepresentation of the truth should be flared up at this time.
—Which misrepresentation?

—Of course, the misrepresentation is quite clear; that is, that there is any substantial support for any opposition to the present Prime Minister. The fact of the matter is that the Prime Minister, Mr Fraser, has been and remains an extraordinarily successful Prime Minister in the history of Australia. Nothing that the Labor Party can attempt to do can overcome the fact that the Prime Minister, Mr Fraser, has had the greatest series of victories, in magnitude, of any Prime Minister in Australia's history. The victories of 1975, 1977 and 1980 show that the people of Australia, sitting in judgment in pre-selection of their Prime Minister, have said with the most unique record: 'We want Mr Fraser as Prime Minister'. Let that be perfectly clear.
—Which misrepresentation?

—The only misrepresentation lies in the headlines. I do not know who should be damned annoyed. I think the public will judge who should be damned annoyed as a result of the grossly untrue headlines, which are aimed to damage. Indeed, they are completely out of context with the choice of the electors at the ballot box. Let nobody doubt that.
—You are tied in up to your neck. Withers will be back.

—For the last five years as I have stood in this place the Jeremiahs have said: 'It is your last week. You are going to be beaten'. That is what they said in 1975, 1977 and 1980. Thank God, Mr President, that the wisdom of the people of Australia was such that they rejected the Australian Labor Party and kept it on your left hand side, as they will do for the future. There is no significant disunity in the Government. Government members are strongly behind Mr Fraser as Prime Minister. His record is a first class one and it will be judged again in the ballot box.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry. Australia's experience in recent years in handling suspected outbreaks, following the possible invasion of serious exotic animal disease, must have the effect of streamlining Australia's quarantine and Customs services in relation to repelling importation of such disease. This week 's announcement of Denmark's outbreak of foot and mouth disease has, of course, triggered an alert for our inspection services. Do we now have a fast co- ordinated force of trained people capable of directing troops and others to rapidly contain exotic disease and eradicate it when it first appears anywhere in Australia? What, if any, additional detection techniques are we now using to lessen the possibilities of a similar outbreak as the odds on such a problem arriving here are always on the cards and are probably shortening?

—Australia has a very good record in terms of avoiding the importation of exotic stock diseases. The unfortunate outbreak referred to by the honourable senator in his question is a reminder of the need for continuous vigilance in this area. Over recent years the Government has taken some major steps to improve quarantine facilities. I am not able to say whether it has this fast fleet referred to by the honourable senator in his question. However, in light of the importance of the question generally to such major parts of Australian industry and in light of the current interest which is aroused because of the difficulties which have been referred to in the question, I will seek from the Minister a more detailed statement of current quarantine arrangements for the information of the Senate and the Australian public.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications. I preface it by reminding the Minister that on 18 November 1981 I raised with him the poor telephone communications between Palm Island and the mainland and Burketown and southern areas. The Minister promised to investigate the matter. Can the Minister now inform the Parliament what improvements to the telephone system have been made at these two centres?

—As is usual, when questions of this nature are asked of me at Question Time I pass them on to the Minister whom I represent for appropriate action and advice. I do not recall Senator Keeffe's question of 18 November 1981 but I do recall his having been concerned about Palm Island and the people in the Gulf area. I will undertake to find what advice Mr Sinclair offered to him at that time. As to whether the service has altered since then, I will also put that question to the Minister whom I represent and try to get more detailed information for Senator Keeffe.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Keeffe Sen J.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to ask a supplementary question. It will probably help the Minister's memory if I repeat the answer he gave me on 18 November. The Minister said:

QUESTION.PARA: Last week I was in Burke Shire and met there also with representatives of Carpentaria Shire. They raised a number of matters with me, including their communications problems. I will undertake to make known to my colleague Senator Keeffe's concern about the communications problem on Palm Island and also his desire that the two shires he mentioned should also have access to better communication. I just add that the Clerk of Burke Shire, Mr Allan Choveaux, is one of the best communicators and one of the best boosters of his own shire . . .

On 18 November I asked a supplementary question and I reminded the Minister that at the onset of the wet season those phones would not be operating. The crux of the matter is that apparently the Minister has done nothing about representations made by Mr Choveaux, nor has he passed on my previous request to the Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have already said in my answer to the original question that we do pass on to the relevant Minister matters which are raised during Question Time. That is a fact. We have done something about the matter. As usual Senator Keeffe's suggestions are incorrect.

—The Minister representing the Minister for Science and Technology will remember that yesterday I asked a question about the research effort that is presently going on in the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation. Today I refer to an article in a recent National Times which states that an original Budget allocation of nearly $50m for industrial research and development grants which was passed by this Parliament has been slashed to $33,500,000. Is it true that many of the recipients of these industrial research and development grants are small businesses which very much rely on Federal Government grants to keep up with technological change in order to survive in this country? How is it that moneys that have been passed by this Parliament are now chopped off without reference to this Parliament?

—Earlier today Senator Macklin asked me a question broadly in relation to the matter about which Senator Townley has now asked. Since Senator Macklin's question my colleague Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle has referred me to a question which she received earlier this week from Senator Watson also in relation to the same matter. I think everybody must have been reading the National Times. I cannot think why. Perhaps I should refer both Senator Macklin and Senator Townley to a very detailed answer and explanation given in relation to this matter by Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle yesterday, which appears in yesterday's Hansard at page 1095.

—I ask a supplementary question. I have things to read other than Hansard. The main thrust of my question is: How is it that moneys that have been passed by this Parliament are just cut off without reference to the Parliament?

—The matter of the moneys voted for these programs and the expenditure of those moneys by the potential recipients is all explained in the answer Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle gave. If the honourable senator does not want to read Hansard I can have that answer retyped and he can read it in that form. I think he will find that the explanation is contained in that answer. If he has any other questions which he wants to refer to me he can come back to me.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Health aware that international drug traffickers have started dealing in the tranquilliser diazepam, otherwise known as valium? Is he aware that drug officials in the United States of America are alarmed at the very high dose of valium being used by drug abusers? As valium is made under licence by European manufacturers and exported to buyer countries, where it seems supplies go through several hands to reach the illicit market, will the Minister give an assurance that drug companies in Australia will be required to produce extensive details of commercial production figures, of commercial movements of tranquillisers, and of how much is shipped to whom and for what purpose?

—Australia has a very extensive system of recording the production and movement of drugs which are considered to be drugs of addiction. Senator McIntosh really asked whether diazepam, which is known popularly as valium, should be treated in the same way as some other drugs which are known to be drugs of addiction. I am aware and I think many other senators would be aware that the problem is not one involving the chemical substance itself but a problem of people willing or wishing to use chemical substances for non- therapautic purposes. I am not certain that it is correct that diazepam has become a worry in terms of drug abuse in the same way as have narcotics. I am certain that some people who are users of chemical substances would use diazepam as they used to use Bex and Vincents or as they use other minor tranquillisers. Whether the problem is of the quality that Senator McIntosh asserted is something on which I would want to take advice. I will put his suggestion concerning the recording of production and movement of tranquillisers to the Minister whom I represent for appropriate and careful attention.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Finance. Is the recent merger discussion between the National Mutual Life Association of Australasia Ltd and the T & G insurance group a recognition by certain life offices of a need to shore up their business against the inroads of further taxation or foreign competition in a similar way to the reaction of the banks in response to the recommendations of the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I am not able to make any suggestions with regard to the motives that may lead major companies to amalgamate or to restructure. If any information is available on this matter I will see that Senator Watson is advised about it, but I should think that a number of factors are always taken into account in decisions of this sort at the corporate level. I am not aware of any particular reason that would relate to the two companies mentioned.

—My question is directed to the Attorney-General. Did the report of the Lynch Committee of Review of Commonwealth Functions, the razor gang, recommend that law publishers be permitted to publish laws and regulations passed by the Parliament? Did the publishers meet representatives of the various interested departments last August and agree on arrangements whereby this might be done? Is it a fact that notwithstanding this agreement the Attorney-General has still not advised publishers that they might publish Acts and regulations without obtaining approval in advance? What is the reason for the delay? When will the matter be resolved?

—Senator Evans seems to have been reading an article in the Bulletin. The fact is that the recommendation of the Lynch Committee, which was adopted by the Government, was that the restrictions on the publication of material for which Crown copyright subsists-that is, Acts, regulations and, indeed, judgments -should be eased. The position is that the Commonwealth asserts, as I am sure Senator Evans is well aware and no doubt supports, a copyright in--
—I do not like Crown copyright.

—Senator Evans is well aware of it even if he does not support it . The Crown asserts a copyright in this material, but for many years permission has been granted to various law publishers to publish this material. Indeed, we are very indebted to the efforts of private enterprise in this field. I refer to the special publications in relation to Acts such as the Family Law Act, the Income Tax Assessment Act and the Conciliation and Arbitration Act where very prompt and useful publications are made by the law publishers ahead of the official publication by the Government through the Australian Government Publishing Service. We have at times given permission to publish without even any accompanying material. The traditional basis of giving permission to these publishers has been that they wish to incorporate the material in their own special publications which do contain accompanying material. However, there has been an increasing desire by the publishers to be able to publish, without any accompanying material, certain Acts for which there is a very strong demand. They seek to satisfy that demand ahead of the availability of the official version through the AGPS. We have been discussing the easing of these restrictions with the publishers to provide for some system of permission to be given to certain publishers without having any accompanying conditions such as in the existing rules. As reported in the Bulletin, a meeting was held between representatives of the Government and the publishers in August last year. The proposal was to give effect to the idea I mentioned.
—Why the delay?

—The matter was with officials. The question has still to be resolved at ministerial level. I have been having correspondence with several colleagues who are concerned with it. There will be direct competition in this case with the AGPS in which the Government naturally has considerable interest and concern. I hope that we will be able to make a decision in the near future to give effect, certainly in substance, to the decision of the Review of Commonwealth Functions. I emphasise that that decision was that the restrictions be eased; it is the way in which they will be eased which is still the subject of discussion.

—I direct a question to the Minister for National Development and Energy. Has the Government made an assessment of the recent statement by Sheikh Yamani which explained Saudi Arabia's oil production policy? Australia's oil prices are linked to the price of Saudi Arabian light crude. Can the Government foresee any substantial changes in the price of oil in Australia in the near future?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government has been studying what has been said by Sheikh Yamani and the Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries following the recent meeting of that organisation. I was fortunate to have prior lengthy discussions with Sheikh Yamani in Saudi Arabia. Basically, Saudi Arabia had been endeavouring to get a stabilising of the OPEC oil price and a stabilising of volume so that there would be no movement over a period and then a movement less than inflation. That, of course, would have produced a fall in the real price of oil. However, there was an underestimation of the degree of conservation by various countries and of the effect of the world recession. Another factor which has emerged is that Iran, in particular, and Iraq are close to exhausting their foreign exchange and must sell oil on the world market to get money to buy food and other goods. Therefore, they are increasing the volume of oil in the world. The effect has been a destabilising one.

ANSWER.PARA: The Saudis and OPEC have taken the view that the first thing to do is to reduce the volume of oil. Saudi Arabia has led the downward trend in volume and others have taken cuts. The Saudis have indicated that at the moment they have no intention of reducing their price. I make the point that holding to their price over a period would, of course, be a real reduction. I cannot assess whether all the other OPEC countries would be able to sustain the lower volume and any lower prices. All I can say is that at the moment it is likely that the present cut in volume may not be enough to remove the surplus and we will need to see whether there will be further cuts in volume. As Senator Thomas said, the Australian prices are pegged to the price of Saudi light crude. That has been one of the cheapest in the world and we have had the benefit of that. At the moment I see no immediate change in the nominal price but, as inflation moves, a fall in the real price of oil in Australia will occur. We can only wait and see what the pressure of supply and demand will be in the months ahead.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 24 February Senator Giles asked me a question about bringing in legislation on what she described as pensioners' assets, but which was a reference to the Government's announced intention to introduce legislation on income deprivation. I have a more detailed response to add to the answer I gave at the time. I said:

ANSWER.PARA: It is still my hope to bring in that legislation during these sittings. When I bring it in will be dictated by when the legislation is ready.

I now advise the Senate that the Government will not be introducing legislation during this session of Parliament to strengthen the provisions to prevent income avoidance for pension purposes. I announced last year that we would be taking steps to ensure that the income test on pensions is operating properly so that it fulfils its function of enabling the Government to provide more assistance to pensioners in greater need within the limits of total money available. Since I made that announcement officers of my Department have been working with officers of the Attorney-General's Department on draft legislation designed to catch highly artificial arrangements that increase pension entitlement. However, it has proved very difficult to do this effectively in a way that does not touch normal investment activities. We have consistently indicated that we will not take action in this area until we are sure that the arrangements proposed will not have any adverse effect on the normal domestic investment decisions of pensioners. As I said in the Senate on 13 October last year:

It is a matter of having legislation which will catch the artificial and yet at the same time leave untouched the normal domestic arrangements of the great mass of pensioners who do not enter into such schemes. Until I have legislation which I am satisfied will not be in any sense punitive to those pensioners who are simply carrying on their normal domestic affairs and who are not entering into artificial and contrived schemes, I would not propose to introduce such legislation into this Parliament.

As there has been considerable interest in the question of pensioners keeping large sums in non-interest bearing cheque accounts and considerable comment on the suggested figures of $2,000 for single pensioners and $3,000 for married couples as reasonable amounts to be retained in a cheque account, I should make it clear that, in the absence of amending legislation, there is no restriction on the sum which may be kept in such accounts. The introduction of legislation at a later date will depend on whether a satisfactory form of legislation can be devised.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement.

I move that motion because the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) has , in fact, announced a considerable change in the Government's policy and strategy as announced in the Budget last year. I believe he has also compounded an unfortunate situation which exists in this community at the moment concerning pensioners and their assets and incomes. The Government announced in the Budget last year that it intended to correct by legislation what it believed was a major anomaly in the income testing of pensions in this community. It wished to correct, it said, avoidance by a large number of people of the income test through various means-contrived and otherwise. I quote from the statement by Senator Chaney on 18 August last year, which reads:

The Government is concerned that, in the welfare area as well as in taxation, income rigging practices are circumventing the intent of the laws and throwing undue burdens on taxpayers generally. In turn such practices make it more difficult to help genuinely needy people. The Social Services Act already has provisions aimed at preventing people who are well able to maintain themselves from deliberately arranging their affairs so that they become eligible for higher rates of pension. These provisions, like the pension income test, are an essential part of the mechanisms for ensuring that available assistance is focused on those who are least protected and that the already large demands made by the welfare system on taxpayers are not further increased.

We shall therefore be moving during the Budget session of Parliament to tighten up the relevant legislation so as to prevent income avoidance for pension purposes by such devices as keeping large sums of capital in non-interest bearing accounts or by participation in other income avoidance schemes that are being promoted within the community. For example, there are schemes which produce no 'income' to pensioners but enable them to withdraw capital equal to the amount of income that would be payable under a normal investment arrangement . In other words, income is withdrawn in the guise of capital.

Questions were later asked in this place by me, by Senator Walters, by Senator Hamer and finally by Senator Giles as to just when this legislation would be coming in. Senator Chaney, in answer to a question by me on 9 September 1981, announced:

I will follow up the matter very quickly and see what is going on. With respect to the precise legislation which is to be introduced this session, pursuant to the announcements in the Budget, I would expect it to be within the Parliament well before 1 November.

On 24 February Senator Giles asked Senator Chaney when the legislation would come in. The essence of Senator Chaney's answer at that time was that it would be introduced as soon as possible. What has happened since this announcement in the Budget-an announcement which said that there was considerable avoidance of the income test on pensions, that people were using contrived means to avoid the income test, that there was in fact a serious problem and that the Government intended to do something about it, and quickly-is that there has been continual speculation among pensioners and other retired people in the community as to just where they stood. Some firms, such as insurance companies and so on, have taken advantage of the honourable senator's announcement and have advertised for pensioners and retired persons to join these contrived schemes so that they can receive a pension and health benefits. There has been considerable anxiety and uncertainty among people who arranged their affairs under the old rules as to just what is happening. When people on this side of the House drew attention to this anxiety and uncertainty they were accused by the Minister of trying to frighten pensioners. On one occasion we were accused of trying to frighten little old ladies.

It is perfectly clear from the Minister's answer to Senator Giles today that when the Minister made the announcement following the Budget Speech, the Government did not know what it was going to do and how it was going to do it. The Government announced a serious legislative change and it did not have a clue what it was doing. At the time the Government created anxiety and uncertainty in the community. I believe that what Senator Chaney has announced here today is that the Government will not introduce any such legislation. What he is saying to us in fact is that when the Government looked at what it was trying to do it found that the whole thing was too hard.

Further questions now need to be asked. What is the present situation? Is it still true, as Senator Chaney announced following the Budget, that a large number of people are indulging in the activities in which he said they were indulging? If it is true is the Government going to do anything about it? It seems quite clear from the Minister's statement that it will not. Is it true, as I have suggested, that the Government announced this Budget change without knowing what it was going to do and without knowing how it was going to do it? Is this the end of it or are these people, as Senator Chaney said, going to have to sit and wait for months and months before they know just what is going to happen, how they can adjust their affairs in the future and whether the way they have adjusted their affairs will result in them having the same standard of living as they have now?

I suggest that this is a most unsatisfactory situation. The question is not about who is avoiding the income test, where the income test is being avoided, whether it is fair or whether there should be an assets test. Rather, the question is this: What does the Government intend to do? Does it intend to persist in leaving this uncertain situation whereby thousands of people who have retired or will retire do not know where they stand and do not know how they should adjust their affairs? Are we still to have the situation where finance companies, insurance companies, banks and other organisations in this community are producing contrived schemes which remove money from the revenue just as certainly as do contrived taxation schemes? Are we going to persist with this situation where the Minister repeatedly comes into this place and says: 'We will have the legislation before 1 November. We will have the legislation in the near future'? Now the Minister says: 'We will have the legislation some time if we can work out ways to deal with it'.

I believe that the announcement of this change in policy should have been made as a ministerial statement and not sneaked in at the end of Question Time in an answer to a question asked by Senator Giles some time ago. It is a major matter. It deserves full debate. I believe that it is just a demonstration of the incapacity of the Minister and the Government to deal with this problem in a reasonable and fair way and to ensure that people who are retired and are eligible for age pensions in this community know what is going on and have some certainty regarding their retirement and some indication that the Government and the Minister know what is going on. Otherwise we will persist with the sorts of debates we have had in the newspapers in this country since the Budget announcement last August. We will persist with throw-away lines such as those the Minister made in the second reading speech for the social services amending legislation last year, when he talked about $2,000 or $3,000 being the sort of reasonable amount that pensioners could keep in their interest-free deposits before they would be affected by the Director-General of Social Services.

This situation is quite unsatisfactory. We need a firm and clear statement of what the Government intends to do. The Minister has in his Department probably a bigger staff than any other Minister in the Government. He has research facilities far beyond those of anyone on this side and far beyond those of most other establishments in this country. He should come down with a statement on what he thinks should happen in regard to the situation as it exists so that we can have a proper and sensible debate and so that we do not have a repetition of the nonsense of the Minister making statement after statement in this chamber about his intents and having to retract them until we are now in the situation where what he really is saying is: 'We do not know what to do and it is all too hard'. I do not believe that this chamber, this country and particularly the retired people of this country should be treated in this way by either the Minister or the Government. I hope that in the future it will not happen. In order that in the future we can have a proper debate on this matter, I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I will not detain the Senate. He would know, because he has a rapport with those sorts of people, that they are deeply concerned about this issue. SPEECH.PARA: I would have thought, seeing the issue has been hanging over the heads of 1.4 million pensioners for such a long time now, that it would have been the subject of a decision. INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator PETER BAUME

TALK.START.PARA: —During Question Time Senator Archer asked a question of Senator Chaney concerning quarantine. As Minister representing the Minister for Health, I have some information relating to the matter raised by Senator Archer. To take up the point made by Senator Chipp a moment ago, the answer I have is seven paragraphs in length and contains no material that is unsuitable for incorporation. I seek leave of the chamber to have it incorporated in Hansard.

INTERJECT.PARA: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows-
Australia's quarantine arrangements are with justification amongst the most stringent in the world. This has been crucial to our success in keeping major exotic animal diseases out of Australia.
The Government is committed to a strong and effective quarantine service and to ensure that all practical steps are taken to minimise the possibility of major exotic disease entry.
Quarantine and Customs screening arrangements at our ports of entry have been demonstrably successful. These procedures are under constant review.

Comprehensive Commonwealth/State contingency plans and cost sharing arrangements have been developed for the major animal diseases to allow immediate action to be taken when animal health emergencies occur. These arrangements provide for a co-ordinated national response and have as their objective, early containment and eradication and were developed under the auspices of the Australian Agricultural Council.

Detection and interception methods at air and seaports have been supplemented in recent years by the establishment of a comprehensive coastal surveillance program which includes as a major component a daily aerial quarantine search of the coastline between Karratha in Western Australia and Cairns, Queensland.

A national Quarantine Publicity Campaign has also been implemented. The program has been designed to develop public awareness and understanding of quarantine and the implications of a major disease outbreak and to encourage individual responsibility and self-regulation among travellers.

Additional measures to advise foreign visitors to this country of Australian quarantine requirements have also been taken. These measures include the production of multi-lingual leaflets and in-flight announcements and the showing of films on selected flights into Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Further to the point raised by Senator Chipp I say to the chamber that Ministers have the right-this is something the Chair encourages-if they have a further extension to an answer, to give it after Question Time, rather than take up the time of Question Time.
