DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT TASK FORCE ON DRUG TRAFFICKING

PROCTEXT.PARA: Report and Ministerial Statement

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the papers.

The saga of Nugan Hand continues despite efforts by the Government to contain any public debate and discussion about the issues of that organisation. The report of the Joint Task Force on Drug Trafficking, which is an interim report by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser), deals with a number of the more rudimentary and routine questions of that organisation. The Parliament is being given access to what can only be described as a very routine and very interim report. The major part of the report has been made available privately to the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Button). In the other House today a debate is currently proceeding about a number of matters relating to the activities of the organisation, Nugan Hand. The task force which the Senate is currently looking at deals largely with the drug trafficking aspects of the organisation, Nugan Hand. What the Government does not seem to understand and appreciate is that the problems associated with that organisation will not just go away, and the sooner the Government comes clean about the activities of its agencies in respect of the Nugan Hand group of companies, the better it will be for the Parliament and the Australian community.

When one is involved, as Nugan Hand was, in clandestine activities-those activities related not only to drugs but also to currency manipulations and covert activities on behalf of the Central Intelligence Agency of the United States-it is clear that sooner or later those facts will come to the light of day. A much more advanced and progressive attitude about the freedom of information legislation in the United States is now enabling the Congress of that country, the Senate and the House of Representatives, to look at the activities of organisations, particularly intelligence organisations and other agencies. The availability of that information has become a very important aspect of understanding the events of 1975. I will leave that matter aside for the moment. Honourable senators will appreciate that it is difficult to deal in 10 minutes with the ramifications of an organisation that came to the attention of a government agency in 1975-that is now some seven years ago-an organisation that has clearly been involved in a whole range of illegal activities in the Australian community, particularly the importation of hard drugs, heroin.

Documents that have come into the possession of the Opposition show a very unsatisfactory state of affairs in respect of this organisation, particularly as it relates to the Australian Narcotics Bureau, the Bureau of Customs and, maybe, the Australian Federal Police. I have a copy of those documents which have been referred to only very briefly insofar as the report that is before the Senate is concerned. I will read from a minute paper of the Narcotics Bureau on a memo addressed to the Commander of the Eastern Region. The minute paper is headed: ' Subject: Nugan Hand Ltd. Suspect principals of heroin importations'. The paper reads:
The original information that Frank NUGAN and Michael HAND were financing the importation of heroin was received on 3.5.77 and is contained in folios 1 and 3.
I add that I am reading from a copy of folio 14. I have not the complete folios dealing with the matter. According to my information some have been destroyed. The paper continues:

Preliminary enquiries showed that Nugan Hand Ltd and a number of its associates ; Leslie COLLINS, Robert PIKE, John NORTON, Graham DEMPSEY had come to the notice of the Narcotics Bureau in October 1975, (folios 30 and 31). Both Nugan and Hand travel extensively throughout South East Asia and Australia.

2. Nugan Hand Ltd., is supposed to be a merchant bank with a turnover in 1976- 77 of $220 million. A BCI check shows that as at 12.7.77 Nugan Hand had made seven importations from Hong Kong and China, five being canned foods, one of furniture and one of golf clubs and balls.

That might appear to be quite unimportant and irrelevant to the report. But the Woodward Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drug Trafficking was given evidence that furniture and other goods imported into this country were the means by which heroin was brought in. Yet that information, in a preliminary aspect, was in the hands of a government agency in 1975. I make that point because we know what happened in November 1975. From that period on the Narcotics Bureau and the Bureau of Customs were very much involved in several operations, some of which are referred to in others of these documents. Operaton Canopus is one that comes immediately to mind and somewhere in the documents another operation is referred to. All of these operations were concerned with the importation of hard drugs.

These are documents which my leader, Mr Hayden, attempted yesterday to make available-having been challenged to do so on previous occasions when he raised the matter. Last Thursday, as a very responsible member of the Parliament, he would not make them available because of information contained therein insofar as persons whose names appear in these documents may be embarrassed, compromised and even intimidated in some way. Yesterday Mr Hayden offered to make those documents available to the Parliament so it could have some sort of wide-ranging debate. He was refused leave to do so at the instance of the Prime Minister. The Government is culpable in respect of Nugan Hand.

Because we have very limited time to debate the matter I will conclude by saying that on pages 1649 and 1650 of the Woodward report of 5 September 1978 the Commissioner, Mr Justice Woodward, said that there was a lack of co- operation by the Federal Government in respect of these matters. He said that in general he did not receive the co-operation of the Federal Government, the Narcotics Bureau or Customs. Not one single officer was made available to give evidence to him and there was no official information provided from the Narcotics Bureau. Yet these documents show that the Bureau of Customs and the Narcotics Bureau were very heavily involved in seeking information and carrying out investigations into the Nugan Hand group. I remind the Senate that we have had three royal commissions inquiring into drugs-the Williams, Woodward and, currently, the Stewart. We are determined as an Opposition that these matters will be brought to light and that there will be a proper public debate. Finally, I will conclude by quoting from a minute paper signed by Brian Bates, the director of the Narcotics Bureau. He said in dealing with the matter of Nugan Hand:

I desire that this Bureau should not for the time being engage in any active external inquiries into this matter. Until such time as I indicate otherwise, I wish this to remain purely an Intelligence gathering and holding matter, oversighted from Canberra by Mr Haydock-Wilson, OLIA, to whom subsequent information reports connected with the matter should be directed by Regions.
That paper was dated 22 March 1978.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be very brief because there is not a lot to be said about the Joint Task Force on Drug Trafficking report before us. I will make two or three points. Reasons have been given in the report-no doubt Senator Evans will speak about these-as to why the report should not be released at this stage except to the Leader of the Opposition. I cannot disagree with the essential reasons given for that. They are: Firstly, if the report were made public it could be sub judice; secondly, matter contained in the report could lead to legal action and, thirdly, that could prejudice further investigations. Those reasons seem to me to be perfectly valid. I doubt that Senator Evans would disagree with that.

SPEECH.PARA: I will refer to what Senator Gietzelt said about the documents from the Narcotics Bureau leaked to the Opposition. I do not relish the thought of being the sole defender in this nation of the former Narcotics Bureau. But I am its defender and proud to be. Of course, there were crooked officers in the Narcotics Bureau, particularly in the latter years. That is inevitable in any law enforcement agency particularly when we are dealing with the commodity heroin which, as Senator Gietzelt suggested, has profits of around $250m a year emanating from its illegal importation. That is a profit greater even than that of Telecom Australia. That is the kind of league drug importation is in. That is the kind of money going into the hands of creatures who care not for any decency , who are totally amoral, immoral and, into the bargain, have formed relationships with overseas connections. I do not think any Australian need be in any doubt at this moment that those Australian criminals have now forged very strong and lasting links with overseas syndicates, particularly the Mafia. It is a serious situation in which we find ourselves. Totally amoral and immoral people, many of whom are known to many of us-we cannot name them because there is no evidence to justify a court action-have formed these associations with the Mafia and are earning profits of the magnitude I mentioned before.

I repeat that the fact that that kind of illegal money is being earned makes very few policemen in this country safe. I single out not only policemen; all magistrates and all politicians of all political parties are marks if this kind of money is available. An overwhelming majority of policemen, magistrates, politicians and judges would be honest and incorruptible if the potential bribe offered were $100 or $500. However, if the bribe suddently escalates to $200,000 a year, which would be petty cash to groups such as this, one must ask: Who is vulnerable?

I make two points. I am a bit disturbed at the Australian Labor Party. Mr Hayden started off the denigration of the Narcotics Bureau. I remind Senator Gietzelt, whom I respect and admire in these matters, that the disbandment of the Federal Narcotics Bureau was announced in this Parliament two or three years ago at precisely the time the Melbourne Cup was run. I do not regard that as fortuitous. Something stinks about the reason why the Federal Narcotics Bureau was disbanded. The thing that stinks is the stench that comes from the Queensland Police Force, the Wilsons and the way in which information was leaked . The Queensland Police Force, formerly close to Mr Hayden, would be one of the most corrupt, rotten and contemptible groups of people engaged in law enforcement in the world at this time. I view with disquiet a quotation by Senator Gietzelt, in good faith, from a letter by Brian Bates, an incorruptible policeman if ever I have known one. He said that from now on investigations into Nugan Hand will be covert instead of overt. That in itself is not mischievous but perhaps to quote him solely like that borders on mischief. Why did he do it? I would never believe that Brian Bates or his brother Harvey Bates-while they may have made errors of judgment-would have been got at by Nugan Hand.

TALK.START.PARA: —They could have been got at by a Minister or a government and given instructions.

—I acknowledge Senator Gietzelt's interjection and that is a worrying thing. I do not believe that either. I do not believe for a moment that a Labor Minister, a National Country Party Minister or a Liberal Party Minister was on the take. But there is something that stinks and I hope that this Task Force can get to it. I hope that its report will be better than the comparatively useless reports of the Williams commission and the Woodward commission. If ever there was a joke, a total waste of public money, a waste of at least hundreds of thousands of dollars-I think it got to millions of dollars- it was the compilation of the Woodward and Williams reports. The Woodward commission, having carte blanche to investigate corruption in the New South Wales Police Force, came up with what? It came up with the names of three policemen. The report is almost a joke.

SPEECH.PARA: I would be the last person to cast aspertions on Mr Justice Woodward's character. He is a fine, honourable man. However the report reveals absolute incompetence on the part of these people to unearth something-that the dogs are barking, that the police are corrupt, that magistrates are being got at and that court hearings are being changed suddenly to suit criminals and syndicates. The dogs in Sydney and Brisbane are barking yet a judge, sitting as a royal commissioner, can not find it. After spending $1m of taxpayers' money, all he can do is suggest that three policemen in Griffith or wherever may be on the take. That is not good enough.

When one reads, as I and most honourable senators read, of the infamous kinds of activities in which this covert organisation, the Central Intelligence Agency , is engaging-not just assassinating people likely to be unfriendly to the United States of America but financing the activities of creatures like Gaddafi and financing opium growing in the Golden Triangle-it is enough to send chills of fear through anybody. These facts are on record. There are allegations of a connection between the CIA, Nugan Hand and Australian criminals. I ask the Parliament to look at interim reports with restraint and to look at leaked documents seriously, as the Labor Party is doing. I commend it for that exercise . It astonishes me why the documents were not allowed to be incorporated yesterday in the House of Representatives Hansard. It is a difficult task and one with which we must proceed with great restraint.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Contrary to the expectations generated by Senator Chipp, I do not propose to canvass further any of the substantive questions that arise out of the report of the Joint Task Force on Drug Trafficking although undoubtedly they will deserve and demand the attention of this Parliament on a number of occasions in the future. I simply want to spend a few moments drawing the Parliament's attention to a policy matter of general importance which is raised by the conduct of this Task Force and the events of the last two or three days. It relates to the powers that are able to be exercised by these task forces and which set of rules, Commonwealth or State, they should operate under. The creation of joint task forces of this kind is a very significant advance in the efficiency and effectiveness of law enforcement in this country. It is a development that I certainly welcome and the Australian Labor Party welcomes. We believe it should be supported.

SPEECH.PARA: However, a question has arisen in recent days, following a meeting in Canberra of police commissioners from all around the country, as to the ground rules that should apply in the conduct of investigations by these joint task forces. It is a problem which arises because of the differences in the laws relating to criminal investigation, the powers of the police with respect to arrest, interrogation, search and seizure, and so on in the different jurisdictions involved. Those differences in the state of the law are not great at the moment, although there are some variations, and to the extent that there are variations at the moment, the rules are probably more stringent on Australian Federal Police than is the case for police forces in the States.

With the passage of the criminal investigation Bill, later this session or at least later this year, there will be some significant differences in the state of the law governing criminal investigation as between the Commonwealth and State level. What has happened in recent days is that the Police Commissioners, meeting in Canberra, have taken it upon themselves to express grave dissatisfaction at the prospect of the passage of the criminal investigation Bill. They met with the Attorney-General, Senator Durack, on Tuesday night and put to him the proposition that the Bill ought-in the words of the police commissioners-to be significantly improved if it is to form the basis of any future co-operation between the Commonwealth and the States. As I understand it, the view-this meeting has been the subject of a public statement issued by the commissioners-put by them to the Attorney-General is that the conduct of both this Task Force into the activities of the Nugan Hand group and related matters and all future joint task forces between the Commonwealth and the States would be gravely prejudiced if the States participating in such task forces were to find themselves in a situation of having to live with the application to such investigations of Commonwealth law as it would be after the passage of the criminal investigation Bill.

I simply make the point that it is my belief and that of the Opposition that the Government should strenuously resist this approach on the part of the police commissioners, in effect, further to emasculate the Criminal Investigation Bill now before the Parliament. A significant amount of snipping has already been going on with the Bill in its present form as compared with earlier manifestations of it. It would be most unfortunate if the process of emasculation were to be made complete as a result of the police representations to the Government.

I believe that much of the police attitude and the hostile attitude of the State commissioners to the terms of the Criminal Investigation Bill is based on a misunderstanding about the effect of its terms. I suspect-I have some direct knowledge of this-that their reaction has been more emotional than rational. Of course this is not the place to canvass the content of the Bill as it now stands . I think it can be simply and succinctly said that overwhelmingly that Bill introduced by Senator Durack late last year simply codifies and clarifies the very messy condition of the present common law governing police investigations to increase police powers in some significant respect so far as particular investigative procedures of stopping and searching, fingerprinting, and the conducting of some other forensic investigations are concerned and only in some limited respects to increase significantly the rights or the protections available to the suspect in the criminal process. The Bill as it now stands is already significantly weaker from a suspect's point of view, or from a civil liberties point of view, than that originally recommended by the Law Reform Commission in 1975. Sir Colin Woods has publicly put on record his view in recent months, that it is perfectly workable from a police point of view.

It is my view and that of the Opposition that, to the extent that the passage of the Criminal Investigation Bill at the Commonwealth level, roughly in its present form, results in a number of differences in the powers and duties available to and having to be met by police officers at Commonwealth and State levels joint task forces should operate under Federal or national investigation rules and not by the lowest common denominator standards which would otherwise be applicable. It is already the case that joint task forces like the one that we are discussing now are operating under Federal rules to the extent that they are using investigative procedures involving telephone tapping. It is only under Commonwealth legislation that telephone taps can be authorised at the moment. I cannot imagine that it would make any significant practical difference to the effectiveness of the operation of these joint task forces; nor can I imagine that any serious objection in principle could be mounted to the ground rules operating in the future being those rules of the Commonwealth-those relatively stringent, but often no more than what is presently the law, rules that will be created by the Criminal Investigation Bill.

Finally, I make it clear that the Labor Party certainly is not happy with every aspect of the Criminal Investigation Bill now before the Parliament. We will be moving a number of amendments when the Committee stage arises. We certainly believe that the present Bill is better than having no Bill at all. We certainly believe that the present Bill that is before the Parliament is better than the kind of Bill which, at the moment anyway, would win the unanimous assent of the present State police commissioners. So if Senator Durack sticks to his guns on this one-as I hope he will and as I hope the Government does-he and the Government will have the full support of the Labor Party.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator Sir JOHN CARRICK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for National Development and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —Drug trafficking must be regarded as one of the most serious issues before the Australian community. Certainly it is one of the gravest responsibilities of any government, Commonwealth or State. I reiterate that this Government and, I am sure, every member of the Parliament would want to pursue the exposure and destruction of drug trafficking to the greatest degree possible . Against that background I now put the matter into perspective as I see it. It is not for us to sit in this chamber making accusations against some person or some institution unless it is to point in a direction for investigation by others. The right probing must come from some judicial body. The real test is whether any judicial bodies of sufficient competence are in existence or have been in existence and, if so, whether their terms of reference are adequate. If the answer is no we should do something about it. That is the key. If anybody has any information let us give that information to such bodies.

SPEECH.PARA: As I understand it-I am subject to correction in detail-the two royal commissions in existence are the Woodward Royal Commission into Drug Trafficking set up by the New South Wales Government, of which Senator Chipp has been critical, and the Williams Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drugs set up by the Commonwealth Government. I understand that the Commonwealth Government invited the New South Wales Government to join it in the Commonwealth royal commission but that invitation was declined. It is essential that there should be links between Commonwealth and State governments in any inquiry of that nature. I recall that as a result of those inquiries the two royal commissioners approached the Commonwealth and suggested that a joint police task force should be set up. That was done in May 1979. That Commonwealth-New South Wales Joint Task Force on Drug Trafficking exists today. I think everyone would acknowledge that that was a good step forward. Honourable senators will bear in mind that, whatever the arguments about the matter of the Narcotics Bureau-I will come to that matter in a moment-the Commonwealth Police today are led by a police commissioner of international reputation.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Federal Police.
—I thank Senator Chipp very much. He is quite right. The Australian Federal Police are led by a man of international reputation and integrity. It is important to keep that in mind.

SPEECH.PARA: When the Woodward Royal Commission made public its views in its second report it exposed some matters that were of Commonwealth importance such as foreign exchange, importation matters, passports and fraud. On 26 August 1980 the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) proposed to the Premier of New South Wales that the terms of the Joint Task Force be widened to include Nugan Hand Ltd and others. The Premier of New South Wales agreed to that proposal. The Joint Task Force now has that specific responsibility. We have before us volume I of the report of the Task Force. I understand that there will be three or four volumes. The first volume refers principally to Murray Stewart Riley and Harry Wainwright but it has been indicated to me that the second volume will deal specifically with Nugan Hand Ltd. I understand that the second volume will be available in about a month. Yesterday, the Federal Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) was given the first volume and was told what the contents of the second volume would be. He has that information available to him. That is the background.
I recall that yesterday Mr Hayden sought to table a document which purported to be a particular document but he wanted to table it with names--

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you know which document it purported to be?
—I do not know. I think it was purported to have come from a department.
—Documents-plural.

—That is right. As I understand it-there may be some inaccuracies in what I say because I was not there and have not had a chance to read Hansard-he wanted to blank out any names in the documents. He said that he was doing that to protect people. The response of the Government was that it was imperative that the document contain names because the joint task force needs the document to put names and allegations together.

SPEECH.PARA: I shall put another proposition to the Senate: If one wants to do real damage and start all sorts of allegations one should publish a document which makes certain suggestions and leaves names blank. One will do more and not protect the people whose names have been blanked out but put a quite wrong odium on a range of people. I put that proposition quite fairly to the Senate. This problem is bigger than just a political argument across the benches. It is much bigger than that. I, as all honourable senators know, have no support at all for capital punishment in any form. Nevertheless I believe that the greatest mass murderers of our time are the heroin smugglers and pushers. Let me put that in its absolute magnitude: I loathe what they are doing. I have an intensity of loathing for it without any undue emotionalism. But one must be terribly careful that we do not simply place all sorts of allegations too widely where they are not to be. If a document exists it ought to be made available.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not follow you. I respect your view, but how can you protect people by deleting names?

—One is not protecting people by deleting names. As I understand it, Mr Hayden said he deleted the names to protect the people because there may be false allegations. I have said that the danger is that the public, when reading it, will put the wrong names in, and that will damage other people. That is the only point I am making. But that is not the important thing. The important thing is that the document should get into the hands of the joint task force because that is where it ought to be identified. That document ought to get into the hands of the Stewart Royal Commission. As I understand it, and I am trying to be as apolitical as possible on what I regard as a major subject, and I believe it to be so, the Commonwealth has said: 'If it is necessary to extend the terms of reference of the Stewart Royal Commission to embrace this or any other matter, tell us the need, although we understand from the royal commissioner it would not be necessary, and we will make that available'.

SPEECH.PARA: Fundamentally, however one might want to do point scoring in the Parliament on something, this game may be bigger. We all ought to stand up and be counted if any of us have any information at all on this matter. Our job is to go to the joint task force, to the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) and get the permission of the Crown law officers or go to the royal commissioner and put up the information and have it examined. The royal commissioner, I am quite sure, is willing to take information in confidence because it is a delicate matter. I do not believe that we should seek the protection of Parliament for the information we bring. We should seek the protection of Parliament to expose arguments and avenues, by all means.

The decision to disband the Narcotics Bureau, for good or ill, rightly or wrongly, was made in good faith by a Cabinet of which I was a member. It was done in good faith, whether it was right or wrong. I hold in respect the Bates officers. I want to be very careful that we do not in fact condemn all when there are only some villains. Let us pursue the villains. If anybody has any information at all, put it in the hands of those who are investigating the matter and it will get a fair hearing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is only because of the importance of the Commonwealth-New South Wales Joint Task Force on Drug Trafficking and the fact that we are talking about drug trafficking that I wish to make a few remarks. I intend to make some remarks concerning the comments passed by previous speakers. Senator Chipp drew attention to some of the points that I believe should be clarified in this place. Senator Chipp rightly pointed out that because of the large amount of moneys involved in drug trafficking people were open to bribery. He talked about people within departments, politicians, members of this place and members of the House of Representatives. I suppose he implied members of State parliaments. He also talked about the allegations against members of the Narcotics Bureau and of the corrupt police force in Queensland, and that is the major point about which I shall speak.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that this is a very serious matter, particularly the work being undertaken by the Joint Task Force. I refer also to the investigation that will take place in regard to Nugan Hand Ltd and also the information put forward by the Leader of the Opposition, Bill Hayden, in the House of Representatives. Senator Chipp said in general terms that the Queensland police force is one of the most corrupt police forces in the world. I do not believe I should allow that matter to lie there. His speech implied very clearly to me that it was an attack upon the total police force. When I was a member of the State Parliament and a member of the police committee I was probably noted as one of the critics of the Queensland police force-a very strong critic-and some of the action taken by it. But one lesson I learnt was to be very responsible in any attack that I made. I believe that some people in the police force are doing the job they are there to do. I believe they have as great an intention to see the drug problem in Australia cleaned up as have politicians in this place. I believe some protection should be afforded to those people. It is totally wrong generally to make the accusation that the police force is corrupt.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you defending the Commissioner? Come on, say so.

—I will not say whom I am defending. Senator Chipp does not have the evidence. Senator Chipp is naming people. It is very easy to name people in this place. We should allow the Joint Task Force, those commissions and those people investigating the matter to take the evidence, and then let us be the judge. Let us not judge on rumours, say so, correspondence or a story which someone has told. Let us not sit here and make a judgment in those conditions. We should let the royal commissions do the job. What I am saying is that an accusation of corruption of the Queensland police force is totally wrong. Members of that police force have families, are involved in the cities and the towns and are as good citizens if not better than some of the people in this place and in other places like it. Those general accusations should not be made until people have evidence to back up the accusations they have made, allow the Joint Task Force on Drug Trafficking to finish its investigation or allow royal commissions and the various people undertaking investigations to put their evidence before us. Too often the public says that all politicians are lazy and corrupt. I believe that is incorrect. I would speak against that type of statement in the same way as I have spoken against the general statement made about the Queensland police.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall speak very briefly in support of what Senator Jones said. I think it is very easy to make acusations, as he said, against the Queensland police force generally. In my experience the responsible members of the force, which is certainly the great majority, welcome moves to make things clear. My experience of the police force, and the Queensland force is no exception, is that the honest policemen-that is, most of the police force- welcome initiatives which will make sure that the force stays honest. There is nothing more distressing to an honest cop than a dishonest cop.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Text of a Statement by the Treasurer

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I wonder why the Senate is being placed in a position in which honourable senators are required, in a 10-minute contribution, to debate this very important policy statement on housing. When it was presented in the House of Representatives last week eight speakers contributed to the debate, four from the Government and four from the Opposition. To suit the convenience of the Senate last Thursday, I agreed that debate on the statement be held over to this week, but in so doing I did not agree that it be dealt with as one of the general ministerial papers because it is a statement of major significance. It represents a great departure from the procedures as well as the policies of this Government. The statement by the Treasurer (Mr Howard) can be seen only in the light of a panic move to deal with the housing problem on the eve of the election in Victoria. I do not want to take time away from my colleagues, but this procedure is a negation of the undertaking that was given that we would have adequate time to debate the statement and not compress the discussion into a few minutes.

I draw the attention of the Senate to what is involved in the statement. It is obviously a statement of such significance that the Government, in the last 10 days before the Victorian election, allocated $300,000 in order to popularise and bring to the notice of the electors in Victoria the importance of the statement. Yet we are denied in this place an opportunity, except for a 10- minute contribution from one person, to discuss the matter properly. I remind the Senate what the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) said on 22 February during the period of the Lowe by-election. At that time the Opposition and many interested welfare groups throughout Australia were saying that the housing problem was emerging as a major social and political issue in this country. The Prime Minister's response to that view was that the subsidisation of home buyers would be considered in the context of the next Budget. He said:

We're not going to be run off the main stream of our policies because of a by- election or a State election, and I believe we will have more respect by sticking with and staying with policies rather than offering some short term expedient that would not necessarily be a real answer.

The Prime Minister made that statement on 22 February. Yet, due to pressures exerted upon him by the ailing Victorian Liberal Government, the Premier of that State, the Master Builders Association and the Housing Industry Association, the Government has succumbed to the very short term expedient that the Prime Minister said he would resist. It is a clear case of pork barrelling of public funding because it is a short term, ad hoc approach. It gives to a select few persons a subsidy of about $22 per month to help them overcome the disastrous decision made by this Government to approve a one per cent increase in interest rates on home loans. That is the fifth increase in housing loan interest rates in the last two years, since April 1980. In less than two years this Government has given approval for the finance institutions of this country to increase home loan interest rates to the extent that they have risen from 9.5 per cent to 13.5 per cent. There is no indication that they will stop at that level. Despite the sugar-coated pill which Mr Howard introduced-he often introduces bad news in the Parliament, leaving Mr Fraser to bask in his own reflected glory-interest rates will not stop rising. In fact, as predicted by the Federal President of the Australian Labor Party, Mr Wran, we will see even more horrendous increases in interest rates during 1982.

What has the Government set out to do? It has given a subsidy to a particular set of people. A survey carried out by the Melbourne Institute of Applied Economic and Social Research estimated that, in 1980, 45 per cent of first home buyers, or 202,000 households, had incomes in excess of 150 per cent of average weekly earnings. The people who will benefit from this subsidy are those who earn in excess of $456 per week either as a single income or a joint income. They are the very people who will get the subsidy outlined in the statement. I submit to the Senate that that is a complete misuse of financial resources in this country. We know that only about 15 per cent of the Australian people are in that income bracket. We know that two-thirds of the Australian people receive less than average weekly earnings. Therefore, they will not in any way, shape or form be assisted by this package. It is no wonder, therefore, that the Australian Institute of Urban studies put out the following Press statement:
The Government's latest package only scratches the surface of the housing problem.
It still totally ignores the shrinking rental market and the mounting public housing crisis.
It offers a bribe to the greedy but does nothing for the needy, who- unfortunately for them-are still electorally outnumbered by the greedy.

Mr Kennett, several months ago, indulged in humbug and hypocrisy when it became apparent that the Fraser Government had reduced by 50 per cent the amount of funds to the States for public housing in its last three Budgets. He placed a series of advertisements in the newspapers and publicly criticised what the Government's policies were doing to those people needing housing, particularly in the public housing sector. Yet he is on the public record, because he is a candidate in an election, as saying that this housing package is a wonderful step forward. His Government has set out to try to match the subsidy by helping not the needy but those whose income is well above average weekly earnings. The rebate will apply only to the purchasers of houses over the last five years, that is 30 per cent of the 1.6 million citizens who are paying off their housing loans. Consequently, the Opposition is in agreement with the Press articles and with the statements made by those involved in the social welfare area that this housing package does not do anything to solve the basic housing problem that exists in our country. It does not solve the problem of homelessness that affects, increasingly, hundreds of thousands of people in Australia. It does nothing to raise to higher expectations those hundreds of thousands of people who dream of coming into the home ownership area.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer to the fact that the Fishing Industry Research Committee annual report is for the year 1979-80 and is therefore late in being presented to the Senate. I seek leave to move a motion in relation to it.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

DEBATE.TITLE: COMMONWEALTH SCIENTIFIC AND INDUSTRIAL RESEARCH ORGANISATION

PROCTEXT.PARA: Annual Report 1980-81

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I would like to make some constructive observations on the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation annual report which is presented with accompanying statement of the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Thomson). One could be led to believe that the CSIRO had the potential to provide a viable alternative to Mr Jacobi's proposal for an institute of freshwater studies. However, the proposals, as outlined by the Minister, do not comprise a response of a quality and level which would, in fact, be a viable alternative to the Institute of Freshwater Studies Bill which was agreed to by the Senate on 25 February this year and which has not yet been brought forward for debate in the other place.

The Minister's review and proposals do not address some of the key issues and regrettably dismiss others. The review is disappointing and has all the hallmarks of being hastily prepared and put together to provide at least some indication, or at least hope, that the CSIRO is about to set its house in order on water research. It would appear that the CSIRO approach, or rather its priorities are largely in the field of hydrology. Ecological studies figure hardly at all in the proposals and are scarcely mentioned directly even in its list of major research trends. Little reference is made to the limnology and biology management of freshwater ecosystems. In effect, the whole thrust of the Government's proposal for CSRIO is hydrological rather than ecological. Surely the Minister would appreciate that many of the water quality management problems that we face have a biological and an ecological base.

Research efforts should be expanded in three priority areas; namely, salinity and other quality aspects, ground water and catchment hydrology. Increased salinity problems, typically in the Murray-Darling system and in Western Australia, require basic information on mechanisms for formation and movement of water soluble salts. The level of additional resources involved requires a progressive build up from the present effort involving expenditure of some $4m to an amount of some $8m over a three-year period. This level of expansion would necessitate additional resources being made available to the Organisation. Co- ordination arrangements need to be improved also with other agencies undertaking water research or having policy responsibilities for water resource matters.

The real issue which this Government has failed to face up to was well summed up by Mr Jacobi in Saturday evening last when he was the guest speaker at the annual general meeting of the native fish Australian organisation which I also had the privilege of attending. I will quote from part of a speech made there by Mr Jacobi. I think it sums up the need for the Government to set about hastily setting up the Institute of Freshwater Studies which was agreed to by this House , as I said, on 25 February. Mr Jacobi said in a paper tabled on 22 February this year that the Government at least appears to have shown enough courage to grasp the nettle. There was a report on that paper in the Australian the next day. It stated:
The paper, prepared by the Department of Science and Technology, sets out comprehensive plans to change the role of the Government in scientific research.
It advocates the linking of government scientific research with economic and social issues, and the strengthening of ties between research and the needs of industry.
Mr Jacobi stated:

We must recognise the many practical shortcomings in water research and management if we are to correctly diagnose and cure our problems. If existing organisations are incapable of producing the necessary solutions then they must be changed, or new bodies must be created. But a so-called national authority, which is nothing more than an aggregation of representatives from State water departments, simply retains the limited perspective of these State bodies. The best answer is the establishment of the proposed Institute of Freshwater Studies , which cannot be shackled by State policy-makers and which can conduct balanced research into our most complex water problems. It can provide also independent and autonomous leadership, and by creating a body directly responsible to this Parliament we can ensure that water resource problems are given their proper priority and that funds provided by the Commonwealth are spent in the most efficient manner.

The challenge that faces us in water management was summed up by Professor Sandford Clark when he said 'Somehow we must also address, and display for rational decision, the political, social and environmental alternatives which must be weighed in the balance . . . We can provide only the leadership expected of us if we are adequately informed, and it is the duty of the Federal Parliament to seek out the knowledge required.
Mr Jacobi finished that part of his speech by saying:
Regrettably, this Government refuses to accept that responsibility.

I am concerned about the Press release put out by the Minister on 22 March-this week. He said that the CSIRO was going to have a review of the environmental problems in the one million square kilometre Murray-Darling Basin. I do not have time to quote from the release. It appears to both Mr Jacobi and me that this is a ploy being used by the Government to get itself off the hook by giving CSIRO another job to do which it is not fully equipped to do. It is a ploy the Government is using so that it will not have to bring on Mr Jacobi's Bill, which was passed in this place, and have it debated in the other place. This might bring about a split in its ranks. Many Government members agree with that Bill and the work that an institute of freshwater studies could carry out. I am very disappointed, as will be many other people, that the Government is now calling on the CSIRO to perform this work. Under its charter the CSIRO can be directed by the government of the day as to what it ought to do, not what the Organisation thinks it ought to do. Mr Acting Deputy President, I see that you are looking at the clock. I think it would be wrong of me to continue my remarks in the couple of minutes that I will have available to me later, so I conclude my remarks on that note.

As the Leader has said, the arrangements which are contained in the motion which he has moved today are similar to the arrangements which applied last year. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Sessional Orders of the Senate of 26 November 1980, relating to the days and hours of meeting, the suspension of sittings and the adjournment of the Senate, be amended to read as follows-
(a) Days and hours of meeting: That, unless otherwise ordered, the days and hours of meeting of the Senate shall be Tuesdays at 1.45 p.m., Wednesdays at 2 p .m., and Thursdays at 10 a.m.
(2) Suspension of sittings: That, unless otherwise ordered, the sitting of the Senate, or of a Committee of the Whole, as the case may be, shall be suspended from 6.30 p.m. till 8 p.m. on Wednesdays.

(3) Adjournment of the Senate: That, unless otherwise ordered, at 6.30 p.m. on Tuesdays, 10.30 p.m. on Wednesdays and 7.00 p.m. on Thursdays the President shall put the Question-That the Senate do now adjourn-which Question shall be open to debate; if the Senate be in Committee at that hour, the Chairman shall in like manner put the Question-That he do leave the Chair and report to the Senate; and upon such report being made the President shall forthwith put the Question-That the Senate do now adjourn-which Question shall be open to debate: Provided that if the Senate or the Committee be in Division at the time named, the President or the Chairman shall not put the Question referred to till the result of such Division has been declared; and if the business under discussion shall not have been disposed of at such adjournment it shall appear on the Notice Paper for the next sitting day.

I do not intend to keep the Senate long. This matter has been discussed for a long time in this place. In fact, when first I was elected in 1974, 15 new senators arrived at that time and after a few months many of us were concerned about the sitting hours. It seemed to us that they could be changed to improve the efficiency and the operations of this House and the operating efficiency of honourable senators themselves. Since then many people have been interested in and have from time to time discussed a possible change in the sitting hours. It has been a bipartisan-and in recent times, I suppose one could call it a tripartisan-discussion. Some who were active in it are no longer members of the Senate. The late Senator John Knight was very interested in this subject and, along with Senator Martin and others, had frequent discussions with us on this matter.

It seems to me that these discussions have gone on long enough and that the time has come to put the matter to the Senate. Last year a poll of senators clearly indicted a desire to reform the sitting hours. My motion has been worked out after a contributrion by many honourable senators on both sides and represents a suggested change in sitting hours within the present practice of this Parliament and this Senate of a three-day sitting week with broadcasts from the Senate on Wednesdays. That is the basic premise from which it was worked out . There are, of course, suggestions-many of which I would be attracted to-for changing that basic pattern of sitting hours. But in fact we are restricted by the present three-day sitting structure and the hours have been worked out to cope with that.

I suppose it would be desirable in some ways to introduce a reform of the sitting hours in both Houses simultaneously but I suggest that this is not on at present and that, if reform is considered desirable, it should and could well start in the Senate or it will not occur at all. I make no suggestions about, nor do I intend to debate at the moment, the distribution of business within the sitting hours I have suggested. It is not beyond the wit of those who organise such arrangements, I believe, to come to a satisfactory agreement about this. I am aware that some rearrangement will have to be made to party and committee activities held outside sitting hours. This, I suggest, is equally not beyond the wit of reasonable men and women in this place to arrange. Of course I am aware of the fact that some consensus of agreement will have to be reached about procedural matters such as quorums and contentious issues being introduced during what may be meal hours. This can and should be done to ensure the proper functioning of this chamber. I do not see any great difficulty in this. I confine my arguments to the sitting hours I have moved to establish and not to the details of business within them.

I am not one who argues for these changes primarily on health grounds. It seems to me that in the past there has been an idea that the best way to improve the health of honourable senators and honourable members in this place is to adjust the sitting hours. It is certainly a fact that the two evenings which will be available during the week and during which honourable senators can take part in recreational or cultural activities or whatever else they might like to do may in the long run have a spin-off beneficial to their health. I suspect, however, that Senator Harradine and many or most of us will in fact use the time for work , either in committee or as individuals. I argue strongly that such work will, in the absence of bells and the other distractions which occur in this place, be in fact more efficient and more satisfactory for the benefit of everyone inside and outside the Parliament.

In a conversation with Senator Harradine we suggested all sorts of thing that could be done on the night off. He said that we could go and play the poker machines, but he would do so only if we received an extra parliamentary allowance. I believe that many things could be done. But parliamentarians, being what they are, I suggest, will probably work, although I can assure honourable senators that I will not work every night if these hours are agreed to.

The hours I propose do not represent a reduction in the total sitting time; it is a re-arrangement of the total sitting time. As I said before, I believe it will make the work of senators more satisfactory and more efficient. The effect of the proposal will be to sit from 1.45 p.m. to 6.30 p.m. on Tuesdays and 10 a. m. to 7 p.m. on Thursdays with the exception of probably the first Tuesday of each session when we will start at the later time as we do now. That needs no extra motion as there is no motion to do that in the sessional orders. On these days the Senate would sit through the relevant meal hours although, in the case of the evening meal, I suggest that most people would wait until the Senate has adjourned to have it, but others may not. Certainly, if we sit through meal hours there will have to be some arrangement whereby contentious issues, quorums and other annoying procedures will not occur. That can surely be arranged between reasonable people.

On Wednesdays, the Senate will sit from 2 p.m. to 6.30 p.m., which is an extension of the present afternoon session, and from 8 p.m. to 10.30 p.m. We recognise that at the moment the Senate is broadcast on that day. It would be difficult and undesirable to change that broadcast arrangement. I suggest that most people would not want to do so. It seems to me that one of the difficulties in working as a member of parliament is that while the House is sitting-let us face it-most of us are doing other work unless we are directly involved or particularly interested in the debate taking place. It is well known that we organise committee meetings of various types. We see groups and delegations during those hours. We cram into our meal hours other committee meetings, both Senate and party. We come in early in the mornings to work a few hours before the sittings commence. When we try to sit on those committees or carry out other functions during the times of the sitting of the Senate we are continually interrupted. We are frequently interrupted by bells. Someone in my position, in the position of Leader of the Opposition or in a Minister's position is frequently interrupted by things to do with the business and procedures in this place.

The beauty of these sitting hours, I believe, is that they provide, on two nights a week and on the mornings before the Senate sits, time when there will be clear opportunities for us to do the important business of research and committee work and of seeing delegations. The new hours will also provide an opportunity, on Tuesday night and Thursday night, for members of this Parliament to act like civilised human beings, if they choose, and to go to the movies, see a play, read a book, watch television or something else. I propose these new hours of sittings acknowledging the work of Senator Martin over many years, Senator Knight before he died, Senator Peter Baume and Senator Chaney, I believe , before they became Ministers, and various people on this side of the House including Senator Robertson and Senator Sibraa. I urge the Senate to consider seriously the introduction of hours such as these so that we may even show the way to those ladies and gentlemen on the other side of the Parliament who seem to be more reluctant to change than we do. Then we will eventually have a parliament which will, as a whole, sit for far more sensible and civilised hours .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be brief on this subject. I raise at the beginning a matter that I think Senator Grimes is unaware of and which is confusing a number of honourable senators at the moment. As Senator Grimes indicated in the course of his speech, there have been quite extensive negotiations between him, Senator Robertson, Senator Sibraa, the Australian Democrats and honourable senators from the Government side. As he said in his speech, the sitting hours seek a re-arrangement and not a reduction of hours. In fact, the motion does entail a reduction of hours. Furthermore, we have been circulated, while Senator Grimes was speaking, with another document that shows certain hours of sitting which will involve a reduction of hours.

SPEECH.PARA: I point out to the Senate that Senator Grimes's motion should be slightly amended if it is to result in no reduction of hours. As the motion stands at present, sittings on Wednesday would commence at 2 o'clock and rise at 10.30 p.m . In fact, to have the same number of hours of sitting as we do now, it will be necessary for the Senate to sit at 1.45 p.m. on Wednesdays and not to commence the adjournment debate until 11 p.m. At present we have 21 1/2 hours of sitting time which comprises six hours on Tuesday, six and three quarter hours on Wednesday and eight and three quarter hours on Thursday. The motion as it appears in the Notice Paper and on the circulated document means that we will sit for four and three quarter hours on Tuesday, seven hours on Wednesday and nine hours on Thursday. That would give us a total of 20 3/4 hours sitting time as against the present 21 1/2 hours.

The changes that I have outlined entail sitting at 1.45 on Wednesday and commencing the adjournment debate at 11 p.m. We would sit 7 3/4 hours on Wednesday, which is the same total of hours as now. Those hours were discussed and finally agreed to as meeting all the basic criteria for sitting hours. I suspect that this document and the document on which Senator Grimes's notice of motion is based are out of date. Certainly, at one stage, a document was circulating containing the hours I have mentioned, but it became out of date in the last couple of days. There was some nipping and tucking. Senator Grimes shakes his head.

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree with you about 11 o'clock, but not with the starting time.
—And at 1.45 p.m. on Wednesdays?
—No, that was not my understanding, but I am easy.

—Well, Senator Grimes is easy on it. I reiterate that that would be necessary to give us the same total number of hours. The same total number of hours is a matter of some concern and some priority because, at present, there is a division of priorities in the Senate between Question Time, petitions, General Business, Government Bills, private members' business, matters of public importance and so on. The Government, currently, has access to eight and a half hours out of the total of 21 1/2 hours that we sit. That is not very high. Certain things are virtually fixed in our practice, and they are the non- government things. If the hours were to be cut back at all, Government time would be lost. I think the Government could reasonably feel that it was a little hard done by because Government Business does not take a large proportion of the total time of the Senate in any event. It is a detail that has significance in those terms to establish a principle.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to speak briefly on the merits of the motion. Senator Grimes indicated that this matter has arisen on a number of occasions but has rarely been addressed formally certainly in the Senate. Only once during the autumn session last year was it formally addressed when certain ballots were announced and certain speeches were made at the conclusion of the ballot. The situation then was that proposals were being considered outside the chambers which would involve both the Senate and the House of Representatives sitting altered times and sitting, basically, the same times. With the decision that there would not be any radical alteration of hours the House of Representatives made a small adjustment to its hours and the Senate continued with its previous hours.

Now the Senate seeks to move to a rather different pattern of sittings independently of the House of Representatives. Of course, there is no reason why we should not do that because we are masters of our own destiny. The fact is that we have duties, in this place, which are not just confined to the hours when the Senate is actually sitting. Those duties involve members of the House of Representatives. I name the obvious ones, such as joint parliamentary committees which have been created by both Houses of Parliament, party meetings, caucus meetings and so on which have some significance. Additionally there is a large expenditure on support facilities for members and senators, such as a dining room, a library, certain attendants, Hansard and so on. We have to have some responsibility in our approach to this matter to make sure that any change we make will not dislocate either those joint facilities or joint activities.

After considerable debate and discussion between individuals and, on some occasions, on behalf of other individuals, these are the hours that it is suggested be put forward to the Senate for its adoption. It is a compromise proposal. It is certainly not ideal. I would have thought the proposal that we considered this time last year outside the chambers was a better proposal over all. However, we are in the position of having to find a workable situation in which the Senate can move to sensible, workable hours without disrupting our other activities in the Parliament.

I make a brief reference to Senator John Knight. I first raised this matter of sitting hours in a government context in the Budget session in 1979. That was a matter that involved only the Government parties. Various individuals raised the issue with me in the early half of 1980. In the Budget session of 1980 I was overseas attending the United Nations as one of our parliamentary observers at the General Assembly. On my return, at the beginning of the autumn session last year, Senator John Knight, who was then the Government Whip, raised with me the issue of sitting hours and asked me whether I would restart the discussion on the subject. He indicated to me that there would be considerable support for starting these discussions again. I was feeling a little cranky at the way in which the matter had been treated on earlier occasions and said that I would engage myself in it only on condition that, firstly, there was public support from Government members and, secondly, that Senator Knight made available to me some of the facilities of his office so that it could be handled. That was on the Thursday night of the first week we sat. A few days later Senator Knight was dead. If there are honourable senators on either side of the chamber or, indeed, members of another chamber who think I became almost manic in my obsession with the subject during the autumn session last year, it had much to do with my own personal emotions at Senator Knight's death and the fact that he was the person who had asked me to initiate it. My own personal conviction is that he might not have met such an untimely death if we had approached our duties in a more sensible way.

Senator Grimes has covered a number of the issues. The basic need is a rational arrangement of our working hours, remembering that the public think the only hours we work are the hours that this chamber is meeting and indeed the hours that we actually sit in this chamber. It is not a matter of our working hours; it is a matter of our public hours here and when the workings of the parliament are on display to the general public. I doubt very much that our priorities are right in relation to the sitting of the chambers. If we choose to sit at night when we have already put in a full day's work, we are tired and we do not have the energy or the attention to bring to our duties in the evening that we ought. If we claim that we are working between 8 p.m. and 11 p.m. I want to know whom we think we are kidding. While many senators and members are in here while the chambers are working and while certain individuals are working because they have responsibilities in the chamber, most members and senators are just desperately trying to keep themselves on their feet until they go home. Last year I saw a Press comment on the subject of our sitting hours. It described the arrangement of the number of hours that we sit in any week as most inefficient. The comment was that if we set out to find a more inefficient way of arranging our hours it would be difficult to imagine what we could possibly come up with.

I support Senator Grimes's motion which I hope will be amended by somebody in line with the suggestions that I have put forward. The hours themselves are not magic. They will not assure all things to all people. In fact, a certain amount of good will and co-operation on both sides will be essential if they are to succeed. The matter of calling quorums and whatever cannot, in any way, be restricted. There are some working arrangements in this chamber which I think need to be looked at and thought about fairly carefully. I know there is much concern in certain areas relating to quorums and the adjournment. If we want these hours to work, they will work. If we do not want them to work, it will be very easy indeed to destroy them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make an explanation of a proposed alteration to my motion.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I accept Senator Martin's corrections. I explain that it is, indeed, my fault. So many things have been going backwards and forwards that I did not notice that in the motion the finishing time on Wednesday nights is 10. 30 p.m. when it should be 11 p.m., as it is now. I believe that a 2 p.m. start on Wednesdays is reasonable. Senator Martin says that 1.45 p.m. would bring the sitting hours to exactly the number we sit now. I am surprised that anyone would worry about a quarter of an hour. I therefore seek leave to amend my motion so that the adjournment motion is put at 11 p.m. on Wednesdays, with a starting time of 1.45 p.m. on that day.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support what has been said by many honourable senators both in this place and outside it and what has been said today by Senator Grimes and Senator Martin. It is my desire to reform the sitting hours, but I cannot believe that the reform of sitting hours proposed will be of any benefit to any honourable senator. I was surprised to hear what Senator Martin had to say at the end of her speech. I think that when she reads the Hansard record she will think that something went wrong in what she was trying to say. I do not think that Senator Martin believes that it is not a matter of what our working hours are but a matter of what the public think our working hours are. When she reads what she has said she might change her mind.

SPEECH.PARA: It really is a question of what our working hours are. It is proposed that we start sitting on Thursdays at 10 a.m. I am the Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances. That Committee has meetings which commence at 9 a.m. on Thursday mornings. Clearly, I will have to start these meetings at 8.30 a.m. So on a Thursday morning my day, and the day of members of that Committee, will commence at 8.30 a.m. I know that other committees also meet on Thursday mornings. I think the Joint Committee of Public Accounts or the Joint Parliamentary Committee on Public Works meet on that day. Clearly, our working day on Thursdays will start at 8.30 a.m. Honourable senators can say: ' All right but you have Tuesday night'. With respect, Senator Grimes said that, not me. He said: 'We have Tuesday night. I will not be working every Tuesday night. People will be able to go to the movies, see a play, read a book or whatever else they want to do'. I suggest that they will want to dine and dance. With respect, I do not believe that that is what honourable senators come to Canberra for. I believe that we come here to put in--

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a cheap way of getting your name in the newspapers. You will get a headline out of this. Big deal.
—With all due respect, Senator Chipp put forward his views in good faith and I am entitled to put forward my views. I firmly believe this.
—Who said anything about dancing?
—Of course that is what will go on. People will go out to dinner at various places. Good grief, Senator Chipp is a man of the world. He knows what happens in this world.
—Florence, will you join me next Thursday night? Which disco do you recommend, Senator?
—I would not know, Senator Chipp. I have never been to a disco in this town.
—That might explain a lot of things.

—Yes. I sincerely believe what I am saying: The day will be extended and not compressed by these hours. In fact what will happen is that honourable senators who meet on committees which now sit during their lunch hour will have less time for those committees but will still try to fit in that work. There are two points to the suggestion of some honourable senators that committees can sit at night. Firstly, I suggest that many honourable senators will find they are unable to go to those committee meetings because some other thing is being organised, for example, a visit to an embassy. We all get invitations to do that sort of thing. Honourable senators may stay on at the embassy longer. Secondly, we all know that politicians talk too much. At the moment when we have a committee meeting from 6 o'clock to 8 o'clock at least we know the meeting will be over at 8 o'clock. But if we start a meeting at 7 o' clock it may not finish till midnight. That is exactly the sort of thing that concerns honourable senators.

SPEECH.PARA: There are major problems associated with our task. The first I would like to mention to honourable senators is the problem of late nights. We sit on here far too late at night. Also we have long brackets of sitting hours. Look at what is proposed for sitting hours on a Thursday. On a Thursday in this chamber we would work-apart from what we had done the night before or the morning before-for nine consecutive hours. It is absolutely beyond me how any honourable senators could suggest that it would be of any benefit to honourable senators to try to cope with nine hours continuous work in this chamber.

I suggest that we should forget about the number of hours we should try to work and forget about the matter of broadcast days. We have the unbelievable suggestion that we sit through until 11 o'clock on Wednesday night just because it happens to be broadcast day. I suggest the change to our sitting hours should be that the Senate adjourn at 10 o'clock every night-Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday nights. We would sit at 8 o'clock and put in two hours to 10 o'clock. There could be some short-I hope they would be-adjournment addresses from 10 o' clock onwards.

TALK.START.PARA: —They will be longer with these hours.

—I agree with Senator McLaren, who said that adjournment speeches would be longer if the adjournment debate started at 6.30 or 7 o'clock at night. We can bet our bottom dollar that honourable senators will see an opportunity to make a speech at night which will get into the newspaper next day and so they will start to speak on matters that ought to be addressed in first reading debates. With respect to the honourable senators who proposed the motion-I know it has been done out of good will-I cannot support the proposal. I would certainly support a proposal that the Senate adjourn every evening at 10 o'clock .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats strongly support the motion proposed by Senator Grimes and supported by Senator Martin. I pay a tribute to both Senator Grimes and Senator Martin, and to the many other honourable senators who have worked tirelessly for a long period to try to introduce some form of sanity into our sitting hours. The fact they have kept their patience against the kind of addresses we have just heard adds to the credit that must accrue to them. I think I was one of the senators who put to Senator Martin the matter she mentioned. She said that if the Senate set up a committee to report on the most inefficient, most unhealthy, most wasteful and most expensive sitting times possible it would come up with the kinds of hours we are sitting right now. In my mind there is no question about that. The strain on both body and mind is intolerable. As I understand from Senator Grimes and Senator Martin the motion seeks to do two things: One is to acknowledge the insanity of the hours we are now sitting and the second is to try the new hours as an experiment to see whether they improve things. If they do not and if the worst of Senator Lewis's fears are realised, if we find Senator Missen and Senator Walters whirling around in Juliana's Discotheque at unhealthy hours of the morning, we will say Senator Lewis is right. We might have to revise our thinking.
—Fortunately they never dance.

—I hope Senator Missen is not reflecting on Senator Walters's dancing qualities. We could say to a committee: 'The Senate wants to sit 21 1/2 hours a week. Sort those 21 1/2 hours into three days of the week'. The hours we sit now would be considered the absolute worst from every point of view. I agree with Senator Lewis; these proposals may well lead to more problems.
—That is right.

—Let us look at those proposals. At least let us try them. Let us give them a chance and if necessary revise them in the light of experience. I react very strongly to being treated like a schoolboy and being a virtual prisoner in this place. Unlike other parliaments--
—You don't have to be.

—With great respect, Senator Walters, we do. For example, if we happen to be at an embassy, meeting important overseas visitors and engaged in important conversations, none of us dares be back here at one minute past eight. That demonstrates the schoolboy treatment to which I object. Some honourable senator might try to be a smart-Alick, call a division and catch the other side- if honourable senators will forgive the well known expression-'with its pants down'. Next day there would be a headline 'Government defeated' and all that rubbish just because a couple of honourable senators happened to be at a meeting . I cite the classic case of those of us who like to see the Australian films presented from time to time by various Ministers. A great number of honourable members and honourable senators see those and so they should. If such a film ends a little late, for example at five minutes to eight, does that mean that if honourable senators are back here a few minutes late and a division is called in the meantime a government can be defeated? The way we live here is absurd. I object strenously to that. I think it adds to the tenson and the unnatural way we treat the institution.

SPEECH.PARA: What could these reformed sitting hours achieve? Certainly they could achieve a better committee system, notwithstanding the real difficulties Senator Lewis has pointed out. Does any honourable senator really believe that the back bench committee system, let alone the select and standing committee system, is working satisfactorily? I have been on back bench committees for 18 years. Everyone knows the system. For example, we meet at 6 o'clock after having done a hard day 's work. We have a drink, talk for a quarter of an hour, have a meal till quarter to seven, listen to a guest speaker for half an hour and then have 20 minutes to question or cross-examine the witness before the bells start ringing at five to eight.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a lot different these days. You are out of date.

—I suggest that even if we do not have a guest speaker and even if we do start talking over the steaks and other fare the system presents difficulties. With great respect to Senator Walters, I do not know that the concertinaing of discussions on important matters is the best way to come to decisions on very difficult problems. One of the things that attract us to politics is the fact that very few issues are stark black or stark white. There is a grey area which means that on every subject there is a bit of right and a bit of wrong. The thing that is fascinating about politics is that by talking to people and hearing other people's points of view we can come to a consensus. The kind of atmosphere that prevails here between 6 and 8 o'clock, when we are forced to have our backbench meetings, is not conducive to lack of tension and to reaching consensus, particularly when one pursues the more technical and legal matters, as does Senator Missen. Without being cynical or critical I think the Executive or the Cabinet, whether it be Labor or Liberal, has a vested interest in not changing the hours.
—Is it opposing this?
—No.
—So, be fair.

—I am coming to that. I think that in this instance the Executive is being very generous. I was about to say that when the honourable senator pre- empted me. I am making the general point that an Executive would have a natural wish to preserve the current hours. The last thing any Executive wants-this is not criticism of an Executive-is a highly efficient, well-staffed group of backbench committees which have unlimited time in which to examine closely proposed legislation that is coming forward.

SPEECH.PARA: I have not mentioned lunchtime meetings which are a joke. It is impossible to have any real discussion at such meetings. Also I would have thought that they are decidedly unhealthy to honourable senators. I am not reflecting on the quality of the food, to which Senator Martyr might well refer. However, this is imposing an incredibly unhealthy lifestyle on a person.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is free at lunchtime. Well, ours was.

—Mr President, for your information-you have a vested interest in this matter-Senator Martyr ought immediately to disclose which committees get free food. I think all of us have an interest in that matter. We come in here at 8 o'clock or whatever in the morning. We then go on to the insanity of a lunchtime meeting, still confined in an artificial atmosphere, walking through smoke-filled corridors and into smoke-filled rooms, instead of being able to go out and enjoy some form of exercise. This is not only unproductive but also decidedly unhealthy.
—How would these hours help that?

—I suggest that these hours do not help the immediate problem of the luncheon break but they certainly give an opportunity to meet, without a pressurising ending time, in the evening. Senator Lewis put forward the point that politicians talk too much. Committees will go on too late and we will probably find ourselves sitting beyond 11 o'clock. I think there will be a self- disciplining factor within committees. Senator Lewis has been here long enough to know-unless he is one of the offenders-that politicans, while they do have faults and do talk too much, have an incredibly efficient way of dealing with wafflers. In fact a waffler soon has newspapers rustled in his face and people start walking out of the room. I would not have thought that that is a serious objection.

SPEECH.PARA: I have heard many honourable senators speak in a very wise and deep way on foreign affairs, and so they should. We hear some tremendous speeches from both sides of the House. However, is it not true that the present sitting hours deny us any real opportunity of meeting the diplomatic corps of Canberra?

TALK.START.PARA: —We are not all interested in that.
—Quite, we are not all interested. But there are a great number--
—Most of us would be.

—I think most honourable senators are interested in international affairs. The way in which we have discussions with the diplomatic corps-unless we come here on a Monday or stay over a weekend-borders on the ridiculous. When there is a cocktail party at an embassy one arrives there at 6.15 p.m. or 6.20 p .m. Something totally indigestible is thrust into one's left hand and a drink is thrust into one's right hand. One has a few conversations on one's feet with a few people--
—Cigarettes.
