—Again this happens in a smoke-filled atmosphere. We are unable to get into any in depth conversation with a diplomat or member of our foreign service and by 7.45 p.m. people start to panic, the cars roll up and we come back here. How in the name of goodness can anybody have an in depth conversation with a Russian about Afghanistan? How can one have an in depth conversation with a Russian about Afghanistan anyway? However, at least in a civilised time scale one could conduct-even Senator Lewis with his legal training could conduct-a proper cross-examination of a Russian diplomat about Russia's intentions in Afghanistan.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn to our relationship with the Public Service and outside groups. How many honourable senators have appointments with important people from, say, industry and commerce? We are all stupid because we say: 'I think three o'clock on Thursday will be a non-busy time. We will have an appointment then.' Honourable senators meet top people from industry, the Public Service or whatever. It just so happens because of the way this place works-it is nobody's fault; it is inevitable-that at three o'clock absolute chaos might descend on the Senate or there might be some sort of crisis. This is happening to me right now. I happen to have had an appointment at three o'clock with some important people from the ethnic community. I have had to keep them waiting for half an hour. That has happened to every honourable member in this place and it will continue to happen to them. I believe it is a ridiculous way in which to conduct our affairs.

One could mention that the relationship between the Senate and the Press could well be improved if more time were given. Relationships between the Parliament and the Ministry could be improved. Let us look at the kinds of question that we face. I will give one example. We understand that amendments to the industrial relations legislation will be introduced into the House of Representatives some time today. We do not know when-we cannot find out-but they are of a controversial and fundamental nature. Is it not the wish of many honourable senators on both sides of the chamber to talk with employers about what effect they think these sorts of amendments to the Conciliation and Arbitration Act will have? Do members not think it is important to talk to trade unions about what effects this legislation will have? Within the kind of time scale that the present schedule allows, can only honourable senator really say: 'Yes, I have two hours when I can sit down with you and discuss these matters at some length' . Most honourable senators who are on committees, who attend party meetings, who attend standing committees, select committees, and party committees and then have to attend the sittings of the Senate find that it is impossible.

I concede that to change the sitting hours is a bold step. I congratulate very sincerely those who are associated with it. However, it will need good will for it to work. There are people in the Senate chamber who, no doubt for good reasons, call quorums and divisions. I am not questioning their right to do that or the fact that they do it. I am saying that if we are going to give this system a fair go, the calling of quorums and divisions at times-unless they are absolutely fundamental to an issue-could well be sacrificed to give this system a fair go.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be very brief. I congratulate anybody who is going to try to get some improvement out of the sitting times that we have at present. I do not think any of us are satisfied with what we have now. The main problem is the time that we finish at night. A proposition which still allows for an 11 o'clock finish, to me, does not constitute an adequate improvement on what we have. The only people that it would suit to be working at 11 o'clock at night are probably not in the chamber now; probably they are having an afternoon snooze. We will not get anywhere without a little more rationalisation all over.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to find a way in which we can achieve what we are after without having to sit through the meal hours. I do not think a continuous sitting is in our best interests as those honourable senators who have commitments in the chamber still have to fit in a meal. If a honourable senator thinks that he or she may be the next speaker in a debate or the speaker after that he or she will be in trouble here or in the cookhouse. The staff members of this place also have to eat and some reasonable arrangements have to be made to suit them. We have to accommodate these other people a little bit more.

We have a problem with things such as joint committees. Senator Elstob and Senator McIntosh, for instance, could attest to the fact that it would be very difficult to have a Joint Publications Committee meeting when the Senate was sitting and the other House was not. There would have to be a break from the normal routine of the committee meetings. A lot of reorganising would be required to avoid interfering with time slots that have been allocated to other business for some years. I realise that these matters can be attended to but we need to take them into account before we make a firm decision. I agree that we have appointments during the day that are nearly always difficult to keep. I have just had handed to me a piece of paper which states that a gentleman is waiting in my office right now. I have to dash off to see him and that is another reason why I will not be speaking too long.

As one who has never spoken in the adjournment debate since I came into this Parliament I have grave reservations about whether it is reasonable to put constraints on those people who wish to participate in that debate. I believe it represents one of the freedoms that the ordinary back bench member has in this place. Yet if we do not put constraints on them it will be difficult to organise anything. The number of times we get an opportunity to receive visitors or to have a meal on our own, even in the dining room here, is so limited that reasonable arrangements would have to be made if this proposal were to work. I cannot see that this proposal will change the number of hours of any of us who want to work or have commitments which suggest that we should work. Those who do not want to work all the time now will soon find that they can rearrange their hours and still not work all the time. Those who do work will be putting in at least as many hours as they do now, whether it be in this place or outside the Parliament. They will still be doing the same thing.

One of the important things that I do when I come to Canberra is to see people from departments, from industry, and various lobby groups, as they are sometimes called, or the various interest groups, as I prefer to call them. I want to be able to see them on much the same basis as now. I think we all do. I think we should not make it difficult for them by saying: 'I can see you but not until 9. 15 p.m. I have a meeting at 7 p.m. When we come out of that meeting at 9.15 I will be able to see you'. I do not think it is reasonable to expect people from the Public Service to come to see us at all sorts of ridiculous hours such as that. I think we have to take these matters into account.

I want to see some changes. I certainly want to see some improvements. I do not want to see our ranks decimated by people dropping over because they cannot take the pressures of the place. At this juncture I am prepared to give anything a go that may be an improvement. I would like to see this proposal run for a period at the end of which, failing other alternatives, we go back to what we now have. I would like to see a change but the change should be a temporary one so that we still have our present arrangement to fall back on. I would support implementing this proposal for the balance of this session if after that we could revert to the present arrangement or come up with some other improvement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the proposal for new sitting hours which is before us today. I am in agreement with what Senator Archer has just said. Of course, this ought to be only a temporary measure at which we ought to look again. If this proposal is implemented until the end of this session I do not think it will be long enough to judge the effect on the members and their activities. It will not be a long enough time to rearrange the sitting times of committees and do the other things which have to be done. I certainly think before Christmas we should look at this matter again to see how it is working and whether or not it is right for us. The points that were made by Senator Lewis should rightly be considered. If honourable senators intend to speak in the adjournment debate for long hours and thus still keep the Senate sitting late at night I for one will not stay here and keep the House for them. I hope that other honourable senators will not stay here either. We must look at whether people intend to treat the adjournment in that way.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe sitting hours have serious effects not only on the health of members of parliament but also on the way in which they do their business. Why should we be expected to come here on three days of the week and sit until late at night each day? Other organisations do not do this. Nobody expects people to concentrate, morning, noon and night on the one work in the one building. When we go out at night we do not know what the weather has been like during the day because we have forgotten to look through the window, or we have not been outside.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is good in Canberra. You can be sure of it.

—The honourable senator from the Australian Capital Territory said that we should be looking at the weather of the Australian Capital Territory, that we should be enjoying a bit of the beautiful climate here, which we do not do because of the hours that we sit. The important thing about this proposal-which should only be a trial-is that we will have relatively early nights two nights of the week as opposed to our present three late nights a week . This proposal has all the advantages referred to by other honourable senators; namely, that we can then go out somewhere at night. This does not mean to say that we will all be going to discos and so on. Some of us are beyond that. Other honourable senators might have ambitions. Some honourable senators have friends in the Australian Capital Territory whom they never meet as they know that they have to tear back to Parliament.
—And families.

—Other honourable senators have families. We do not visit these friends because it is useless if we have to rush away at 7.45 p.m., to be back in the chamber for the resumption. This Parliament plays no part in the lives of the people who live in Canberra and who represent their countries here. Why should they bother to invite us to any functions when we run away very quickly from such functions? It is important that we endeavour to keep some contact with the ordinary life of the community when we are away from the major cities of Australia. We should at least retain some contact with Canberra and with the people whom we know here.

SPEECH.PARA: It is important in terms of the health and welfare of parliamentarians and for efficiency with which we conduct out business to give this proposal a trial. The hours which have been suggested have a reasonable possibility of being quite successful. I think parliamentary committees will work in with these hours quite well. We will not want to take up every night with committee work, but I think we will be able to fit committees in better than we do at the moment. At present we have to attend a mass of committees. I have some 11 parliamentary or party committees that I have to attend at one stage or another. One often finds that one has three committees sitting at one time. Therefore, one makes a random choice and attends a different committee every week. I think we could organise these things better if the Parlament did not sit for these long hours at night. To my mind that is the killer, the thing which has endangered the health of members in this place. Another factor might be the food to which we are subjected in Parliament. Recently I had the food prepared in this Parliament analysed as the meals I have had in this place have been absolutely outrageous. I have taken steps and fortunately the parliamentary cooks are willing to fall into line with my thinking on this subject. We should not be the victims of the meals in this place. We should have the opportunity of making a choice. Generally I believe that what has been said today is--

TALK.START.PARA: —There is nothing wrong with the meals here.

—It is all right for the honourable senator. The meals here have produced him and they have produced me. They disagree with me but they do not disagree with the honourable senator. He must be made of tougher old stock.
—I agree with you. They would kill a brown dog.

—Senator McLaren can continue eating the meals here and I will eat elsewhere. I believe the proposal, which has come from honourable senators who have pushed for it for years-I have been behind it-is to be commended. We ought to try the system and if it does not work properly we should change it a bit. Therefore, the Parliament will act sensibly and will not try to work morning, noon and night, and therefore inefficiently.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I interrupt the debate to seek leave to have a table which I have circulated incorporated in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The table read as follows-
SENATOR LEWIS'S PROPOSED SITTING HOURS
Tuesday 2.00 p.m. to 6.00 p.m. 8.00 p.m. to 10.00 p.m. Wednesday 2.00 p.m. to 6.00 p.m. 8.00 p.m. to 10.00 p.m. Thursday 10.30 a.m. to 1.00 p.m. 2.00 p.m. to 6.00 p.m. 8.00 p.m. to 10.00 p.m.
Hours Tuesday 6 hours
Wednesday 6 hours
Thursday 2 1/2
4 hours
2 hours
20 1/2 hours

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Townley Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think a few points should be made. I refer to the last point Senator Missen made about food. I have seen the food prepared for him recently and I commend it, as somebody who knows a little about food, and most of us do. The kitchen staff here are doing an excellent job. I do not agree with some of the other statements made about the food. I do not know where honourable senators were eating before they came here but they must have been pretty flash places if they think the food in this place is no good. It is very good food. If honourable senators could be bothered reading a few books on food they would know that they could always choose a well balanced diet-something that is quite good for them. If we did not have too much of the coffee, tea and other things we would have a pretty well balanced meal. Somebody was talking about missing meals.
—Order! Senator Townley, I hope you are relating your remarks about meal times to sitting times and not to the dietary problems of certain senators.

—Mr President, you know I would not argue about a cup of tea. Half the people in this chamber would be much better off it they went without a few meals, myself included. If I ate three meals a day that would be one or two too many. I will not become personal, but for many people's benefit it would be good if we did not have any lunch hours at all.

SPEECH.PARA: Having said that, there are a couple of quite serious matters I wish to talk about. First of all, Senator Chipp said that a certain amount of good will will be needed to get this system working. I am one of those who have been very much in favour of a change-not a reduction but a change-in hours for quite a long time. As well as a certain amount of good will, we will need a fairly long trial term for this system. We know that we have perhaps another four sitting weeks till the end of this session. Often during that time the Government will have extra work that it will need to get done. That could lead as all to a wrong conclusion about whether these hours are in fact working because we will have to sit some hours, I think, before the end of the session other than these proposed hours that we will agree to in a short time.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is better than sitting until two or three in the morning.

—I agree entirely; it is better than sitting until two or there in the morning. I have always said that that is crazy. I have always been surprised that somebody has not died as a direct result of those crazy hours. When we explain to members of the public at large that most politicans come in here some time between 8 a.m. and 9 a.m. and do not usually leave the building until 11 p.m. they reckon we are crazy. It is not only ourselves whom we should consider. No Ministers have spoken about this matter, but if I were a Minister I would look forward to having two nights free a week either to work or to go to a Cabinet meeting. I think some Ministers would agree with me. I have noted that none of the Ministers has complained about this change. It has been quite evident that they, without saying so, want to try it.

SPEECH.PARA: I bet that when we try these hours it will not be long before the House of Representatives adopts them as well. When that happens it will leave room for a lot of other changes that could eventually make these hours much more sensible for everybody in this building. We must not forget the staff who work here. There are people here who have to work for an hour after we leave and yet they have to be back before any of us get here the next morning. There are those associated with the printing of parliamentary papers. A lot of us, unfortunately , take too much for granted. We should be thinking of them. It is not only the individual senators' hours we are talking about; it is the staff hours as well. Admittedly some staff will be a bit annoyed that they will not get as much overtime as they might, but I do not think that is the important thing. Their health is more important, in my mind, than the amount of money that they might get from overtime. The matter is of such importance that we were recently sent a booklet discussing how dangerous the parliamentary lifestyle is. We were also sent a booklet containing helpful hints on healthy living. Whoever wrote this booklet must have written it for politicans because just about everything we do is wrong, according to that book.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a fine book, is it not?

—Did Senator Peter Baume write it? It does not have his name on it. I find that most of the things Tasmanians do are entirely wrong. I did not mean that we should not cast aspersions on the Government. I am glad to see that we are to move to the same number of hours. I think the hours will be more sensible. They will lead to Cabinet being uninterrupted and committees having better areas than they have now. It will help the health of everybody, particularly if they get out of this building. I do not think, as Senator Lewis did, that getting out of this building is a bad thing. He seemed to say it was a crime to go out and have a meal at night. I do not think it is a crime. I think it is sensible because everybody needs a break from the madness of this House.
—I had a few months break and I did not like it much.
—Many of us were glad to see Senator Martyr back in Parliament even if in a different costume.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the proposals put forward by Senator Grimes which I understand have some consensus approach to what I consider to be the effective working of the Senate. I think they will enable us to have a much more civilised day of activity and will improve not only the health of members of the Senate but also the efficiency of the Senate. I do not believe that when we decided to become members of parliament we also decided to enter an endurance test, and that is what it is. I do not think anybody in this country expects us to cram into three days more than a 40 hour week, and that is what we do. Nobody expects us, in addition to that, to go back and perform our normal duties. Any change, in my view, is beneficial. The sort of change recommended is considerably more than beneficial because I believe the work of the Senate will be considerably improved.

SPEECH.PARA: It is not the first time we have made endeavours to change the sitting hours. We have always had some resistance to change. I can remember the period when former Senator Murphy was the Leader of the Government in this place. He introduced for a short period a 6.30 break on Tuesday and Thursday nights, and it was very popular. I remember the Western Australians were very happy to be able to catch a plane back on a Thursday night, but things changed. We somehow got back into the bad old ways and we did not profit. I recall that Senator Martin attempted to put into effect some proposals which would have improved the working conditions of the Senate. I think we have to consider also the working conditions not only of the Senate but also of the journalists who have to put up with our speaking for these long periods. I hope that they will be very interested in the proposals which will keep us within the same number of hours but will enable us to work in a much more rational way.

I am certainly attracted to any proposition that enables us to find out a little about what happens outside this place. We do not even know sometimes whether it is raining outside because we are in here from 9 a.m. and it is 11 o' clock at night before we go out to enjoy a bit of fresh air. It must surely be recognised that we work during our lunch hours and evening meal periods in the committees of the various parties to which we belong. We do not have the opportunity to get any fresh air, least of all any fresh ideas. I think we all could put up with a few more of those.

The House of Representatives has already taken a tentative step-the sort of step suggested in the amendment proposed by Senator Lewis. It is not good enough . We have the absurd situation at the moment where, because the House of Representatives meets earlier than the Senate, the party committee meetings start at a quarter to one. We may be sitting in the chamber because we are dealing with Bills. The work of the party committees has begun by the time we get to the meetings. We are ready to keep the battle going and the House of Representatives members are leaving because the House of Representatives begins its sittings earlier. In many ways we are acting as though we live in two different countries instead of working in unison. I agree with the last couple of Government speakers who have indicated that when we take this step we will probably prod the House of Representatives to shift away from the tentative step it has taken to move to a much more realistic set of working hours.

I am attracted to the idea for a number of reasons. Firstly, we will have an opportunity to know a little about Canberra. Senator Reid, as a Canberra representative, will be happy about that, I am sure. We come to Canberra on Monday nights and leave on Friday mornings. We never get a chance to look at the wonderful city of Canberra. The proposed new sittings hours would give us an opportunity to taste even the Canberra points of view as well as its food which, in this place, has deteriorated alarmingly in recent times. The new sitting hours would give us an opportunity to get to know some of the public interest groups that operate in Canberra. I am attracted to the proposition that Senator Chipp raised. Therefore, I disagree with the point that Senator Missen made.

I find one thing strange about the Canberra scene. I learned a great deal in local government about the capacity to mix with, socialise with and learn from its full time officers. I was able to be influenced by them and learn from their expertise about town planning, health matters and public administration. We have no access to that sort of experience in Canberra. If we are able to get a public servant to talk at a committee meeting we usually find that by the time we have had a quick lunch and asked a couple of questions the bells are ringing and we have to get back to the chamber. It is a most unsatisfactory way in which to conduct a meaningful dialogue with people who, it has to be recognised, are experts in their particular fields. That is not to say that we have to adopt their ideas but at least they could inform us about matters on which we might want some information. We would then be able to make a much more reasoned and balanced judgment about the matters we had discussed with the Public Service. That opportunity is denied to us at the moment.

I am not sure that the situation will necessarily be easier under the new sitting hours but at least we would have a chance to socialise with public servants if we wanted to do so. We cannot do so at the moment. I know all the prescriptions about the Crimes Act and so on but I would dearly love to get among public servants to find out a little more about how the bureaucracy ticks. It would contribute to the more effective functioning of the Parliament if we had that opportunity. I think any change at all, even Senator Lewis's proposal, would be better than the existing arrangements but I am for taking the more far- reaching step that was suggested by Senator Grimes, which appears to have quite a lot of support in the place. If the Senate agrees with it, it will show again that it is capable of making decisions which will be of some benefit to the Senate and, ultimately, to the House of Representatives.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am also opposed to the proposed new sitting hours.
—Go on!

—At least I have surprised Senator Chipp. He talked about the need for social activities, such as cocktail parties at the embassies. I understand that that is a most important part of the process of government, particularly if members of parliament are interested in foreign affairs. But I think everybody has forgotten that social activities also take place at lunchtime. I will give honourable senators an example. I was invited to a lunch today held by the Pulp and Paper Workers Federation of Australia. I arrived at ten past one and left at five to two. That is not a very long time. I was able to listen to the major speech. I was not able to listen to any other speech. Under the proposed new sitting hours all lunch hours would be ruled out. On a Tuesday I would have had to be back in the chamber by a quarter to two. That would have ruled out completely any social engagement.

SPEECH.PARA: On Thursdays I would have to stay in the building. There is no guarantee that a quorum or division would not be called. I would not be allowed out of the building between 10 a.m. and 7 p.m. No lunch hour engagements at all could be undertaken outside the building. Many of us have lunch hour appointments and social engagements. Somebody referred to social appointments with representatives of industry and commerce.

TALK.START.PARA: —And play tennis.
—Personally, I do not play tennis, although I think after Senator Chipp's comment I ought to watch myself. Many of our colleagues in this place play tennis.
—How do they get the time to do that?

—They do it in their lunch hours but they would not be able to do so under the proposed new sitting hours. I am sure that Senator McLaren will not give up his right to call a quorum in the middle of the lunch hour.
—I will not, no. Under the Standing Orders, while the right is there, I will reserve it and the right to speak on the adjournment.

—So Senator McLaren should. I believe that the proposal before us today tries to deny him that right. It is something for which he should be fighting vigorously. I assure you, Mr President, that on Thursdays I for one will not enjoy having to leave a hot meal in the dining room or a meeting to answer the call for a quorum or a division in the chamber.
—Have a hot meal at night.

—It does not matter whether it is a hot meal. Even if I were sitting over my ice cream I would not be particularly keen on leaving it to melt while I attended a division or a quorum. I think it would be a most inefficient way of organising the sitting hours. If there had been some written agreement on the calling of quorums and divisions it would have been a different matter but I believe it is entirely wrong for the Senate to sit over meal times. It will inhibit many of us from attending functions in the Capital Territory during those hours.
—Don't you believe that gentle- persons' agreements work?

—I do not believe that they work in this place. I have been here long enough to have seen that they do not work. I do not think anybody has mentioned-perhaps one of the organisers of the proposal, Senator Martin or Senator Grimes, could answer this-whether a costing has been carried out on keeping the dining room open. We have not heard when the dining room will close on Tuesdays, Wednesdays or Thursdays.
—Trust us.
—I do not trust anyone in this place.
—That is a bit nasty. What about Senator Hamer? Don't you trust him? He sits next to you.
—It depends on what Senator Chipp is asking me to trust him with .
—He does not trust you.

—I think it is mutual. Until what time will the dining room be kept open on Tuesdays, Wednesdays and Thursdays? If the adjournment debate goes on until nine o'clock, as it could, will we keep the dining room open until 10 o 'clock at night or are we meant to go there during the adjournment debate and not listen attentively to our colleagues on the other side tell us what sort of things they have received in the mail that week?

SPEECH.PARA: We have also been informed that after 6.30 at night we can all have meetings of our Senate standing committees. Has anybody costed the additional overtime work that will be required? Has anybody asked the secretaries and research officers of those standing committees whether they are particularly keen to be kept here until 9 or 10 o'clock at night on Tuesday and Thursday evenings? That is what it is expected we will do with the additional time we have been given. I do not believe that anybody has really approached our Senate staff to ask whether they are very happy to stay on until 10 o'clock at night to service the Senate standing committees. I think that the Hansard staff attending some of our Senate standing committee meetings at that hour of night might not be too happy about it either. According to what we have been told this could be quite possible. I have just learnt that this practice was tried in Senator Murphy's time.

TALK.START.PARA: —We did not hear that. Could you say it again?
—It was tried in Senator Murphy's time.
—Until you people ruined it.
—I would like Senator Keeffe to tell us why it was stopped. I have no knowledge of why that was done.
—Because the Government changed office; you people changed it. We got up at 4.30 p.m. on Thursdays.
—I do not believe that is so. I came in with the new government and there was no discussion of hours at all. I would like someone who was in the place at that time to tell my why it was stopped.
—Because the Government changed.
—We got up at 4.30 p.m. on a Thursday. You people came in and changed it.

—I am not talking about Thursday afternoon. Good heavens, what is wrong with Opposition senators? I am talking about the change of hours that Senator Keeffe was talking about when he said said that the Senate had tried to change the time the Senate adjourned so that we got up at 6.30 p.m. on a week day.
—We tried it on Thursdays. We tried it out for one day a week. As soon as you people came in you went straight back to the horse and buggy days.

—We were told that 6.30 p.m. had been tried many times and that Senator Murphy had brought in that practice. We were told that sort of petered out over a period. I believe that occurred a lot earlier. I do not know what year it was. I would like to know what it was that did not work. Let us not go through all that again. Senator Lewis has put forward a proposition saying that we should sit from 2 p.m. to 6 p.m. and from 8 p.m. until 10 p.m. each day. This would reduce by one the number of hours which we would work.
—Which is Government Business time.
—This would be in Government Business time. Senator Martin would object. I think the Whips would probably object to that also.
—The Government might object.

—The Government might object also. If the practice cut out any time for the Opposition it might object also. If we just altered the motion that is in front of us so that we would sit until 10.30 p.m. on Wednesday and start on a Thursday at 10 a.m. instead of 10.30 a.m. the position would be covered and we would again have our 21 hours.
—That is the status quo.

—It is not the status quo; it is to me quite a considerable difference. It is one that I would support. We would still have-Senator Chipp referred to this-the schoolboy situation. We certainly would not be able to leave the premises. We would have to be here between 1.45 p.m. and 6.30 p.m. We would still not be able to move out of the place for our lunches. We would still not be able to sit, with any assurance, even in the dining room or in a committee room having our lunch in peace. We would have to answer the bells. I think they are the main arguments I wanted to put. I believe that this change will ruin our committee system. Those of us who are on many committees, who value the committee system of the Senate, are concerned that this will, indeed, be very detrimental to our committees.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mulvihill Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —My comments will be brief. I hope to touch on at least one ground that has not been mentioned yet. Before I do so I would like to get away from these false ideas that have been created in some people's minds that we will have incessant filibusters during the adjournment debate. I have used, and always will use, the adjournment debate as-Reg Wright, who was not known as a leftist senator, used these words-a forum for injustice. Speeches in the adjournment debate should be short 10 or, at the most, 15 minute rapid fire commentaries. Most honourable senators are involved in such speeches.

SPEECH.PARA: On rare occasions, probably when the timetable has gone haywire, there has been a conflict of views and perhaps four or five senators have spoken. Senator Keeffe would know that sometimes in debates on some trade union matters we would have four Democratic Labor Party senators speaking. We would have to mark them, independent of what Government senators might have said. Those were exceptional times when the adjournment debate went much longer than was intended. My main reason for intervening in this debate is to ask: What will happen when we finish on a Thursday? Most of us, as senators, find that we are occupied in our States or interstate at seminars and ethnic community conferences and the like where we learn a considerable amount. The thing that attracts me to the proposal is that if an honourable senator clocks off at half past seven or 8 o'clock at night and flies out on Friday at 7 a.m. or even at 9 a.m. he or she has had an extra couple of hours to charge his or her batteries. Certainly, honourable senators will not be put in the pastures during the next 48 hours. On the contrary, honourable senators will fire better on a Friday night, a Saturday and a Sunday. I know that my colleague, Arthur Gietzelt, who is smiling, agrees with me. With our responsibilities in the Australian Labour Party we could have to go to a State executive or a national executive meeting, a State or a national conference. Our fluency can suffer if we have a very late night in the Senate on a Thursday.

Senator Gietzelt also referred to fraternising with people. I have related to the Senate oppressions in the Latin American community following the spending of all day at a Uruguayan congress. One can learn more from those congresses about the lower wage people in Australia than from a printed document. I know that Senator Chipp advanced the idea that this proposal would not be 100 per cent successful. If honourable senators get a couple of extra hours in bed on Thursday night they will find that when they go out to cover their responsibilities away from the Parliament they will be more effective instruments in the next two or three days. I make only one postscript; it is particularly for Senator Peter Baume's ears: Even when one does go out in such circumstances plenty of salt on one's steak does not effect one's efficiency.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I enter this debate only to make a plea on behalf of the work force in Parliament house. Apart from Senator Archer, every other speaker in this debate has been speaking only about the problems which beset members of parliament. Nobody has mentioned the Senate staff, the attendants and the officials. Nobody has mentioned the Hansard staff. Nobody has mentioned the transport officers or the dining room and kitchen staff. I have not heard the people who have spoken and who have put these proposals say that they have had any consultation at all with those categories of people which I just mentioned. I would be pleased to hear Senator Martin tell the Senate whether, in fact, she has consulted with the Senate staff on how this change of hours will effect them, how it will affect the Hansard staff and how it will affect the transport officers. Will they be allowed to knock off, say, an hour after the Senate rises, if it does, at 6.30 p.m.? May we have an assurance--

—I raise a point of order. To make sure that the debate is conducted in an orderly form, I just thought that Senator Grimes should take some of the blame. He should be asked whether he has consulted the staff. He moved the motion.

—Senator Grimes was not interjecting; Senator Martin was. I am answering her interjection. I fully believe that Senator Grimes, with the right of reply, will be able to say to me that he has, in fact, consulted all of these people. I hope that he has because we should not be one-sided in this debate. I have always endeavoured during my lifetime to stand up for the rights of workers . Whilst I would be quite happy to agree with the proposal put forward concerning Tuesdays and Wednesdays, I have some misgivings about supporting the proposal for Thursday. If we agree to it, particularly members of the Australian Labor Party, we will say that people do not need a lunch break. That is what it means. We will sit here from 10 a.m. to 7 p.m. with no lunch break. I want to know whether there will be a roster system involved for all of the staff who service this place and what will be the situation in the dining room. Senator Walters did mention these matters. In particular, I want to know what will happen to the dining room staff.

SPEECH.PARA: It is almost certain that the hours in the other place will not coincide with the hours in this place. We will be faced with having to employ extra dining room staff. I would have no complaint about that, considering the high degree of unemployment, but what I am concerned about is whether we will ask the people in the dining room and the kitchen to work longer hours. Goodness me, they work long enough hours now. The same situation applies with regard to the transport officers. Will we still expect those transport officers to be here until midnight or one o'clock in the morning because those laggards who hang about the place want cars? I might say that they are not working; they are doing other things. Some consideration should be given to that. I noted that Senator Chipp mentioned the calling of quorums and divisions. He said that some unthinking people took a great delight in calling quorums and divisions and that people might get caught with their trousers down. Senator Chipp was not a member of this place when one of our senators-

TALK.START.PARA: —I said 'pants'.

—Well, pants. It is the same thing. One of our senators was placed in that position. It is unfortunate that he is not here today because he could have spoken for himself. The person concerned was Senator Georges. Some years ago we did not have the red and green flashing lights in the toilets. If one happened to get caught in there, as Senator Georges did, one had to run out and have a look at the lights which were over the main door. Because Senator Georges got caught with his pants down we now have the little red and green lights in each cubicle. So one does not get caught in there. That is on the record. It is in Hansard. The honourable senator made a great plea to have that done.
—Do you mean to say we are in the red light district?

—Yes, red and green. The other matter to which I refer-this has been raised by several other speakers-is the fact that the adjournment debate is to commence at 6.30 p.m. on Tuesdays and 7 p.m. on Thursdays. There is another proposition floating around this place to alter the Standing Orders so that senators would be limited to 15 minutes, I think, in which to speak at the first reading stages of Bills and, say, 10 minutes on the adjournment. This will attract more people to speak on the adjournment. If one cannot get a question answered at Question Time-it might relate to an important matter but one cannot get the call because of the long-winded answers of the Liberal Government Ministers-one has to raise the matter on the adjournment. My colleague Senator Mulvihill has had to use this device and I have used it too. What a great opportunity there will be on Tuesdays and Thursdays. The Press will still be here. The newspapers will not have gone to bed. You are asking for people to speak on the adjournment. As I said by way of interjection, I will be quite happy to do just that.
—But you won't go too long, will you?

—No. As Senator Mulvihill has said, we will make hard-hitting speeches and no doubt, if they are of some import, they will be reported. Under the present situation, if a senator speaks on the adjournment at 10.30 p.m. on Tuesdays and Thursdays or 11 p.m. on Wednesdays the matter is not reported. Unless a matter is very important people do not bother to stand up and raise a matter on the adjournment.
—But you only get up when it is an important thing.

—I do, but I might have more important matters to raise if I am able to get up here at an earlier hour in the night. So will many other people. Of course, we will reserve that right. Is it proposed that the Standing Orders be added to so that the rights of members are restricted? Are we to have only 10 minutes or 15 minutes in which to speak at the first reading stage of a Bill? Goodness knows, we are restricted enough now because we are allowed to speak to first readings of Bills only on Thursdays. It may be that a matter which a senator wants to raise has become stale news. We are now deprived of speaking immediately to the first reading of a Bill when it comes in.

SPEECH.PARA: If there are the numbers in this place to carry this motion, what are these hours going to mean? If you have the numbers you can do anything. If the Liberal Party is in government and it has a jam of business, the Leader of the Government-if it is still Senator Carrick-will stand up and move a motion that Government Business take precedence over General Business and away we go. We can go until 3 o'clock in the morning. I have just had a look at a notice of motion which I placed on the Notice Paper on 10 June last year complaining about Senator Carrick keeping us here until 3 o'clock in the morning debating Government Business. Nobody wants to be fooled that that will not take place. No matter who is in government-whether it be my party or the people who are now in government-if the Government has business to deal with, and if it has the numbers, what will it do? It will carry the day. It will not matter that some people might say things such as: 'Well, we agreed in the Senate that we--

TALK.START.PARA: —You will finish at midnight instead of 6 o'clock in the morning.

—We might, but we will still have late hours. Instead of people having to finish here at 6 p.m. or 7 p.m., or whatever it is, perhaps the best solution would be to sit an extra day each week, or an extra week, so that we can deal with the business. I have in mind the people who have to travel from Western Australia every week to this place in order to sit here for three days. If we could program the sitting of this Parliament so that we have a four or even a five-day week, such as the normal work force has to work-eight hours a day-it would be much more sensible. I work seven days a week in my job. That is why I have no time like the people to whom Senator Walters was referring. Senator Martyr replied that he liked to play tennis. I never get the time to go out on a tennis court, but that is my business. I am not worried. It is my decision. I try to do the work which is involved in being a member of parliament .
—Will you be going dancing?

—No, I am too old for dancing. I know that members of the Government who attend the embassies and so on like to dance to the tune of all the foreign music. In conclusion I make the point that not enough discussion has gone into this proposal which is before us at present. It was amended on the floor of the House. My colleague Senator Grimes, who moved it, had to stand up and seek permission to make an amendment to it while it was under debate and then Senator Lewis came in with another amendment to be considered. That proves to me that there has not been enough discussion. There might have been discussion among a few members of parliament by way of sending out a questionnaire, but I am yet to be convinced that any discussion took place with all of the other important people in this Parliament. Sometimes politicians run away with the impression that they are the most important people in the country. If one went out and talked to the general public one would find that, next to football umpires, politicians would be the least important and the least popular people. We do not want to get the idea into our heads that we are the be all and end all of everything. The place could not function without the ordinary work force which does all the chores about the place.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said earlier, I am not prepared, as a good trade unionist, to give away that lunch hour on any day of the week. Whatever we decide in here, unless the Standing Orders are amended there is no way that people will be prevented from calling quorums or divisions. I well remember what happened in 1972 and 1975. Members of the National Country Party and the Liberal Party really brought the calling of quorums to a peak when we were in government. We could not interview people who came here. I think that two of our Ministers had heart attacks from rushing to and fro because of quorums and so on. Members of the National Country Party and the Liberal Party set the stage and we would like to follow it. I endeavour to follow it sometimes but I have had the finger put on me by some of my colleagues. But, of course, that may change.

TALK.START.PARA: —Name them.

—I have done that in the party room but I will not do it in here . When one is coming to the end of one's tether in this place one gets off the leash. One can do certain things which one might not do if seeking endorsement again. My time to speak is coming to an end. I have always endeavoured to abide by the Standing Orders. Until the Standing Orders are altered whereby quorums or divisions cannot be called, we will do it. I hope that this matter can be adjourned and further consideration given to having discussions with the people who really do the hard yakka about this Parliament.

—I should make one matter clear to Senator McLaren and to the Senate. The honourable senator stated that Senator Lewis moved an amendment. I make it clear to the chamber that so far as the Chair is concerned no such amendment was indicated to me by Senator Lewis.
—I apologise for that, Mr President. I should have said ' circulated'.
—Order! I am still speaking. Senator Lewis sought and was given leave to incorporate in Hansard another set of figures with respect to sittings. That is all that he did.
—I stand corrected.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I claim to have been misrepresented. Senator McLaren laid heavy emphasis on the subject of staff. Whilst Senator Walters asked a series of questions which could have been answered-it is a pity they were not asked earlier-Senator McLaren made a series of allegations in relation to the consideration of staffing. The facts are not as stated by Senator McLaren. A great deal of work has gone into the subject of staffing. Those of use who have been working on it have been aware of and have paid scrupulous attention to the effect that any proposal would have on Hansard staff , the dining room, the Department of the Senate and other staff here. I cannot answer all the questions that Senator McLaren asked, but that does not justify his making the allegations that we do not care about that matter or have not thought about it. The simple fact is that arrangements will have to be made with people such as the transport officers, if this motion is passed, to define some reasonable sort of modus operandi for them. I do not believe Senator McLaren's allegations are in any way well justified. If people go into this reasonably, it will be solved.

SPEECH.PARA: I have been informed-because it has been researched-that there will be a small difference to the Hansard staff by virtue of the fact that we will be sitting through a lunch hour, but that is a very small difference. I am given to understand that in fact they welcome these new sittings hours in terms of making their life a bit more bearable. There will be a small difference in the dining room. Had Senator McLaren stopped and thought before he spoke he would have been aware that at present the House of Representatives sits at 1.45 on Tuesdays and Wednesdays as proposed in the sitting hours that we have been debating. Had he taken the trouble to find out for himself rather than making allegations, he would have been aware that, as a consequence of that change of hours in the House of Represenatives, services in the dining room are now available at lunch time from 12.30 in any event. The time has been extended there. I suggest to you , Mr President, because you will be the person who will bear at least half the responsibility for this, that the evening meal situation would in my opinion require an adjustment of about 15 minutes. But the dining room staff has been consulted on a number of occasions, as have other staffs.

Most importantly, as you would be aware, Mr President, throughout there has been close consultation with you and you have sought and given information and advice on the effect of any change of sitting hours on the staff for which you, not I, are responsible. Those details have been attended to. In all the time that this discussion has been going on-three years-only one employee in this building has raised with me any objection to the earlier hours, and that involved losing some overtime. I do not think we are required to sit here so that people can earn high levels of overtime. All other members of staff, most of whom have initiated conversations with me, have indicated how very strongly they want a change. Finally, on the matter of costing, I understand that there is a potential in the Department of the Senate for saving considerable money.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I find it remarkable that today Senator McLaren is being intimidated by the Australian Labor Party. If he has been intimidated before today, his intimidation will be a great deal worse if these sitting hours come into effect. Senator McLaren can look forward to his colleagues getting at him about the adjournment and about the calling of quorums . I wish to address myself particularly to the proposed lunch time sitting hours , particularly on a Thursday but also with respect to the other two days. I concede that there is in my argument a fair amount of personal interest in terms of my life as a senator for the Australian Capital Territory. I think it will apply to a number of other senators as well in that there are held between 12.30 and 2 o'clock a number of functions and conferences which, if we can attend at those times, we can get something out of. The sitting hours that are proposed in this motion virtually eliminate the possibility of taking part in the life of the national capital at lunch time. That is a pity in the sense that that is the time when one may well meet public servants and other people at functions.

SPEECH.PARA: Under this proposal, as I understand it, we will be expecting public servants to float around here at 9 o'clock at night to talk to us-I think that is asking a lot more of them-not to mention the hours that we would be asking Senate staff to work to man committees. I express my very strong regret that the matter is being treated in such a way as virtually to eliminate the possibility of taking part in anything that goes on in the Territory at lunch time on sitting days. As to Thursdays, I think it is absolutely disgraceful for the Senate to embark upon the course of sitting through lunch time. I have no doubt that someone will say that the Parliament of Westminster does so. I am not the least bit interested in that. I am concerned about this Parliament and about the national capital of this country. I think that to tell the world that the Parliament sits through lunch time and that it does not really matter whether members are present there is a disgrace.

TALK.START.PARA: —Only on one day.

—That is one too many. I am very disappointed that responsible senators suggest that. As to tension, can honourable senators imagine sitting in the dining room and eating a steak when they know full well that Senator McLaren has had his and is on his way back to the chamber? Can honourable senators imagine a more tense situation than that, with the quorum bells about to ring? There is no reason on earth why Senator McLaren should not call a quorum. Once we give up our right to these things we begin to make a mockery of what the whole Parliament is about.
—Who says that Senator McLaren is intimidated?

—Senator McLaren told us a few minutes ago that he is intimidated by people such as Senator Grimes. I can well imagine that to be the case. Another aspect of the proposal is that we finish at some undisclosed time on a Wednesday evening after 11 o'clock and it will be probably nearer midnight by the time one gets home, if one goes straight home. We will be expected back here , to get our day sorted out and to be working again in this chamber, by 10 o' clock on a Thursday, which is considerably less than 11 hours later.
—What time did we start today?
—What time did you get home last night?

—I was in bed by 10 to 12. I do not agree that the present sitting hours are ideal. I come to what I think needs to be done. I am pleased to note that Senator Gietzelt is anxious to get to know Canberra better. I really have the solution for him. The Parliament and the Senate should sit on four days a week with the hours spread more reasonably or we should sit for more weeks. From the way honourable senators have been talking, one would think that they were talking about 52 weeks a year. That is not the case. We are talking of a very few weeks in a year. The solution to the problem is to sit for more weeks and to spread the hours more reasonably.

SPEECH.PARA: I will deal with a number of other matters. I am totally at a loss to understand the reasoning behind Senator Chipp's argument concerning lunch time. Of course, I realise that he has been around this place for a great deal longer than I have and that he perhaps understands some of it better. But I do not see any possibility of improving social life significantly. Senator Mulvihill might get to bed a bit earlier on a Thursday, but he is about the only one in this chamber I can see who would be getting to bed earlier because the others are talking about films, television, Senate committees and a whole range of other activities. I do not think this has anything to do with the time one gets to bed . Certainly the present hours should end. The Parliament should rise at 10 o' clock and should not go on beyond that, in my opinion, on the nights that it sits. But I think that the proposed sitting hours will do nothing to enhance the Parliament in the eyes of the community.

I express the strongest personal regret at the possibility of having eliminated all opportunity to take part in lunch time activities, not to mention functions after work at 5.30 or 6 which, if we rose at 6 o'clock, we could attend so that we could talk to a number of people between 6 and 8. Senator Chipp obviously is invited to all the embassies but has obviously had some fairly bad experiences. He has indigestible food thrust into his left hand. I have never had indigestible food at an embassy; I have always enjoyed it. I concede that there are some fairly crowded cocktail functions between 6 and 8 at an embassy, but there are a number of other places, such as the Housing Industry Association and the Real Estate Institute, where one can meet and talk to groups of people between 6 and 8. If honourable senators suggest that they will have to perform after 9 o'clock-this would occur if Senator McLaren and Senator Mulvihill speak in the adjournment debate-I do not think we will be improving anything at all. I think we are significantly weaking the standard of the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Robertson Sen E.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be brief in what is a most entertaining debate. I want to make a few comments. I support the commendable motion which has been moved by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Senator Grimes) which gives us some attempt to better utilise the time which we spend in Canberra. It is quite clear that this proposition is not all that could be done. We recall the four-day sitting week that we tried; we recall what former Senator Murphy did when he was here; and we recall that attempts have been made to make better use of our time. I am not foreshadowing any of those. Let us look at this proposition. I will not repeat all the arguments in favour of it. I say simply that I agree with most of the things that have been said. I want to comment on a couple of the arguments that have been made by speakers. When Senator Grimes replies he will provide answers to questions raised by various speakers.

SPEECH.PARA: I am very pleased to see that Senator McLaren supports two-thirds of our proposition. This is excellent. I thought that he was totally opposed to the whole thing. So the debate has brought us a little further around than we were before. Senator Lewis suggested, virtually, an inflexibility. He seemed to suggest that, because committees now meet at a certain time, they must meet at that time in future. This is not so. We are not tied to the present arrangements . We are not tied to having a meeting of a committee at 9 o'clock in the morning . It is possible to meet at half past eight or it is possible to meet at night. We do not have to fit in with the present committee arrangements. But I think the most telling point was when Senator Lewis suggested that we will sit locked in the chamber on Thursdays from 10 o'clock in the morning until some time at night. That is a load of rubbish. Most senators sit in this place for about an hour and a half a day beyond Question Time. Honourable senators do not come in and sit throughout the whole day. It is quite easy to organise one's time so that one can make one's contribution. Most of us get to work at 8.30 a.m. and we are here until 11.30 or 12 o'clock at night. This is the very thing that we are complaining about. Because we have to sit late at night there is no way to modify our program. There is no flexibility because of the present hours.

There has been a suggestion that the adjournment debate will be a danger. Senator Mulvihill mentioned this, I think. I believe that the novelty will wear off. Without any doubt there will be a rush of prima donnas who will want to grab the air at 6.30 and speak while they think the Australian Broadcasting Commission is broadcasting. There is no doubt about this; we know it. But let us face it, this novelty will wear off. Senator McLaren rightly made the point that if something needs to be said or if there ought to be a matter raised in the adjournment debate it ought to be done whether it is 6.30, 11 o'clock or 12 o' clock. Certainly, that debate will get a lot more coverage and attention if it is broadcast at 6.30 or 7 o'clock at night. Let us face it; we are here to represent people. We are trying to find the most effective way to do it so that we stay healthy and also make a greater contribution. The last point I make to Senator Lewis is that if there are problems, and he has some, let us try the system. We can always change it later; we are not bound to it. If it does not work we have the opportunity to look at it again.

Senator Walters' main complaint seemed to be that she was not allowed out of the building and likened the chamber to some sort of school. I suggest to Senator Walters that, if she does need to leave the building-I cannot see why she should need to-then the normal arrangement of getting a pair exists. If she cannot play tennis at 11 o'clock or 12 o'clock then she can do what my colleague , Senator Sibraa, does and play tennis at 7 o'clock in the morning. That is the sort of flexibility she has. She is worried about lunch on the one day a week where there is an imposition on our lunch time. She seems to think that every Thursday she is going to be torn screaming from the dining room because something is going to happen. She is worried about not being able to attend functions on Thursdays. I make those points because I think she has raised what seem to be bogies. We will answer them as we go on.

Senator McLaren and others raised a matter relating to costing. I have been provided with information which has been partly given already by Senator Martin. There will be no changes to the cost of running Hansard; the Senate staff will actually experience savings; and there will virtually be no change in the dining room. Costing will be about the same. I make the point that those of us who were involved in coming forward with some recommendations certainly did not, blindly, one night, make up a list of figures and throw them to honourable senators. Consideration has been given to all aspects. I think it is grossly unfair to suggest that the people who have considered this proposition over a period of 12 or 18 months have disregarded every other aspect.

Some personnel who work here, apart from ourselves, will also be able to get home at night. Surely that is the sort of thing that they want. I make the point quite clearly so that there is no contradiction that, if it is said that the attendants will lose money because there is no overtime and that attendants need the extra money, that is contrary to union principle. The attendants ought to be paid enough for the normal time that they serve in this place without having to look for additional payment. If, as has been said, they need additional money then, with respect, Mr President, that is a matter which you and your officers will no doubt look into.

Senator Archer said that the joint meetings will be a problem. Perhaps they will be. I believe that we can organise that. It is not beyond the wit of the groups to get together and organise joint meetings. Senator Archer also made the criticism that we have not thought about various aspects of the proposition. I assure him, as Senator Martin and others have done, that the dining room staff, the attendants, the drivers, the ABC employees, Hansard and others involved were considered. Perhaps I will be regarded as one of those people whom Senator McLaren mentioned who think politicians are important. I do not think that at all. But I do think that this House operates for the senators who sit in it and for work which they have to do. I believe that the services that come to us from the Library, the dining room and other areas are provided to the people who are here to do a certain job. I think we ought to keep that in mind. Surely it would be ludicrous to say that we had better meet between the hours of X and Y because that is when the gardeners want us to meet or that is when it is convenient for the dining room staff. I am not making the point that we should disregard those people; we have not done so. But I make the point that the chamber is for the senators, and we ought to organise the service arrangements for the senators to suit them.

Public servants, of course, are already here at odd hours. I thought it was strange that they should be mentioned. They come here at all hours of the day or night; there will be no change to that. I have seen them here at 12 o'clock at night waiting in the corridors for us to adjourn so that Estimates committee meetings can be held. Senator Archer finished on a good point when he said: 'Let us have temporary changes'. That is all we are asking for. I could not agree more. Let us try these hours. If they work we will keep them; if they do not we will throw them away. I will comment briefly on a couple of matters raised by Senator Reid. Firstly, she said that the Goverment was intimidated by the Australian Labor Party. I think that is fantastic. It is a lovely thought. What a pity it is not so. The harsh reality of the situation is--

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Whip.

—Yes, that is the way it ought to be, too. As Senator Chaney has found out, to his horror on many occasions, numbers count. Neither party intimidates the other. Senator Reid seemed to be a bit paranoid because she thought that poor Senator McLaren was intimidated by someone on this side of the chamber. I assure her that Senator McLaren, from his shearing days, has never been intimidated by anyone and to the end of his days will not be.
—You put the screws on him in a big way.

—Terrible. She is worried also that during lunch hour on a Thursday she will not be able to get out to some lunch functions and she will not be able to take part in activities. My heart bleeds for her. If she lived seven hours away by air as I do and could get home if she were lucky for weekends she would have nothing to complain about. We meet for 60-odd days a year. If she cannot adjust all of the things that she wants to do in her electorate-I commend her for doing them-I think she will experience difficulty. We are here for the work of the Senate and not to attend social functions or any other functions outside of this place. Senator Reid raised the matter of a four- day sitting week. I could not agree with her more. I think that is an excellent idea. She said: 'Let us sit for more weeks'. I could not agree more. I think that is a wonderful idea. But she can see the trouble we are having now trying to change a few hours. What chance would we get of sitting extra days or extra weeks?

SPEECH.PARA: There is some significance in the fact that this motion was moved by one of the doctors in this chamber and strongly supported by the other doctor in this chamber. That must have some bearing on the debate. We must not look for problems in this situation. Do not let us loose the substance of good change in the shadows of what could be imagined problems.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: -I find the hours and the days we sit in this place absolutely absurd. I am astonished at the ossification in attitudes manifested by honourable senators which quite transcends party lines. Somehow or other we seem to enshrine ritual without any respect for what we are trying to do. I could not imagine a worse system than that under which we operate at present. I regard the proposals before us today as the first step on a rather long path back to sanity and some efficient processes of doing our business. What we have done here has just mindlessly perpetuated a mediaeval system of operation. I say that with care. We have a mediaeval system which, in relation to the Budget session and the autumn session, relates to getting in the harvest and the climatic conditions of Europe 500 or 600 years ago. The times of day we sit are related to those gentlemen in the city of London who, after they had a good dinner, would toddle off and, in a part time way, deal with the affairs of what was at the time a small nation. The business of a great and developing nation cannot be run on the principles and practices of 500 years ago.

SPEECH.PARA: A most important point in this respect is that good management practices do not necessarily guarantee good results. But as sure as God made little apples, bad management practices make the attainment of good results very difficult, if not impossible, to obtain. These bad management practices that we follow have a major effect on our efficiency. Who can deal with great matters of State at 2 o' clock, 3 o'clock or even 4 o'clock in the morning as most of us in the chamber have tried to do over the years? It is absolutely silly to continue a practice like that.

I will not labour the health effects. I do not think being in politics is a stress free existence, whether one is in opposition or in government, or whether one is in the Ministry or on the back bench. To add unnecessary traumas and stresses to the pattern of life that we have again is inexcusable. I do not see why we cannot work in daylight hours in the way that every other human being wants to and does.

TALK.START.PARA: —Take the covers off the windows, Senator.

—The honourable senator can make his speech later. The chamber is his when I have finished. I do not see why we cannot work the daylight hours that other human beings work. I do not see why we cannot work a four or five day week. The organisation of this Parliament turns on the convenience of those honourable senators and members-they are in the majority-who come from Sydney and Melbourne and, to a lesser degree, those who come from Canberra. Those of us who come from Queensland, Western Australia, South Australia and Tasmania find that we have to spend most of Monday and Friday travelling from and to our electorates. In a three day sitting week, we effectively end up losing five days in the process. That situation does not apply at all to the people who go to Sydney. Canberra is only 20 minutes flying time away from the Sydney airport. They can do a full day's work on a Friday or a Monday. The current sitting hours present no inconvenience to them at all. They get two full days in their electorate doing the essential business of a member, which is denied us.

SPEECH.PARA: I have every sympathy for Senator Robertson, who spoke previously, about the difficulties he faces in going to Darwin. He has a great difficulty compared with someone who lives in Sydney or Melbourne. Furthermore, those of us who represent the big States have to travel. We cannot do our business from Pitt Street or from the centre of the city; we have to travel very great distances and that inevitably involves time. I support this motion. I think it is the first step we have made towards looking at an intelligent assessment of the way in which we are working. I hope we go much further down this track in the near future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to add, very briefly, to the debate. It has shown that there are probably as many opinions about sitting hours as there are members of this chamber. I do not wish to oppose the proposal for the changed sitting hours. Being what might be regarded as on the radical wing of the apathetic mass, I am prepared at least to give it a try, although I think it is something that I would not have bothered to spend any time on.

SPEECH.PARA: I am amazed that I find myself actually contributing to the debate. My concern is that, if the proposal is taken up on a trial basis, part of the trial will be as to how effective the committee system can be. I regard the committee system as an important part of the party processes, an important aspect of the democracy within the parties and an important aspect of the parliamentary operation. It is my fear that the new sitting times will adversely affect the times available and the availability of honourable senators for both the party committee meetings and the parliamentary committee meetings. I hope that I will be shown to be wrong. Time will tell. I hope that it will be very carefully borne in mind that, if the price that we are to pay for the changed sitting hours is the destruction of the committee system, it will have been a pyrrhic victory.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree that the current sitting hours represent the worst possible combination of hours other than the ones that have been proposed. I feel that the proposed hours do not really have regard to two matters: Firstly, the expressive function of parliamentarians-that is to say, their parliamentary responsibilities which have just been adverted to by Senator Peter Rae-and, secondly, the constituent responsibilities of individual senators even when they are in Canberra. Enough evidence has been adduced to support the proposition that , in fact, the proposed hours will interfere with the expressive functions of members of parliament as envisaged not only within this chamber but also within the committee systems of the Parliament and the committee systems of the various parties.

SPEECH.PARA: First of all, we have a built-in situation in which on Thursdays members of parliament must absent themselves from the chamber. Of course, we all need to do that at present. This is not allowed for in the current hours. On a Thursday it is proposed that we sit from 10 a.m. until 7 p.m. Built into the proposed hours is the suggestion that members of parliament must absent themselves for eating purposes. That might be okay for members of political parties who have their Whips to say what is coming up and what arguments are likely to be put for and against and who have determined policies on those issues. This is not a satisfactory situation for an individual senator. Important matters may come up before this Parliament on a Thursday during the lunch break when the dining room is open, from 12.30 p.m. to 2 p.m. If I did not have an individual policy on them, I would have to sit here for all of that time and listen to the debate. That is part of my expressive function. People might say: 'That is bad luck. You are not in a political party'. I feel that I have as much right as anybody else to express my opinion as to what form the hours should take.

Let me hasten to say to the proponents of this proposition that I do not intend and would not use the forms of the House to disrupt these proposals; in other words, to call quorums while honourable senators were out having lunch and I was sitting here. I certainly will not be doing that. It is not my intention to speak in the adjournment debates, although it will be a very attractive proposition when they commence at 6.30 p.m. on Tuesdays and 7 p.m. on Thursdays for an individual member of parliament who might want to get something off his chest and into the Press.

The second point concerning the expressive function of members of parliament was dealt with by a number of honourable senators including the last speaker, Senator Rae. Built into the proposal is a feature that means there can be no joint meetings of parliamentary committees because on the two nights we will be twiddling our thumbs in Canberra, from 6.30 p.m. to 10.30 p.m. on Tuesdays and 7 .30 p.m. to 10.30 p.m. on Thursdays, members of the House of Representatives will not be available to join in those committee meetings.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have overlooked the fact that they are allowed to attend committee meetings while the House is sitting.

—I was just about to say that. On the two nights honourable senators are free, members of the House of Representatives are not free. If, for example, honourable senators need to speak to public servants it would be a matter of bringing the public servants here in their free time when I think they should be getting their well-deserved rest. If there was a matter that an honourable senator wanted to speak about in respect, for example, his electorate and he wanted to get one or two of the House of Representatives members involved in that discussion, it could well be difficult to achieve that. As the situation is at the moment we can do that during the lunch break. I believe that the proposal will inhibit the expressive functions of members of Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: The second point relates to the constituent responsibilities of members of parliament. As all honourable senators know, at present we do not shed our constituent responsibilities just because we come to Canberra. We all spend a great deal of time on the telephone speaking from Canberra. However, the proposal will mean the use of certain free time presently available during the day. It will be put into the evenings, which will then limit the opportunity that members of parliament have to contact departments and constituents back in the home State. I believe the proposal interferes with other responsibilities of honourable senators. It would be fair enough if, for example, the sitting time on Thursday were brought back so that we could catch a plane home and have the whole of Friday in our constituencies. That might make some sense. To have the adjournment at seven o'clock on Thursday means that there is absolutely no hope of any of us-as I think Senator MacGibbon said-from outlying States getting home that night, no hope whatsoever.

I believe it would be worth a try to give the hours that are currently observed by the House of Representatives a go. Let us not forget that this proposal emerged from the general dissatisfaction expressed by honourable senators as to the lateness of the hours we have kept time and again. Am I correct in saying that? I think I am. Under those circumstances let us for a start bring back by at least half an hour, or an hour, the times we sit at night. We could make up for that at another time. For example, we could start at 1.45 on Tuesday instead of 2.30 and 1.45 on Wednesday instead of 2.15. We would already have made up the time, particularly if we started at 10 o'clock on Thursday morning. I have not calculated the exact saving but I think it makes up for the time lost. We could then knock off at 10 o'clock and overcome the principal objection that we all have to the current sitting hours, that is, that they keep us here too late at night. I assure those proponents of the motion that if it is carried I will attempt to co-operate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Put an amendment. We haven't got one.

—Before I sit down I suggest to you, Mr President, and to honourable senators that perhaps we could defer this debate until the first sitting week after Easter. We could then determine the matter. A number of things have come out of the debate which I think deserve some consideration and maybe some joint consideration by various honourable senators who have expressed different points of view during this debate.
