—Senator Harradine, I understood your words to be that you suggest a certain course be followed. Do you intend to move a positive motion in that direction or do you merely suggest that the Senate give consideration to it?
—I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave not granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McClelland Sen The Hon D.

TALK.START.PARA: —My remarks on the sitting hours of the Senate will be very brief indeed. I have had misgivings about whether this proposal will work. Having listened to the debate I still have those misgivings but I am certain that we have to give it a trial period. Therefore, it is my intention to vote for the motion proposed. In the time I have been in this chamber we have had a number of trials. When I first came here about 20 years ago the hours we were working were the same as the hours we are working now but the pressure of business was nowhere near as heavy then as it is now. For instance, I well recall that when I first came here every honourable senator who received an answer to a question on notice had the right to ask that question on notice in the chamber and have the answer prepared by public servants and given to the Minister read by the Minister. That invariably took up one or two hours each day. As time went on pressure caught up and that system had to be changed.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Reid suggested that we have a four-day sitting week. I well recall that at one stage-I think in the early days of the Labor government-we had a four day sitting week with two weeks on and two weeks off. We sat on Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday and Friday and came back on Sunday night and sat Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday. Of course, that suited some honourable senators and did not suit others. It tended to suit those who lived far away because they had two weeks off but it did not suit those who came from Sydney or Melbourne. So that system was changed. I remember that we then had a period when we sat through our meal breaks. A sort of agreement was made-an unofficial agreement-that no quorums would be called during the meal break. That system broke down-I think rightly so-because some honourable senators felt their rights were being taken away.

I think that in this trial sitting period-despite the fact that we should not set out deliberately to frustrate the workings of the Parliament-any honourable senator who feels aggrieved should have the right at any time to use the forms and forums of the chamber to express his grievance. I do not think there should be any criticism of any honourable senator who, for whatever purpose, may decide to call for a quorum, a division or whatever. I emphasise that so far as I am concerned if this means sitting through meal breaks there should be no deprivation of any honourable senators' rights in the use of the forms of the Senate. During the final period of the Labor Government we sat on Tuesdays, Wednesdays and Thursdays but the House rose at 5 p.m. on a Thursday. We introduced General Business at 3 p.m. on Thursdays and it concluded at 5 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is going to happen with General Business now?

—That is the very point I am going to make. Is the Government making provision as to when General Business comes on? Under this proposal will General Business come on at 4.30 p.m. Thursday and be debated until 7 p.m. or will it come on at some other time? I think that is a matter that must be sorted out. It will have to be determined one way or the other by the Government. Eventually the Government will have to bring in a recommendation to the Senate on that matter.

SPEECH.PARA: There seems to be an impression abroad that because the hours laid down now are the hours that we have been using for two or three years they must per se be the hours that we should continue to use. I completely disagree with that principle. I remember when we were in government and the Senate rose at 5 p.m. I was manager of Government Business and I ran the wrath of the then Prime Minister because the Senate was not sitting when the House of Representatives sat. Eventually, at the end of our Government, because through political circumstances we could not get Supply through, we had to extend our sitting hours. I understand that when this Government came into office it was determined that the Senate should sit roughly the same hours as the House of Representatives. I do not agree with that. I think we should be masters of our own destiny, of our own times, and make a determination along those lines. If we can get our work through in 17 hours, rather than 20 hours, we should make that determination.

I have great misgivings. I certainly agree with my colleague, Senator McLaren, about the problems that could arise on Thursdays between 10 a.m. and 7 p.m. If General Business is to be discussed on Thursdays, I think some consideration should be given as to when it is brought on. However I believe it is worthwhile having a trial period. Because our present hours are exhausting I believe this motion should be supported.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was fairly easy and relaxed about the proposed new sitting hours. I had indicated to Senator Martin that I did not really care about the matter but Senator MacGibbon invited me to speak and I will accept his invitation. A couple of things have emerged from the debate. I have been here all the time and have listened to it with interest. A couple of points have given me a misgiving in, I think, much the same way as Senator McClelland. An important point is that if the adjournment debate goes on-and there may be good reasons for it going on-and if the situation in the dining room is as it is now we would all have to be prescient and order our meals before 7.30 p.m.
—We can change that.

—No proposition has been put about that. That is something we can do. From a perfectly selfish point of view, there does not appear to be any real advantage to anybody from Western Australia in the proposed new sitting hours and that must cut some ice with me. Also I am impressed by Senator Reid's argument. I am glad that she contributed to this debate to- day because she has made up my mind. I think that we ought to stick with the sitting hours as they are. That is the easiest way out.
—I remind honourable senators that when Senator Grimes speaks he will be closing the debate. I call Senator Grimes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-Thank you, Mr President, I will be brief. In bringing this matter forward I have achieved one thing. I have not seen so many honourable senators in this place for so long for a debate on any topic for a very long time. I am glad that honourable senators are interested in it. When I moved this motion I said that I was proposing to rearrange the sitting hours; that we should sit for the same number of hours as we do now but merely rearrange those hours. I suspected before I spoke that a lot of debate against those hours would relate to the sort of thing that Senator Reid objected to-losing one lunch hour on Thursdays each sitting week. I am not compelled by that argument. Apparently Senator Martyr is. He seems to believe that that is the most compelling argument against this motion.
—He plays tennis on Thursdays.

—Maybe he does play tennis on Thursdays and that is the problem. Today there was a reception at the Greek Embassy and honourable senators from both sides went. They were paired during the sitting hours of this place. The same thing happens on Israeli National Day and the same thing can happen to Senator Reid if she urgently needs to go to some lunch-hour function on a sitting Thursday. I do not see that as an objection at all.

SPEECH.PARA: The second problem-in the order that I am going to mention them-was raised by Senator McLaren who made the extraordinary claim that unnamed honourable senators on this side had been intimidating him, stopping him calling quorums and stopping him speaking on the adjournment. I have never attempted to intimidate Senator McLaren. I would not be game. I have had many requests from Government senators to intimidate Senator McLaren but I have told them that that would be an impossibility and I would not be able to do it. There is nothing in the motion that I have moved that takes away any of Senator McLaren's rights. I have said, and I repeat it, that for this proposal on sitting days to work properly, on those occasions when we sit through meal hours, there may have to be give and take on both sides-one side agreeing that nothing contentious will be brought up in that hour and the other side agreeing that unnecessary quorums, or any quorums at all, will not be called. I would not intend having those matters put into the Standing Orders, nor would I think it necessary. In London the Parliament sits through all its meal hours and it manages to survive. It has done so for a very long time and I do not see why this Parliament cannot survive .

I come to the problem of the adjournment debate. In 1981 the Senate sat for 72 days and on 49 days, someone spoke on the adjournment. Senator McLaren spoke on many of them. The average speaking time on the adjournment was 10.8 minutes. The longest adjournment debate was one hour 29 minutes and on only two days did the adjournment debate go longer than an hour. It may be that because the adjournment will be earlier in the night and honourable senators can not think of anything else to do, honourable senators may speak in the adjournment debate more often than they used to. What we do about that is in the hands of the Senate. I am not suggesting that we take away the rights of honourable senators to speak on the adjournment. However I am suggesting that honourable senators should be reasonable and not speak on the adjournment just because it is earlier any more than they do now. Are honourable senators trying to tell me that a serious person such as Senator McLaren will abuse the adjournment after 7 p.m.? He speaks only on important matters and did so on only 49 days at the most of the 72 sitting days last year.

Of course Senator Harradine is right. We will have to make new arrangements for the hours during which we will discuss General Business. I suggest that a sensible time for General Business may well be from 4 o'clock, 4.30 or whatever on Thursday afternoon until the adjournment time. However that is a matter for the Government and honourable senators on the Standing Orders Committee to consider. Surely it is not beyond the wit of people in this place to make sensible arrangements to divide those hours so that people do not lose anything. If people really suggest that it is beyond our capacity to organise those hours I suggest we should not be here at all and we have no right to represent the people of this country.

I believe Senator Martin effectively answered Senator McLaren's accusations concerning the alleged lack of concern for staff by the people who put up this proposal. In fact the one complaint that I have had about staff working conditions under these new hours is not that they will have to work too long. A couple of them are worried that they will not get as much overtime as they are geting now. I take another trade union principle. If people have to depend on overtime to get a living wage it is up to senators and it is up to unions to get them a proper living wage so that they do not need that overtime. It is quite wrong to suggest that we should sit the hours that we do to provide people with overtime. We should provide people with proper wages and proper conditions.

One thing that this debate has demonstrated to me is that not all the conservative people are on the other side of the House, although it seems that most of them are. People seem to have a great fear of the unknown. Some people are actually frightened that, on Tuesday night and on Thursday night, they will not have anything to do. Senator Harradine said that honourable senators would be twiddling their fingers. I repeat that I am sure that most of us will do then what we do now on Tuesday nights and on Thursday nights. We will work, but we will work more effectively, uninterrupted by bells and the sorts of procedures which some of us have to deal with in this place. I believe that that will make this a more sensible chamber and it will make for more sensible debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —And we can go home if we need to.

—We can go home if we want to; we can go out if we need to; we can do all the sorts of things that we want to do-some of which I cannot mention here-which might do us all some good too. I believe this is a reasonable proposal. We have been talking about it for three years or more. Some of us have been talking about it for almost the whole of the eight years that I have been here. We have had plenty of discussions about it. I see no reason to accede to Senator Harradine's request to defer this matter until after the next break in sittings. That will mean that we will not be able to introduce this proposal this session. If it does not work, so what! If it does not work, we can do what we are proposing to do now-we can change it or modify it. But for heaven's sake let us not hang on to the present archaic and nonsensical hours of sitting just because they have always been there. We have to attempt to make this a more efficient chamber. I believe that this proposal goes a long way towards doing so . If it is not perfect and it does not suit everybody, let them bring up proposals for further change or, even at worst, we can go back to the hours that we are sitting now. I have heard nothing in the arguments that have been used against this proposal today to change my mind at all or to convince me that it is not a reasonable proposal for reform in this place. If the House of Representatives-
—Can I ask you a question?

—Just a moment. If the House of Representatives looks at this proposal and it likes it, it too might change its hours of sitting and we could go back to that glorious situation, which apparently a lot of people want, where we sit at the same times as the House of Representatives. But let us give the proposed hours a trial. Senator Walters should not be frightened of change. I know that she is-
—I would like an answer to a question. If you wanted to make a dinner engagement on any one of those nights for what time would you make it?
—I would make it for 8 o'clock or 8.30, which I happen to think is a fairly reasonable hour at which to eat in this town.
—And you could guarantee that the adjournment debate would be over by then?

—I cannot guarantee that the adjournment debate would be over by then. I am just going on present adjournment debate records. We cannot guarantee anything now. We cannot guarantee that we will be able to go out at a reasonable time now.
—She likes her tea at 6 o'clock.

—If Senator Walters likes her tea at 6 o'clock she can have her tea at 6 o'clock. She can have her tea and bickies or her sandwiches in her room and listen to the little box and rush into the chamber if her presence is needed . But of course we all know that we are not in this chamber hour after hour during any sitting; nor will we be if this proposal is implemented. Let us make this change. Let us give it a trial. Let us demonstrate that we can co-operate in this place. Let us demonstrate our reform to the other House and it may actually follow us. I persist with my motion.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the motion (Senator Grimes's) be agreed to:

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I seek your ruling on whether it is a fact that, this motion having been passed, we are now in a situation in which we conclude business at 7 p.m. and the adjournment debate then takes place. If so, are we now in General Business time? Could you please advise us?
—I am advised by the clerks that we earlier passed a motion relating to business after 8 p.m. As a result of this motion it may be necessary to pass a further motion to permit this to occur.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, unless otherwise ordered, intervening business be postponed until after the consideration of Government Business Order of the Day No. 3, the honey industry Bills.

This motion is to enable those Bills to be referred to a Senate committee. If we do not do so now their reference will be delayed until we return after the three -week break, and the consideration of the Bills would become a matter of some difficulty and urgency.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: HONEY (EXPORT INSPECTION CHARGE) BILL 1982HONEY (EXPORT INSPECTION CHARGE) COLLECTION BILL 1982

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 24 March, on motion by Senator Peter Baume:
That the Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Honey (Export Inspection Charge) Bill and the Honey (Export Inspection Charge) Collection Bill are related to provisions for recouping a protection of the cost borne by the Commonwealth for the inspection of honey for export from Australia. It is recognised that two questions arise in relation to this matter which have nothing to do with the question of whether it is reasonable that there be some cost recovery from the industry concerned. The first relates to the cost recovery of a proportion of the provision of the service provided, and the proportion which has been provided for in the Honey (Export Inspection Charge) Bill is 50 per cent. The second question relates to the reasonableness of the amount allocated to be recovered, including the method of operating the service and calculating the cost. The second matter has caused some considerable concern.

SPEECH.PARA: The proposal is that an amount of $6.75 per tonne be imposed by regulation under the Bill. This would provide for a maximum amount of $14 to be charged. The total amount involved is a relatively small one of $49,000 which may or may not be reasonable. Much concern has been expressed in the industry with the suggestion that it is about three times as high as would be reasonable. Another concern is whether the proposed method of charge is equitable between honey producers. Dramatic examples have been put forward to support claims of inefficiency, administrative extravagance and the like. These may or may not have some validity.

The position is that considerable concern has been expressed. The Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations has considered this matter and is unanimously of the view that it would be desirable for this Bill to be referred to that Committee and for the Committee to have the opportunity to look at the second of the two questions which arise; that is, the reasonableness of the amount to be recovered and the method of operating the service and of allocating the costs by the Department of Primary Industry. I seek leave to move a motion. Briefly, there is no opposition to the principle; rather the Committee seeks an opportunity to examine the basis of the allocation of inspection export charges and the reasonableness of those charges. The Committee will investigate without delay and report by 28 April.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) That the Honey (Export Inspection Charge) Bill 1982 be referred to the Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations for consideration and report to the Senate.
(2) That the Committee report to the Senate on or before 28 April 1982.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats support this move and commend Senator Peter Rae on the work he has done in this regard. We believe that the reasons he set out, particularly the very high cost of the export levy at $6.75, certainly necessitate that there be an investigation of this matter, hence we support his motion.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Motion (by Senator Peter Rae)-by leave-agreed to:
That the consideration of the Honey (Export Inspection Charge) Collection Bill be an order of the day for the next day of sitting.

DEBATE.TITLE: INTERNATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS (PRIVILEGES AND IMMUNITIES) AMENDMENT BILL 1982

PROCTEXT.PARA: Assent reported.
Bill presented, and read a first time.
Standing Orders suspended.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

Honourable senators by now will be familiar with the practice of introducing an omnibus miscellaneous amendments Bill during each period of sittings of the Parliament as an expeditious way of making amendments of a non-controversial character to a large number of Acts. I said in the Senate on 25 November 1981 that provided this form of legislation is properly confined to non-controversial matters, it is a convenient way of approaching the situation. That has been the guiding principle in preparing the present Bill. The rest of the speech is a fairly lengthy detailed account of what I hope are non-controversial matters. I seek leave to incorporate it in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The short title of the Bill has been numbered 'No. 1' to indicate that a further omnibus Bill will, in the normal course, be introduced later this year in the Budget sittings. The numbering takes up a useful suggestion to this effect made by the opposition in another place on 17 November 1981, when the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Amendments) Act 1981 was being debated.
Some of the amendments are made by the Bill to correct printing or drafting errors. Others make drafting or other technical amendments. These provisions do not call for particular comment.

Other provisions go into matters of substance in varying degrees. I propose to explain in some detail the nature and effect of those provisions. In addition, a detailed explanatory memorandum covering all the clauses of the Bill has been circulated.

PROCTEXT.PARA: In a statement to the Senate on 26 May 1981, I advised that the Government has decided to give effect to a number of recommendations of the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances on matters relating to parliamentary disallowance of delegated legislation.

The amendments proposed by the Bill to the Acts Interpretation Act give effect to two of those recommendations. One is ensure that upon the dissolution of the House of Representatives after a notice of motion for disdallowance of a regulation is given in the Senate, the regulation shall be deemed to have been tabled on the first sitting day of the Senate after the dissolution of the House of Representatives. The amendments in paragraphs (a) and (b) of clause 4 of the Bill have that effect.

The other matter is to provide that on the disallowance of a regulation which repeals, in whole or in part, an earlier regulation the repealed regulation will be revived from and including the date of disallowance of the repealing regulation. This is dealth with by paragraph (c) of clause 4 of the Bill.

Paragraph (c) also deals with another matter. During the course of its preparation a question was raised whether the effect of sub-section 48 (3) of the Acts Interpretation Act upon a failure to lay regulations before each House of Parliament as required by paragraph 48 (1) (c), is to make such regulations void ab initio. If it did, any rights or obligations which accrued under the regulations between the date of making the regulation and the final date for tabling would be lost. The Bill clarifies this situation by amending sub-section 48 (6) to ensure that, upon the voiding of a regulation under sub-section 48 (3) , the regulation is regarded as having been repealed. The provisions of section 50, in relation to the repeal of regulations would then apply.
The principles contained in these amendments have also been applied by this Bill to the tabling of Ordinances and other instruments of a legislative character under the following Acts:
Ashmore and Cartier Islands Acceptance Act 1933
Australian Antarctic Territory Act 1954
Christmas Island Act 1958
Cocos (Keeling) Islands Act 1955
Coral Sea Islands Act 1969
Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974
Environment Protection (Nuclear Codes) Act 1978
Heard Island and McDonald Islands Act 1953
Norfolk Island Act 1979
Seat of Government (Administration) Act 1910.

Finally, I mention that the Bill applies sections 48, 49 and 50 of the Acts Interpretation Act to Rules of Court by the High Court, the Federal Court of Australia and the Supreme Court of the A.C.T. These amendments are also intended to give effect to the general policy referred to by me in the Senate on 26 May 1981 that there should be uniform application of the provisions of Part XII of the Acts Interpretation Act in relation to the tabling and disallowance of statutory instruments. It is considered that such provisions should also apply in the case of Rules of Court. The amendments to this effect are contained in clauses 67, 155 and 161 of the Bill.

The Bill makes a number of changes to the membership structure of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal and to the provisions governing the mode of operation of the Tribunal. The changes reflect the growing status of the Tribunal and its increasing workload. Many of the changes will give effect to recommendations of the Administrative Review Council and proposals of the President of the Tribunal.

The Tribunal now has jurisdiction to review decisions made under more than 100 statutes. It covers decisions in fields such as social security, immigration, repatriation, Commonwealth employees' compensation, patents, customs, air navigation, superannuation and export grants. The Tribunal's caseload grew from 227 in 1979/80 to 652 in 1980/81 mainly due to additions to its jurisdiction of social security and Commonwealth employees' compensation matters. Its caseload is expected to increase substantially in the current financial year.
The already increased workload and the further increases expected from the freedom of information legislation have highlighted the need to make changes in the membership structure of the Tribunal.

One of the main purposes of the changes now proposed is to rationalize the membership structure of the Tribunal, having regard to the role played on the Tribunal by Judges of the Federal Court of Australia. Although both Judges and non-judges may now be appointed as Deputy Presidents, in fact only Judges of the Federal Court have been so appointed. The Act as it stands does not distinguish between the roles of Judges and of non-judges.The Judges of the Federal Court who have been appointed as Deputy Presidents have played a valuable role, particularly in some areas of the Tribunal's jurisdiction. With the increasing workload of the Tribunal it is necessary to have additional members of Deputy President status but there is, of course, a limit to the extent to which Judges of the Federal Court can devote time to sitting on the Tribunal. Consequently, one purpose of the proposed amendments made by clauses 8, 9 and 40 will be to distinguish those presidential members who are Judges from Deputy Presidents who are not Judges, and to reserve certain critical powers for presidential members who are Judges. At the same time, the Bill recognises the existing practice of appointing a Judge of the Federal Court as President of the Tribunal, by requiring that the President shall be a Judge of the Federal Court.

The greater part of the jurisdiction of the Tribunal is in fact exercised by the senior non-presidential members, either sitting alone or as chairman of panels of the Tribunal. Full-time senior members are presently appointed for terms of years only. It is now proposed that a full-time senior member be appointed to the age of 65 years, to emphasise their independence in performing their functions on the Tribunal-see clause 10. Further, the role of the senior member in dealing with questions of law requires that he ordinarily have legal qualifications. This is recognised in the amendments made by clause 9.

Provision is to be made by clauses 14 and 38 for those members appointed to the Tribunal in future to take an appropriate oath of office, to mark the importance of the jurisdiction they will exercise.

The present complete bar on outside employment by full time members of the Tribunal is to be replaced by a provision expressly authorizing service with the Defence Force and permitting other employment to be undertaken with Ministerial approval-see clause 15.

Clause 22 of the Bill makes certain changes regarding statements of reasons under section 28 of the Act. First, the Tribunal is to be empowered to review a refusal by a decison-maker to give a statement of reasons for a decision when requested to do so under section 28 of the Act. The Tribunal is also to be empowered to review the sufficiency of a section 28 statement. Secondly, a number of other changes to section 28 will bring it, so far as appropriate, into line with the equivalent provision in section 13 of the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act. In future, a certificate by the Attorney-General preventing disclosure of certain material in a section 28 statement will not result, as at present, in the whole statement being withheld, but only so much of the statement as is covered by the certificate. The whole statement may be withheld only where omission of the matter covered by the certificate would render the statement false or misleading.

The working of the Tribunal will be aided by the provisions giving the President a wider power of delegation (clause 13), authorizing a wider class of members to exercise interlocutory powers (clause 17) and to give procedural directions (Clause 26). The agreement of all the parties will no longer be required to the holding of a preliminary conference (Clause 27).

Clause 25 of the Bill will empower the Attorney-General to intervene in proceedings before the Tribunal where the Commonwealth has a special interest in the proceedings and would wish to put argument on relevant matters to the Tribunal. Provision is made for payment by the Commonwealth of any increase in costs attributable to such an intervention.

The Act provides for the President of the Tribunal to rule on certain claims by the Attorney-General to privilege in respect of documents and oral evidence. Because this jurisdication is given at present to the president as such as such, and not to the Tribunal constituted by the President, the right of appeal to the Federal Court from a decision of the Tribunal does not apply to such a ruling. The effect of clauses 30 and 31 of the Bill will be to vest the power to make such a ruling in the Tribunal which will be required, for this purpose, to be constituted by a Judge of the Federal Court.

It is often convenient for the Tribunal to be able to hand down a decision, with oral reasons for the decision, without the delay involved in the preparation of a written statement. As the Act now stands, it is doubtful whether this may be done, even where a written statement is provided later. Accordingly, clause 33 of the Bill empowers the Tribunal to give either oral or written reasons at the time it hands down a decision. If it does not then give written reasons, it must do so if requested to do so by a party to the proceedings. This provision is designed to avoid delays that now occur in the decision of the Tribunal being available in those cases where it has come to a conclusion at the end of the hearing, but must now delay the handing down of the decision until reasons for the decision have been reduced to writing. The change will be of particular benefit in many social security cases, where an early decision is desirable.
The remaining amendments to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act are largely consequential to those I have already mentioned, or make minor changes to facilitate the working of the Tribunal.

Part IV of the Bill amends the Aged Persons Hostels Act 1972, which is to become known as the Aged or Disabled Persons Hostels Act 1972. The key amendment is made by paragraph (a) of clause 45, which amends section 5 of the Act to extend to disabled persons as well as to aged persons.

The amendments will enable organisations to accommodate disabled persons in hostels originally approved or constructed with grants under the Act for accommodation of aged persons only. Accordingly, the amendments also provide that where an organisation has made an agreement with the Director-General of Social Services undertaking to continue to use a hostel as a home for aged persons only, the undertaking will be deemed to have been given with respect to continued use of the hostel as a home for persons who are aged or disabled.

These amendments will bring the Act into line with the major legislation in the Government's program to house aged and disabled persons, the Aged or Disabled Persons Homes Act 1954, which was amended in 1974 to extend its coverage to disabled persons. The amendments will allow organisations greater flexibility in the operation of homes funded under both Acts ''under the one roof'' and will materially assist disabled persons in those areas (especially in the country) where the only available form of specialised accommodation is a hostel built with a grant under the Aged Persons Hostels Act.
Introduction of these matters of substance also affords an opportunity to make a number of formal amendments.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY SUPREME COURT ACT 1933

PROCTEXT.PARA: Part VIII of the Bill makes several significant amendments to the Australian Capital Territory Supreme Court Act 1933. First, the designation of the Chief Judge of the Court is changed to 'Chief Justice'. This brings the designation into line with the Supreme Court of all the States and the Northern Territory.

Secondly, clause 65 makes it clear that a Judge of the Federal Court of Australia who is appointed to the Supreme Court of the the Australian Capital Territory is not entitled to double salary. His primary salary entitlement will continue to arise from his Federal Court appointment. Provision is, however, made to ensure that, if the Supreme Court entitlements exceed his Federal Court entitlements, he will receive the higher amount and ensures that if the salary or annual allowances to which he would be entitled as a Judge of the Court exceeds the salary and annual allowance by which he is remunerated as a Judge of the Federal Court of Australia, he shall receive as a Judge of the Court, an additional amount by way of salary or annual allowances, equal to the excess.

DEBATE.TITLE: AMENDMENTS OF THE CO-OPERATIVE COMPANIES AND SECURITIES SCHEME

PROCTEXT.PARA: The amendments proposed by Parts XV, XVI, XXVII and XXXVI relate to the package of legislation which comprises the co-operative companies and securities scheme.

On 22 December 1978 the Commonwealth and the six States executed a Formal Agreement that provided the framework for a co-operative Commonwealth/State scheme for a uniform system of law and administration in relation to company law and the regulation of the securities industry in the six States and the Australian Capital Territory. A copy of the Agreement is set out in the Schedule to the National Companies and Securities Commission Act 1979.

Clause 8 (1) (a) of the Agreement provides that the Commonwealth will submit to this Parliament legislation which has been unanimously agreed by the Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities, and shall take such steps as are appropriate to secure the passage of the legislation. The relevant amendments in these Parts have been unanimously approved by the Ministerial Council only after detailed discussion and consideration. Also, the amendments are of a kind considered appropriate for inclusion in the Miscellaneous Amendments Bill. The effect of the particular amendments is set out in detail in the explanatory memorandum that has been circulated. I draw attention to the following features.

Under the amendments of the Companies Act made by Part XV of the Bill, the provisions of the Act relating to inspection of registers kept by companies and the availability of copies of these registers will be standardized. See, for example, clause 95. Other amendments result from on-going work on preparation of the regulations to be made under this Act. Some of the amendments are not intended to change the operation of the principal legislation, but simply to ensure that it does, in fact, operate as originally envisaged.

A significant change to the Act is in the area of registration of charges. It had originally been intended that details of charges contained on registers maintained under the pre-existing law would be transferred to the new registers to be maintained under the new priority system. However, because of administrative difficulties in some States relating to the transfer of information on existing charges to the new register, the Ministerial Council has decided to retain the existing registers for a twelve month period at least. This will enable the Ministerial Council to review the provisions relating to the register.
For this purpose, a new section 215A is to be inserted in the Act by clause 105 of the Bill.
There are also a large number of minor amendments which needed to be made to the Companies Act 1981 before it came into operation.

The amendments of the Companies (Acquisition of Shares) Act are made by Part XVI of the Bill. The time within which the National Companies and Securities Commission may declare an acquisition of shares or other conduct to be unacceptable has been extended from 14 days to 90 days after the acquisition has taken place or specified conduct has been engaged in. The amendment is to be found in clause 132.

Once the Commission has made such a declaration, it will be able to make certain orders which are to be published in the Gazette-see clause 133. These will include orders restraining the disposal or acquisition of an interest in specified shares, restraining the exercise of voting rights, or directing a company not to issue shares to a person who holds shares in it. These orders will generally expire after 30 days, although a person aggrieved by an order will be able to apply to the Supreme Court for its variation or revocation.

Furthermore, in exercising its powers under sections 45, 47, 48, 57 and 60 of the Companies (Acquisition of Shares) Act, the Supreme Court will have the power to make interim orders and will be able to make orders without requiring undertakings as to damages-see clause 131.

Part XXXVI amends the Securities Industry Act. References in sections 4 and 12 of the Act to an acquisition of shares or an acquisition of securities will be clarified by providing that they shall include circumstances where a person is taken to acquire shares in a company for the purposes of the Companies ( Acquisition of Shares) Act- see clauses 208 and 209.

Also, in exercising its powers under sections 14, 83, and 147 of the Securities Industry Act, the Supreme Court will have the power to make interim orders and will be able to make orders without requiring undertakings as to damages-see clauses 210, 212 and 213 of the Bill.

DEBATE.TITLE: CONSULAR PRIVILEGES AND IMMUNITIES ACT 1972DIPLOMATIC PRIVILEGES AND IMMUNITIES ACT 1967

PROCTEXT.PARA: The purpose of the amendments made by Parts XVII and XX of the Bill to the consular and diplomatic privileges and immunities legislation is to assist in preventing the misuse of the customs duty exemptions provided by that legislation. Pursuant to the obligations in the two Vienna Conventions on diplomatic and consular relations respectively, Australia accords, by way of that legislation, customs duty exemptions to members of foreign diplomatic missions and consular posts in Australia.

It is currently possible for most diplomatic and consular personnel and their families to import into Australia for their personal use motor vehicles free of sales tax and customs duty. Those vehicles may then be sold or otherwise disposed of without the payment of duties or taxes after they have been retained for two years. Luxury vehicles can thus be sold at a considerable profit.

The amendments increase from 2 to 3 years the period within which persons entitled to customs exemption under either of the Acts may not dispose of motor vehicles without restriction. The 3 year period corresponds with the usual period for which foreign diplomatic and consular personnel are posted to Australia.
At the same time, the number of vehicles which can be imported free of customs duty by each family under the Acts will be reduced administratively.
These measures are consistent with international practice.

The amendments to the Copyright Act 1968 contained in Part XVIII of the Bill are concerned entirely with the provisions of that Act providing for the Copyright Tribunal. Having regard to the nature of applications currently before the Tribunal and applications expected to be made to it in the near future, the Government has concluded that the existing provisions of the Act requiring members of the Tribunal to possess legal qualifications unduly restrict the range of possible candidates from which members may be appointed. It is felt that the deliberations of the Tribunal could be helped by the presence of members possessing expertise in other occupations relevant to the subject matter of applications before, or likely to be coming before, the Tribunal. Accordingly clause 139 of the Bill broadens the range of qualifications for eligibility for membership.

At the same time, by analogy with the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act, only Judges of the Federal Court of Australia are, under the Bill, to be eligible for appointment as President and Deputy President of the Tribunal. In this regard I point out that under the existing provisions of the Copyright Act, the President and Deputy President have more onerous duties than other members.

Clause 144 modifies the provisions of the Act permitting a Tribunal to continue hearing an application after one of its members ceases to be available. The Bill will make the authority of the Tribunal to continue in such circumstances dependent on the continued presence of the President or Deputy President on the Tribunal for that hearing.

The opportunity has been taken in the Bill to make other amendments to the Copyright Act to substitute new provisions regarding the termination of the appointments of members of the Tribunal (clause 140), the authority of the Deputy President when acting in place of the President (clause 141), and the fixing of the remuneration and allowances of Tribunal members (clause 142). The provisions substituted by the Bill follow the pattern of provisions for similar bodies in other Acts that have been enacted more recently than the provisions of the Copyright Act being replaced.

These amendments are primarily designed to provide a legislative basis for the payment of a Presiding Officer who, though himself no longer a member of the Parliament, continues to perform for a period the statutory functions of the office until the election of a successor. Thus Sir Condor Laucke, though no longer a Senator after 30 June 1981, was deemed to be President of the Senate ( in accordance with the Parliamentary Presiding Officers Act 1965) until 18 August 1981. There was, however, no provision for him to be paid any allowance.
In such circumstances an appropriate ex gratia payment has customarily been made.

It now seems appropriate to put the matter on a proper footing, and at the same time to repeal obsolete provisions of the Parliamentary Allowances Act 1952 which relate to allowances now prescribed by the Remuneration Tribunal.
The amendments also provide for a situation in which a Chairman of Committees is required, e.g. by the death of the Presiding Officer, to take over the functions of his office for a time.

Part XXXI of the Bill includes provisions which amend the Patents Act 1952 to relax the requirements for patent applicants who wish to make divisional applications. The jurisdiction of courts under a number of provisions in the Patent Act is clarified, and two further classes of decisions under the Act are made subject to review by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.

Part XXXI also introduces a wider regulation making power with respect to the professional conduct of patent attorneys. This is being included at the request of the Institute of Patent Attorneys of Australia.

The amendments made by Part XXXIV of the Bill will enable an Australian Royal Commission to function in a foreign country where appropriate arrangements in that regard have been made with the foreign country. It is envisaged that in some cases a Royal Commission would take evidence in the foreign country pursuant to its Australian commission and in other cases it would take evidence pursuant to an authority issued to it under the law of the foreign country. See clause 203.

The legislation is proposed against the background of discussions between Australia and New Zealand for the Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drug Trafficking, conducted by Mr Justice Stewart, to take evidence in New Zealand for the purposes of its inquiries.

The Student Assistance Act 1973 outlines the broad provisions of the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme (TEAS) and the Post-graduate Awards Scheme. The clauses which form Part XXXIV of the Bill will amend the Act to repeal those provisions which are no longer relevant, to make minor changes to facilitiate the administration of the two schemes and to make certain changes to the procedures of the Student Assistance Review Tribunals which review decisions of the Department of Education on individual students' entitlements. The proposed amendments do not reflect changes in Government policy and will not restrict entitlement to benefits.

As far as the administration of TEAS and the Post-graduate Award Scheme is concerned, the amendments will provide that the Minister for Education may approve part only of a course in addition to the existing authority in relation to a course as a whole (clauses 223 and 226). For example, a course may comprise an academic component which is suitable for approval and periods of employment experience which fall outside the scope of educational assistance. The amendments will also enable regulations to be made which would provide for the payment to persons under TEAS of amounts associated with travel to and from an institution, other than by way of reimbursement of fares (clause 224).

There are clauses which concern procedures to be followed by Student Assistance Review Tribunals. They will enable an appellant to withdraw a request for review if, for example, in the light of further information the decision being appealed against has been reversed in the appellant's favour (clause 232). An appellant will also be given the option of having his appeal heard by a two member Tribunal where, for example, the third member is found to be unavailable on the day the appeal is scheduled to be heard (clause 233).

The amendments will provide two further measures which are consistent with the Government's experience with other review bodies and the recommendations of the Bowen Report on Public Duty and Private interest, and are in the interests of appellants. They will require a Tribunal member to declare any interest he may have in the proceedings under review (clause 233), and will enable the Tribunals to safeguard the confidentialy of certain documents presented and evidence given in respect of a particular hearing, where there is good reason for doing so ( clause 238).
I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Senator Gietzelt) adjourned.
Motion (by Senator Jessop) agreed to:

(1) That, pursuant to the Resolution agreed to by the Senate on 26 November 1981 and notwithstanding anything contained in the Standing Orders, a Standing Committee to be known as the Appropriations and Staffing Committee be appointed and, thereafter, be re-appointed at the commencement of each Parliament.
(2) That the Committee inquire into:
(a) proposals for the Annual Estimates and the Additional Estimates for the Senate;
(b) proposals to vary the staff organisational structure of the Senate, and staffing and recruitment policies; and
(c) such other matters as are referred to it by the Senate.
(3) That the Committee-
(a) in relation to the Estimates-
(i) determine the amounts for inclusion in the Parliamentary Appropriation Bills for the Annual Estimates and the Additional Estimates, and
(ii) report to the Senate upon its determinations prior to the consideration by the Senate of the related Parliamentary Appropriation Bill;
(b) in relation to staffing-
(i) makes such recommendations to the President as it sees fit, and.
(ii) report to the Senate on any matter it considers necessary; and
(c) make an annual report to the Senate on the operations of the Senate's appropriations and staffing, and related matters.

(4) That, unless otherwise ordered, the Committee shall consist of the President and six other Senators-the Leader of the Government in the Senate or such other Senate Minister as may be nominated to represent him from time to time, and two other members of the Government to be nominated by the Leader of the Government in the Senate, and the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate or such other Senator as may be nominated to represent him from time to time, and two other Senators not being members of the Government to be nominated by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate or by any minority group or groups or Independent Senator or Independent Senators: provided that, in the absence of agreement between the Opposition and any minority group or groups or Independent Senator or Independent Senators, as to nominations, duly notified to the President, the question as to representation shall be determined by the Senate.
(5) That the quorum of the Committee be four.

(6) That the Committee have power to appoint sub-committees consisting of three or more of its members, and to refer to any such sub-committee any of the matters which the Committee is empowered to consider. The quorum of a sub- committee shall be two Senators.
(7) That the Committee may proceed to the despatch of business notwithstanding that all members have not been appointed and notwithstanding any vacancy.

(8) That the Chairman of the Committee be the President who may from time to time appoint another member of the Committee to be Deputy-Chairman and the member so appointed shall act as Chairman at any time when there is no Chairman or the Chairman is not present at a meeting of the Committee.
(9) That, in the event of an equality of voting, the Chairman, or the Deputy- Chairman when acting as Chairman, have a casting vote.
(10) That a Senator, though not a member of the Committee, may attend and participate in its deliberations, and question witnesses, unless the Committee orders otherwise, but shall not vote.

(11) That the Committee or any sub-committee have power to send for and examine persons, papers and records, to move from place to place, and to meet and transact business in public or private session and notwithstanding any prorogation of the Parliament or dissolution of the House of Representatives.
(12) That a daily Hansard be published of such proceedings of the Committee as take place in public.
(13) That the Committee be provided with all necessary staff, facilities and resources.

DEBATE.TITLE: SELECT COMMITTEE ON PARLIAMENT'S APPROPRIATIONS AND STAFFING

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator Sir JOHN CARRICK
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a statement on the Jessop Committee report.
—That is the Senate Select Committee on Staffing and Appropriations.
—That is correct.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I had intended to intrude on the debate on the motion to establish a standing committee and make a statement giving the Government's response to the report of the Select Committee on Parliament's Appropriations and Staffing. I apologise because I was not here. The speech was to have been circulated and I hope that it has been. Very briefly-I am conscious that I am speaking by leave-the Government has approached this matter in good faith. We believe that, given goodwill on both sides, the Committee's recommendations will work. I seek leave to have the Government's response to the report incorporated in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

This statement arises from the Government's consideration of the report of the Senate Select Committee on Parliament's Appropriations and Staffing, tabled on 19 August 1981. While the recommendations in the report essentially deal with the Senate, the Government's response covers, and is therefore being made in, both Houses of the Parliament. I note in passing that the current procedures for considering the parliamentary Estimates were to be reviewed in any event for the 1982-83 Budget. The Government acknowledges the valuable work of the Committee. In developing its response it has had the benefit of their further views and discussed the matters raised by the Committee with the presiding officers.

The terms of reference of the Senate Select Committee were to inquire into and report upon Parliament's control of its own appropriations and staffing, and related matters. The central theme in the report is that Parliament should have greater independence and autonomy in regard to its own internal arrangements and operations. Control of Parliament's appropriations and staffing is seen by the Committee as essential to achieving this independence.

The Government, of course, agrees that the independence of Parliament as such from executive control is a central principle of our Constitution which must be upheld. But just as the Parliament must exercise its rights and meet its responsibilities, so must the Government be able to fulfil its constitutional obligations, in this case the control of the expenditure of public money.

In responding to the report, the Government has had to devise a balance between these fundamental principles bearing in mind the provisions of the Australian Constitution and the development of parliamentary government in Australia. I believe that the detailed measures I will outline a little later meet this challenge.

This balance assumes there will be a continuing dialogue between the Parliament and the Executive, and it remains the Government's firm intention that such dialogue is effective, and recognizes the proper roles and responsibilities of each party. The fact that this response has taken the time it has flows in part from our commitment to such discussions at all stages.
I now turn to the Government's response to the specific major recommendations of the Jessop Committee.
The report contains recommendations on five main topics:
Parliament's control of its own funding
a separate parliamentary appropriation Bill
transfer of items in appropriations of Government Departments to the parliamentary appropriation Bill and parliamentary administration
control over staffing and terms and conditions of employment
a parliamentary appropriations and staffing committee.

On the first and key issue the Government believes firmly that it needs to maintain control over the total amount of funds available for expenditure by the Parliament because of the constitutional responsiblity of the Government for budgetary policy and for the level of public expenditure. Moreover it is the Government which has the odium of raising the revenue which funds that expenditure.

However, the Government recognises that detailed control over individual expenditure items is not necessary. The Government therefore proposes that it simply approve overall figures, broken down into a capital and a recurrent item, for each of the Senate, the House of Representatives and, as a group, the three joint departments. This arrangement properly balances the overall government responsibility for the level of public expenditure with the responsibility of the parliamentary departments and the presiding officers to determine (subject to parliamentary approval) the direction of that expenditure.

The Government also proposes that, commencing with the financial year 1982-83, there be a separate parliamentary Appropriation Bill which, consistent with the Select Committee recommendations, will not be treated as a Bill for the ordinary annual services of the Government, and will cover all recurrent and capital expenditure items currently administered by the parliamentary departments.

I should also say that the arrangements for consultations between the presiding officers and the Government (and consultations at officer level) during the Budget process will, of course, be maintained.

Within the total figure for parliamentary departments, the Government is also suggesting an advance to the presiding officers as recommended by the Select Committee, provided that such an advance is operated in the same way as the Advance to the Minister for Finance. The Government will be proposing an amendment to the Audit Act in due course to facilitate the use of this advance.

On the question of the transfer of certain items from appropriations of government departments to the parliamentary Appropriation Bill and parliamentary administration, the Government proposes that the two aspects be considered together and therefore that these items should be the subject of further discussions.

I turn now to the topic of control over staffing. The Government has most carefully considered the need to maintain a measure of control over the total number of public sector employees. The Government's policies in this regard are a matter of public record. Suffice it to say that the Government does not wish public sector employees to have any pace-setting role and expects that due regard be paid to principles of wage restraint.

On the basis that the presiding officers undertake to consult with the Public Service Board before determining staff ceilings for individual parliamentary departments, and provided that the presiding officers publish projected ceilings in advance, with the previous year's actual ceilings, by reporting annually to the Parliament, then the Government is willing to give control over staff numbers to the presiding officers.

On terms and conditions of employment of parliamentary staff the Government is also asking presiding officers to give an undertaking to consult with the Public Service Board before determining (as they are now empowered to) those terms and conditions, and that such determinations should also be published annually when the presiding officers report to Parliament. The reason for this is to avoid any undesirable 'leap-frogging' in terms and conditions between parliamentary and executive departments. I should make it clear that these consultations would be on the basis that the final powers reside with the presiding officers, that they agree to consult, but there is to be no statutory requirement on them to do so.

The decisions of the Parliament in these areas should be subject to the same types of scrutiny, inside and outside the Parliament, as those of the Government . It is up to the Parliament to prove its managerial ability in the same fashion as the Government. It is for this reason that the Government is proposing that the presiding officers report annually to the Parliament on the numbers, classification and disposition of staff, as well as any variation in terms and conditions of employment. They should also provide a detailed breakdown of previous and proposed expenditure within each of the items contained in the parliamentary Appropriatoin Bill.

Given these arrangements, a number of further powers will be transferred to the presiding officers as recommended by the Senate Committee. The Government will be proposing amendments to the Public Service Acts Amendment Bill 1981 now before the Parliament, to vest in the presiding officers power to create, classify and abolish offices, and to make appointments below the level of permanent head.

Finally, the Select Committee proposed the establishment of a Senate appropriations and staffing committee. The Government considers that it is appropriate for the Senate itself to decide on the mechanisms it wishes to establish to advise the president on his responsibilities and, therefore, proposes to leave this recommendation in the Senate's hands. For the House, the Government will not be proposing any similar committee.

I am confident that the revised arrangements as I have outlined will provide the basis for a reasonable balance between the need for the Parliament to have a greater degree of autonomy in relation to funding and staffing and the need for the government to retain a limited number of overall controls in the execution of its proper responsibilities.
