DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN INSTITUTE OF ABORIGINAL STUDIES: SOCIAL IMPACT OF URANIUM MINING ON NORTHERN TERRITORY ABORIGINALS

PROCTEXT.PARA: Report and Ministerial Statement

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the report from the Australian Institute of Aboriginal Studies on the Social Impact of Uranium Mining on Northern Territory Aboriginals. I seek leave to make a statement in connection with the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to incorporate the statement in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-

I wish to inform the Senate that I have received a report from the Australian Institute of Aboriginal Studies on the social impact of uranium mining on Northern Territory Aboriginals, for the six month period ending 30 September 1981. I now present that report and seek leave to make a statement concerning some of the issues raised in it.

Before commenting on aspects of the report itself, I should like to draw your attention, Mr President, and the attention of Honourable Senators, to the fact that the Institute personnel who are operating in the Alligator Rivers Region have established fine working relationships with other governmental and non- governmental bodies in the region. Perhaps the most valuable of these relationships is the one that Institute personnel have established with the Standing Committee on the Social Impact, which is doing excellent work on the spot, as a decision making and co-ordinating body, aimed at ensuring that the social impact of uranium mining does not become detrimental. Aboriginal representatives-both from the Northern Land Council and from the local community -as well as Institute personnel hold membership on this Committee, along with representatives of the Territory and the Commonwealth Governments.

Mr President, I turn now to a discussion of aspects of the Institute's report, particularly those aspects which-as it is proper for it to do-draw my attention to unfavourable possible developments in the region. I should like to draw your attention, Mr President, and the attention of Honourable Senators to these developments, and to indicate in brief outline what steps the Commonwealth Government is taking, in association with the Northern Territory Government and other bodies, to alleviate and correct them.

One of the matters raised in the report is an apparent insufficiency of information and education available for Aboriginals on matters of safety connected with the uranium projects in the region. This matter has now been taken under cognisance by three of the bodies operating in the region.

First, the Bureau of the Northern Land Council accepts that this is an area in which it has a major role. I have been informed that the Bureau will be increasing its efforts in the area of environmental safety information and education.

Second, the Supervising Scientist, whose function it is, among other things, to develop measures for protection of the environment, is aware of Aboriginal concerns about safety and has acted to provide information to Aboriginals in the region on the work of his Office and of the Alligator Rivers Region Research Institute.

And third, the Alligator Rivers Region Research Institute, which monitors the technical aspects and the physical effects of uranium mining, held an open information day at Jabiru East last November. This was attended by a significant number of local traditional owners who took the opportunity to learn about and to discuss the roles of the Institute and the Supervising Scientist in the region.
Other agencies, including the Ranger and Nabarlek Liaison and Advisory Committees, will also be encouraged to improve the flow of information to local Aboriginals on safety matters.

The report speaks of inadequacies in adult education facilities in the region. I understand that the difficulties in this area are due at least in part to the high mobility of the people in the region, and indeed an adult educator was withdrawn last year from Oenpelli due to the lack of enrolments in the courses offered.

Nevertheless, the problem is one which is recognised as requiring sympathetic consideration and solution. A new adult educator has been appointed for Oenpelli , and I understand that he took up his duties in mid-January of this year.

The report notes that two significant Aboriginal associations are now functioning: the Gagudju Association in respect of Ranger mining income beneficiaries, and the Kunwinjku Association in respect of Nabarlek. These associations were established by Aboriginal communities, with the assistance of the Northern Land Council, to manage the funds received by the communities as a result of mining activity, and to maintain other administrative functions of the communities concerned.

The Institute's report suggests, however, that the proliferation of other small clan-based uni-functional associations will need to be watched, and an effort made to fit them into the wider-based associations in the region. This concern was raised at the Standing Committee's recent meeting and it was decided that, while the issue is primarily one for the Northern Land Council to resolve, a working party of the Standing Committee should examine the question and provide assistance to the Northern Land Council in this matter.

The report suggests that there may be an excessive degree of consultation and information being imposed on Aboriginal communities and individuals in the region. Indeed the Standing Committee has commented that the dissemination of information presents the Committee with one of its greatest difficulties, because of the need to provide effective information and to consult Aboriginals on important issues, and yet not to impose too heavy a load on the people of the region.

I understand that the Northern Land Council has offered to research this whole question and to report back to the Standing Committee on the wishes of the people and on ways of meeting their requirements. The Communication Planning Section of the Department of the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory is examining similar issues and will maintain liaison with the Northern Land Council.

I turn now to the problems of alcohol, which have again been highlighted in the report. The question of access by Aboriginal workers to the Nabarlek ''wet'' canteen appears to have been resolved for the time being. The management of Queensland Mines Limited and the local Aboriginal people have agreed that the mine manager and several of the influential traditional owners will determine who may have access to the canteens.

In the wider region, the report refers to three alcohol-related road deaths of Aboriginals. The local communities are concerned, and rightly so, at this development; and over recent years they have been taking a growing number of measures, with Government support, to bring the alcohol problem under their control. These measures include the purchase of some of the liquor outlets in the region, the declaration of ''dry areas'', and the making of submissions to the Northern Territory Liquor Commission on matters relating to the licensing and re-licensing of liquor outlets.

The report refers to problems of accommodation and education at the Coonjimba Camp, which is within the Ranger Project area. Most of the residents of the camp have, I understand, expressed a wish to remain on the site and to have the camp upgraded to the status of an outstation.

This matter has been discussed between the camp residents, Ranger, the Northern Land Council, and the Gagudju Association. I understand that the Gagudju Association has accepted some responsibility for upgrading the facilities at the camp and, possibly also, for providing a building and other facilities for an outstation school. Discussions are continuing.
The report cites the need for improved banking facilities in the region and the provision of advice to local communities on investment, saving, and trading matters.

The question of provision of full bank facilities concerns only Oenpelli, as Jabiru will have a full banking service available by April of this year. Jabiru is, of course, a sizeable town and it is a viable proposition to provide that level of service. Approaches to the banks concerning similar facilities for Oenpelli have not been successful, and it is unlikely that they will be until such time as royalty income to the Oenpelli community reaches a level which is sufficient to warrant more than the present savings bank agency of the Commonwealth Bank. That Bank has, however, offered the services of its advisers to visit Oenpelli as needed to provide advice on general banking matters.

On the question of investment advice, I am informed that the Gagudju Association has on its own initiative sought out the advice of financial advisers. The Kunwinjku Association can be expected to do the same. In addition, the Northern Territory Development Commission has offered its services to put both these Associations in contact with investment consultants.

Finally, the report, on page 54, makes one new recommendation and it also refers back to five recommendations in the previous report. I should like to refer here, Mr President, to the measures that have been taken or are to be taken in relation to these six recommendations.

The new recommendation is that there should be a systematic review and assessment of induction programs provided by mining companies, government departments, and other authorities for their personnel in the Alligator Rivers Region.

I have been informed that the Northern Land Council is presently examining the question of mining company induction programs, which are provided for in the Ranger and Nabarlek mining agreements, with a view to making them more effective .

One of the recommendations in the previous report related to the introduction of a course in Gunwinggu-which is an Aboriginal language widely spoken in the Alligator Rivers Region-for the benefit of mining and government personnel.

This matter is now under consideration by the Standing Committee on the Social Impact, several of whose members are expert in the Gunwinggu language, and who know of other personnel and facilities that can be utilised in the preparation of a course in the language concerned.

Another recommendation in the previous Institute report was that serious attempts should be made to involve Aboriginal people from the region in the work of all committees which review and make decisions about the region.

The situation, Mr President, is that local Aboriginals either directly or indirectly through the Northern Land Council-already are represented in some of the committees whose work affects the land and people of the region. I recognise , however, that the extent of Aboriginal representation on these committees could be increased. One of the reasons put forward for low Aboriginal representation is the involvement of potential committeemen in a range of other activities such as employment, local council affairs and, indeed, on other committees. Another is the degree of formality in the proceedings of these committees which might be acting as a deterrent for more local Aboriginals becoming involved in them. Once again, Mr President, this is a matter for which a number of solutions has been proposed and which the Standing Committee is currently examining.

Yet another of the recommendations was that there should be a systematic comparison and review of the various agreements that have been contracted between mining companies and Aboriginal groups in the region.

I am not quite sure from the wording of the recommendation what the purpose of such a comparison or review might be. Nor am I sure who the best person or body might be to conduct such a project. In any case, there is nothing in the commission to the Institute that would prevent it from undertaking this project itself, if it thought that the project would serve a useful purpose. My own view , however, is that the Northern Land Council, which both liaises with the local communities and negotiates the agreements with the mining companies, has by now built up considerable expertise in these matters. Northern Land Council negotiators are able to draw on that expertise.

Another recommendation contained in the last Institute report was that a program should be initiated to assist the Aboriginals to maintain their culture in the face of mining developments and associated activities in the region.

I should like to point out Mr President, that Aboriginals in the region are already active in maintaining their culture. This can be seen through their efforts in the setting up of numerous outstations in the region; in the development of outstation schools with the use of local languages in teaching; the teaching of aspects of culture; and in the increased attention given by Aboriginals to arts and craft production and to the teaching of associated skills. The Government is assisting Aboriginals in their efforts to maintain their culture through such means as financial support for the outstation movement, the Aboriginal Crafts Board, the Aboriginal Dance Theatre and for the range of activities supported by my Department's culture and recreation appropriation.

The final recommendation in the previous Institute report was that Land Councils should be encouraged to prepare long range land management schemes, and that they should be provided with resources that may be necessary to assist them in this task.

I am able to advise the Chamber, Mr President, that the Bureau of the Northern Land Council has recently undergone a major restructuring and upgrading of its administrative and financial resources. The Bureau now possesses the capacity to engage in long term land management planning of the kind that the Institute envisages in its recommendation.

This concludes my comments, Mr President, on the critical aspects and on the recommendations contained or referred to in the report which I am tabling today. I should add that, on the matter of Aboriginal employment and training in the region, which has been referred to in a number of Institute reports the work of a special working party of the Standing Committee on the Social Impact has only recently been completed. I will be able to comment on this subject when I table the next Institute report.

Finally, Mr President, I want to state my satisfaction at the fact that there are in the region significant positive social developments which are also related to the uranium development projects in the area. I can do no better than to quote the latest Institute report on this matter, when it says:

''Mining has brought to the Aboriginal people of the region access to financial resources which provide a basis for a degree of independence from government funding and presence . . . (and there is) increasing confidence of important decision makers to confront major issues . . .''

This Government will continue to foster Aboriginal independence and Aboriginal confidence, as it will continue in its efforts to ameliorate any deleterious effects of mining activity on the Aboriginal inhabitants of the region.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Robertson Sen E.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

The major comments on the Australian Institute of Aboriginal Studies report on the social impact of uranium mining on Northern Territory Aboriginals will be made by the shadow Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Senator Ryan. I would like to make a few comments as well. First, I comment on the fact that we are able to react only to the statement that the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume) put down. We still have the unfortunate situation of the report not being available to us in time for us to do some detailed study of it before we make our statement. This, to me, makes reasoned debate very difficult. I am not critical of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs at this time because it is a practice that has developed. We have raised this matter before; I raise it again at this time.

We ought to have the reports-embargoed if necessary-two or three hours before the Minister tables them so that we can make some sort of reasoned comment. It is possible that the Minister's statements might neglect elements which are unfavourable to the Government. I am not saying that they do; it is possible that this is so. We could not do anything about that. When the report is put aside for later debate we have to wait for several months to speak on it. Quite clearly, when people are reading Hansard they do not pick up one copy and then another one that is six months later. I think it is unfortunate that we have this approach. It is a traditional one; we have tried to change it. I hope that we will be able to take some action soon to do so. I believe that a government that talks about co-operation and adopts this sort of attitude breeds only mistrust. There is no reason we should not have the document beforehand.

I shall make a few comments on the statement of the Minister; that is all that I can do. Firstly, the staff of the Institute are working in a most interesting area and one which is for them very difficult-more difficult than it need be; but I will not go into that. When I represented the Australian Labor Party on the AIAS I found it a very interesting period of my time. The fact that the Northern Territory is involved makes this report more important to me.

A number of aspects were raised by the Minister. The first that concerns me relates to safety connected with the uranium project. Let me make the point that although the Minister said that the Northern Land Council would accept responsibility for doing something about this-by 'something' he is talking about education-we were told that the mining is safe, that there are not problems with dust, that the tailing dams are safe, that there is no possible runoff and that there is no danger with the transportation of yellowcake. If there are no dangers what is the problem with safety? Why has there been an expression of concern about which the Aboriginal people need to be educated? If any safety measures are required at the mine site these are clearly the responsibility not of the Northern Land Council but of the company concerned. Every company that operates, regardless of the industry, has its own safety measures. We certainly do not want to go to the Northern Land Council and say: 'You must not go to that area because there are some tailing dams there and you might have a runoff; you might get affected'. So it is the responsibility of the mining company to operate effectively. If there are any problems I believe that not only the company but also the Minister have some pretty solid questions to answer because we are told that there are no problems. We are told that the Supervising Scientist is aware of the concern of the Aboriginal people. I make the comment again that if the Supervising Scientist is concerned, what is he concerned about ? What are the grounds for this concern if there is no danger in mining in that area?

The report speaks of inadequacies in adult education facilities in the area. It makes the comment that sympathetic consideration is part of the solution to the problem and that a new Adult Educator has been appointed for Oenpelli. I accept this proposition. We all know that sympathetic consideration is important in the job of an adult educator. But let me make the point strongly that the job of the Adult Educator is to meet the needs of the region, particularly the community on which he is based, and not to do the job of the mining company. I trust that there is no doubt that he will work with the standing committee and the group from the AIAS to mitigate the effects of mining, if any. Of course, we know that there are some. We are not talking about the physical effects, but the social effects. It is the social impact of mining about which we are concerned. The Adult Educator can play a major role but it is not for him, as suggested by the Minister's statement-unless I read it incorrectly-to do the job of the mining company, which is to make sure, firstly, that the mine is safe and, secondly, that people who may move near the mine are protected.

I was most disturbed with the comment in the Minister's statement where he said that the report suggests that there may be an excessive degree of consultation. It has been my experience that the Aboriginal people have handled very well the transition from being poked, prodded and measured over the first 30 years or 40 years. That was the situation. They have moved and they have handled the move very well. I am concerned with the comment about excessive consultation because I am afraid that it might mean pressurising and hard selling, the sort of thing for which Gallarrwuy Yunupingu received a silver pen. Information is not so much a problem unless it is part of similar progress. Induction programs are mentioned and I believe these are vital. We need a systematic review and an assessment. That is vital also but it must be related to the total policies of the area.

There was a suggestion that we might have courses in Gunwinggu. This is excellent for the people who are going to stay there for a long time. This is the sort of thing with which the Minister agrees and I support him wholeheartedly. Gunwinggu is a difficult language to learn because of its complexity, as are most of the Aboriginal languages. So we would be concerned only with giving a brief course for those who will be there for a short time and a longer course for those who are staying longer. It is a step in the right direction if it indicates on the part of the mining company and the Government of the Northern Territory a respect of the culture of the Aboriginal people. That is the first step in learning the language. As honourable senators who have lived in the area or who have moved through the area know, if one moves into a community and indicates that one has learnt a few phrases of the language it is enough to open the door because the community realises that their culture is appreciated.

Another recommendation in the previous report of the Institute was that serious attempts should be made to involve Aboriginal people from the region in the work committees which review and make decisions about the region. I commend this. The Minister said that this should be increased but people are busy and there is a degree of formality which might upset the unsophisticated Aboriginal people. I do not accept that proposition. They must be involved in the decision making which affects their region. Mining companies seldom do this. They are paternalistic by nature even with their own people-that is, the white people-so they will be more so with the Aboriginal people.

The employment and training of Aboriginals in the area is the only other aspect I wish to raise because we are running short of time. The Minister promised to comment on that when he is tabling the next Institute report. It is a pity that he cannot do it earlier. I invite him to put down a statement on the employment and training of Aboriginal people. There is plenty of material available. I have raised the different investigations that have been held. I have talked about them here before. Certainly, there is plenty of information available and we could have it. I know that there are other people who wish to speak so I will conclude on that point.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make some comments on the report of the Australian Institute of Aboriginal Studies concerning a uranium project for the period from 1 April 1981 to 30 September 1981 and on the statement put down by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume). The letter of presentation from Professor Colin Tatz on page 3 of the report indicates that this report was presented to the Minister on 12 October 1981. Again, we have a report which is at least six months old being presented to the Senate. I put it to the Minister that, in view of the amount of activity both in terms of mining and Aboriginal land rights which is taking place in the Alligator Rivers region, it is very important that the Parliament receive up to date information. When reports come into the Parliaament as late as this they are of limited use in keeping the Senate up to date with what is happening in the Alligator Rivers region. I would ask the Minister to ensure that in future the Senate receives these reports as soon as possible after the conclusion of the report period.
—They have to be printed. I have a logistics problem.

—I do not think that six months is required for printing. I ask the Minister to see whether we can have the reports more quickly. Otherwise, with the amount of activity that is going on, we do not know from reading this report today what is happening in the Aligator Rivers region. One of the most disturbing features highlighted by this report is the rising alarm among Aboriginal communities in the Alligator Rivers region about the effects on the physical environment of uranium mining. I draw the attention of the Senate to page 16 of the report where it states:

SPEECH.PARA: News of the Queensland Mines Limited spillage reached the Oenpelli community in August and Project staff report a high degree of concern, coupled with a low level of knowledge of detail. . . . The possible development of the Jabiluka and Koongarra deposits makes assurances about safety mechanisms and their operation of the utmost importance and urgency.
On page 58 the report goes on to state:

In the previous report the Committee stated with some confidence that 'there have been no contamination or other gross disturbances of the environment'. That confidence has been shaken in the light of the reported spillage at Nabarlek. . . . Aboriginal anxieties have now been expressed to the point where the Committee-and we believe, Government-cannot disassociate those facets of uranium mining from what have hitherto been seen as social impact factors.

Reports coming into my own office over the last few months confirm the distress and uncertainty being felt by many Aboriginal people and communities. I believe many Aboriginal communities, specifically those involved in the Jabiluka negotiations, feel themselves to be under intense pressure. Since this report was written, the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs has announced the granting of land rights to part of the Alligator Rivers land claim which includes 95 per cent of the Jabiluka project area. Last week the Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Anthony, gave the go ahead, subject to Aboriginal approval, for mining of the Jabiluka deposits. This has significantly increased the pressure on the traditional owners. I believe many of the traditional owners feel that they need more time and information before they can make a declaration on Jabiluka. On page 16 the report states:

To date Aborigines have had very little-and even then, poor quality-education on these matters. They complain of little or no communication on safety from those organisations responsible for monitoring the physical environment.

Another worrying factor related to the issue of education is consultation. The report expresses a certain amount of concern on page 45 at the relationship between the Northern Land Council, the umbrella organisations, Gagudju and Kunwinkjku, and the growing number of small unifunctional associations which have sprung up in the area. It is my concern that the Aboriginal people of the Alligator Rivers area are becoming confused at the myriad of organisations, both government and non-government, with which they have to deal. Some of the information from the Northern Territory suggests that the consultation process in some cases is in very real danger of breaking down. I urge the Minister to look into this situation and, if necessary, to do something about it. The report states on page 49:

Consultation and information flow continue to remain issues of concern. Even the most casual observer is aware of the tremendous pressures placed on individuals summoned to meetings convened in the name of consultation.

I endorse the view expressed by my colleague Senator Robertson that consultation needs to be something real and not a token exercise. Another area of concern is alcohol, which continues to be a major problem. The figure for alcohol-related arrests at Jabiru during the period of the report was an extremely high 211 in an area where the local Aboriginal population rarely exceeds 40. In the month of May alone there were three alcohol-related deaths among Aboriginals in the region. The report states that it is important that the project locate a full time staff member with a close watching brief on the Jabiru situation. I hope that the Minister has noted that the report states that the new proposal is impossible within existing staff resources.

In regard to employment and training, I have noted in earlier reports that the uranium mining in the Alligator Rivers area has brought almost no benefit to Aboriginal communities. This report points out that a working party to examine the question of Aboriginal employment in the mining industry with representatives from various government departments, the Northern Land Council and the Australian Institute of Aboriginal Studies has been establshed. I wish this working party well and I hope that it can suggest measures to effect an increase in Aboriginal employment in the mining industry. However, no progress in this area has yet occurred. The Minister promises to tell us more on this when he tables the next Institute report.

The report does have some progress to report in the solution of other matters of concern to Aboriginals emphasised in earlier reports. The issues of entry on to Aboriginal land and use of roads on Aboriginal land have become less contentious. I would like to commend the hard work carried out by the Uranium Impact Project Steering Committee team in preparing these reports. It does a very complex job with limited resources. I urge the Minister to take note of the numerous references throughout the report to important work that cannot be done because of limited staff resources. The Minister, on page 8 of his own statement , suggests that it is up to the Institute to undertake further reviews and further projects if it wants to do so. I am pleased to see that he would accord it that flexibility. However, if resources are unavailable the work cannot be done. I draw the Minister's attention to that truism.

The report states on page 17 that without additional funds provided by the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service and the Australian Institute of Criminology the project would not have been able to fulfil as much of its brief as it needs to. The report expresses its concern that few of the recommendations which have been made by various social impact reports have taken up. Despite the assurances in the Minister's speech that recommendations not implemented are under consideration, I am concerned that the recommendations of the social impact statement should not be ignored by the Government. I am not at all confident that all is well in what has become known as the uranium province. I urge the Minister to ensure that the rights of Aboriginal people in this area are protected.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The report draws attention, as the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume) has said, to the apparent insufficiency of information and education for Aboriginals on safety connected with uranium projects. However, in the statement the Minister has incorporated in Hansard we find mainly good intentions. On page 2 particularly we find paragraph after paragraph of good intentions. I am certainly not against good intentions. However, there seems to be in the statement very little regard to the need to breach cultural differences and to provide that information within the framework of the Aboriginal communities themselves, rather than to use methods appropriate to our more formal educational system. In this context I think that the inadequacy of the adult education facilities described in the report surely must be of great concern. The Minister mentioned that it is planned, after a considerable time, again to appoint an adult educator to Oenpelli. However, he did not comment on the report's suggestion about the appointment of a specialist educator in radiation and other mining impact problems. I hope that at some stage the Minister will make some comments on that . Neither does he refer to the suggestion on page 18 about a community-based radio station at Oenpelli.

SPEECH.PARA: The importance that the Australian Democrats place on such education in an informal, sensitive and continuous way, I believe, is borne out by the report's discussion of possible excessive amounts of information being imposed on Aboriginal communities and individuals. The Minister responded to that by making a statement that the Northern Land Council and the Northern Territory Chief Minister's office will research this problem. This seems to ignore the fact that there are already in the Northern Territory people and institutions with long years of experience in building positive relationships with Aboriginal people. I point to such agencies as those operated by the Uniting Church which surely could assist and could be immediately put to work in this process suggested by the report.

However, I believe that this point is linked with the need for appropriate induction processes for mining company employees, as is stressed in the report. To the extent that there is a shortage of people who can do this with the requisite sensitivity and knowledge, what does the Minister propose-there do not seem to be any comments on this-might be done to train more adult educators of the calibre and skill required? In other areas of this statement the Minister is able to say only that discussions are continuing, for example, on improvements to housing and banking facilities. Similar trends emerge-when he responds to specific recommendations of the Committee in these terms:
Induction programs are being examined . . . Language courses are under consideration . . . Increased Aboriginal involvement in decisions affecting their land are currently being examined.
So it goes on.

The recommendation that there should be a systematic comparison review of the various agreements between mining companies and Aboriginal groups receives not even token support. The Minister says that he cannot imagine the purpose of such action or who could do it. To us the purpose seems eminently clear. Mining companies are in a position to retain highly trained and expensive lawyers. It is simply a matter of equalising resources, surely, and if the Department is serious about its responsibilities to Aboriginal people one would expect a little more than a vague reference to the Northern Land Council in that regard.

The treatment of the next recommendation is even more offhand. The response is that the maintenance of a cultural heritage can be left to the Aboriginal people who are already doing it. I do not accept that that is a statement that the Minister really would support, given the types of things that he has said here in the past. Aboriginal culture and customs are under serious and continued threat from the relentless pressure that has been put on them by the white community; that is, the economic, social and legal systems of the majority culture. It seems that the battle of the Aboriginal people to preserve their own heritage before it is lost is something for which the white community also must have an intimate concern and that it must seek to provide safeguards and assistance to allow the Aboriginal people to have a fighting chance.

The Minister is certainly correct in saying that mining has provided the Aboriginal people with the financial resources which might give them a degree of independence from government funding and presence. We certainly hope that may be the case. However, an off-handed proposition seems to have been put that this should be coupled in some way with our willingness to withdraw. Certainly, we ought to have a willingness to withdraw, but in a way which gives the Aboriginal people a reasonable chance to establish their independence and their culture in a continuing and progressive manner. We hope that, in subsequent statements on these reports-we certainly commend the Minister and the Government for their previous initiatives in this regard and for the fact that we do have such reports-the recommendations may be treated in a more in-depth fashion and that we may, indeed, have more time in which to debate what is a very serious matter. I am sure that the Minister shares our wish that that will take place. Because the Government wishes to bring on some business now, I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Messner) agreed to:

That, notwithstanding anything contained in the Sessional Orders for the remainder of this day, the sitting of the Senate be suspended from 6 p.m. to 8 p .m. and the Sessional Order in relation to the adjournment take effect at 10.30 p.m.
Motion (by Senator Messner) agreed to:
That, unless otherwise ordered, the Senate, at its rising, adjourn until Tuesday, 20 April 1982 at 1.45 p.m.
Reference to Standing Committee on Education and the Arts

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the following matter be referred to the Standing Committee on Education and the Arts:
The development and implementation of a co-ordinated language policy for Australia.

I regard this reference as important to the current and continuing pattern of decisions of this Parliament and the reference is of very considerable national significance. There has never before been such a unifying inquiry into national language policy, nor has there been such a study of Australia as a multicultural society. The Senate Committee on Education and the Arts is, I believe, particularly well placed now to undertake it. Whilst the particular words of the motion precisely describe the reference to be directed to the Committee, there is merit also in indicating some of the aspects that may be involved in this inquiry.

Without committing the Committee to these exact terms I envisage the reference may include the following ten aspects: (a) All aspects of, including guidelines for, a national language policy; (b) the role of English as a first and second language and its relationship to other languages in Australia; (c) the present use of languages in Australia including use in the community, in the media- including newspapers, ethnic radio and multicultural television-and in the arts and to extend equality of access to services and to the institutions of Australian society; and (d) the particular requirements arising from the community and educational use of Aboriginal languages.
I seek leave to have the remainder of my speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The remainder of the speech read as follows-
(e) the current state of, and trends in, language teaching and learning in primary and secondary schools, tertiary education and other formal and informal programs in the community;
(f) the extent to which existing policies, practices, attitudes, resource allocations and programs are adequate to provide for the appropriate development of Australia's language resources;

(g) the language requirements in Australia necessary for trade, diplomacy, defence, tourism and cultural exchange especially taking into account Australia' s regional and other international relationships;
(h) the special language needs of the deaf and other persons with disabilities;
(i) the ways and means of stimulating continuing public awareness of and interest in the development of Australia's language resources;
(j) arrangements for the on-going implementation of a national language policy including the identification of priorities and the allocation of resources.

By setting out these points it is my intention to provide some clarification of what is intended by this reference. In particular, I hope this will allow interested groups in the Australian public to have a substantial period to begin any preparations of their own which they may see helpful towards developing submissions eventually to be given to the Committee once the conduct of the inquiry is underway.

I want also to add that it is not at this stage possible to indicate when advertisements could be placed in newspapers calling for submissions but these advertisements will not appear before June or July this year. Nor is it envisaged that public hearings could begin until the final quarter of this year. The Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts is at present fully engaged in its enquiry into 'Tenure of employment of Academics in Australian Universities and Colleges', and for this reason the Committee will not be able to add to the indications which I am able to make in these introductory remarks. Accordingly any question directed to the Committee over the next three months will be met simply by the circulation of general remarks such as I am now making here in the Senate. It will only be when this reference is publicly advertised in newspapers that the particular definitions of the inquiry will be confirmed and on that basis public submissions would then be called.
I warmly commend the motion to the Senate.
Sitting suspended from 6 to 8 p.m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Grimes moving a motion concerning the posting of leaflets by the Department of Social Security on behalf of the Victorian Government for election purposes.

I do this because today, and in the last two days, the Department of Social Security in sending out pension cheques to pensioners in Victoria has enclosed a document entitled 'Benefits for pensioners from the Victorian Goverment'. The content of this document is written as a message to Victoria's pensioners and is signed Lindsay Thompson, the Premier and Treasurer of Victoria. It continues to give a list of what is purported to be the benefits available to pensioners in Victoria from the Victorian Government. It advises them to seek further information from another pamphlet. I do not wish to canvass the matter. I believe that this is a serious breach of normal proprieties before election time and I believe that the Senate should debate this matter. Therefore, I move that Standing Orders be suspended so that we can properly discuss the matter and so that I can put my case and the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) can , in fact, reply.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government opposes the suspension of Standing Orders. The Senate laid down its business for the day by a motion earlier today. The Government does not accept that the matter is one which is urgent in the terms of Standing Order 448. The material which is referred to by the honourable senator, and which is not to be canvassed in the debate on this motion, is material which was arranged to be sent on an administrative basis. It was not a decision made politically or by the political arm of the government and there is no substance in the suggestion that the matter needs to be debated this evening. For that reason the Government opposes the motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —This places the Australian Democrats in a difficult position. Senator Grimes came to me earlier in the day alleging that 100,000 or thereabouts pieces of paper had been printed and produced by the Victorian Department of Community Welfare Services and that they had been enclosed with pension cheques mailed out by the Federal Department of Social Security presumably last night. Senator Grimes and Senator Button did not have a copy of the paper. The piece of paper purported to indicate to Victorian pensioners the various benefits available to them from the Victorian Department of Community Welfare Services. On that information, which is totally hearsay to me-I am the only member of my party who has been spoken to about it to my knowledge-prima facie it is a very serious case. The mail of the Commonwealth, and the facilities of the Commonwealth Government Department, have been used for blatant electioneering in a State election; I am saying that prima facie that is the case.

SPEECH.PARA: I was phoned about two minutes to eight by a member of Senator Chaney's staff, quite properly, to ask what attitude the Australian Democrats would have towards a motion for the suspension of Standing Orders. Senator Chaney's staff understood that Senator Grimes was to have moved for the suspension of Standing Orders at 8 o'clock. I immediately asked my colleagues to come into the chamber to hear the debate. I asked the Democrat Whip, Senator Macklin, to confer with the Australian Labor Party Whip, Senator Robertson, who stated he knew nothing about when the proposal was coming forward. Senator Macklin said to me: 'This sounds an interesting proposition. Would it not be better to get the papers out of the way at 8.26 and have a debate on it then?' The two Whips, Senator Robertson and Senator Macklin, were in the process of walking out of the chamber to discuss this matter in Senator Robertson's office when Senator Grimes came to the table and moved for the suspension of Standing Orders. As I stand here--

TALK.START.PARA: —I was trying to explain the position to you.
—Exactly. We were both beaten by time. As I stand here now, no member of my party has seen the alleged piece of paper.
—They should have. I apologise. They should have.
—Senator Grimes interjects: 'They should have'. Mr Deputy President, with your indulgence, I ask him: How should we have?
—He is apologising.

—This can be inflamed into a big issue. It would need no assistance from Senator Teague for this issue to be discussed sensibly. If Senator Grimes has real evidence, a real piece of paper, we would be most interested to see it and we would be persuaded to vote for it. How can we, as responsible senators, vote for a motion when we have no evidence before us? At this stage I suggest to Senator Grimes that he can do one of two things: He can seek leave to withdraw his motion and allow us the courtesy of seeing the evidence he has; or he can proceed with this vote now the Democrats have no alternative but to vote against the motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I apologise to Senator Chipp if he did not receive the document. I understood that he would have. I accept full responsibility for the fact that he did not. I point out that I, like any other honourable senator, can move for the suspension of the Standing Orders in this place to bring up a matter such as this. I have other means available to do so; for instance, the adjourment debate tonight. I am surprised that Senator Chipp has not seen the document. It has been distributed widely around the Parliament tonight. One of the usual snafus has happened, namely, the one person who should see it has not seen it. I accept that.
—We would like to see your document; that is all.

—Of course Government members have not seen it because they were not told about it. They would not be shown anything as ridiculous as this document, a political document which is worse even than the sort of nonsense that went out in the electorate of Lowe before the last election. This pamphlet has been paid for by the Victorian Government and, therefore, the Victorian taxpayers. The postage has been paid by the Department of Social Security, which is Senator Chaney's Department, and he is obviously trying to silence debate.

—I raise a point of order. We are debating a motion for the suspension of Standing Orders, which debate should be relevant to the question of whether there is a matter of urgency which, in terms of Standing Order 448, gives rise to an urgent necessity and requires the Standing Orders to be suspended. In fact, Senator Grimes is canvassing the matters which he wishes to put before the Senate. I suggest he should be asked to respond to the points which have been made in debate. He is replying to a debate on the question of the suspension of Standing Orders.
—Senator Grimes, I suggest you take into account the matters raised by Senator Chaney. I think it is a fact that Senator Grimes was responding to interjections.

—I accept that. As you say, Mr Deputy President, I was responding to interjections from Government senators. If they do not want them responded to I suggest they should not interject. What has happened, in fact, is that I have moved for the suspension of Standing Orders, as Senator Chaney says, because this is a matter of urgency and because this is a matter that needs to be dealt with tonight. Firstly, it is a matter of urgency because it happened only in the last day or so and it was drawn to the attention of members of this Parliament only today. Secondly, it needs to be dealt with tonight because, as Senator Missen and his colleagues know, the Parliament rises tonight and does not meet for three weeks.

SPEECH.PARA: Thirdly, I believe it is a matter which should be debated tonight because the Victorian election will occur in those three weeks. I believe that the duplicity , the political ineptitude and the gross attempt to buy votes by the Premier of Victoria, associated with the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney), deserve exposure in this House tonight.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. Senator Grimes persists in endeavouring to talk on the issue itself. He is also now attacking the Premier of a State in a highly abusive fashion. This is while speaking to the motion that Standing Orders be suspended. I submit that there is no basis for that and that he should be ruled out of order.
—Senator Grimes, I ask you to restrict your remarks to the motion for the suspension of Standing Orders and your reply to the debate that has taken place.

—Mr Deputy President, with respect, I was giving the reasons for the suspension of Standing Orders. Standing Orders provide that I should demonstrate why the matter is urgent and why it is necessary to debate the matter tonight. I repeat: It is urgent because this is a matter that has just arisen. It is necessary to deal with the matter tonight because after tonight we will not have the opportunity. Of course, I realise that I can rise, if this motion is defeated, on the adjournment tonight to air the matter. But I believe it is an issue of such importance that the Senate should debate it now. Senator Chaney is the one honourable senator in this chamber who objects to people raising matters at what he calls the dead of night; in other words, on the adjournment. I am trying to bring the matter on for debate at 8 o'clock because that is a reasonable hour when we can have a rational debate. I believe that I have given a prima facie case that in fact that document did go out and was distributed by the Department of Social Security. Therefore, it is necessary to debate it now. They are the clear reasons I have given. I assure Senator Missen that any irascible comments I have made were in response to his interjections.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-In the last 30 seconds I have received a photostat copy of the document to which Senator Grimes referred. Since the only objection that Senator Chipp had to supporting the suspension of Standing Orders was that none of us had in fact seen the document or a facsimile of it, the fact that we have now seen this document changes the situation. We are prepared to support Senator Grimes in his move for a suspension of Standing Orders.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the motion (Senator Grimes's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.DATA.PARA: (The Deputy President-Senator the Honourable Douglas McClelland)

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —There being 28 ayes and 26 noes and as the motion has not received an absolute majority I declare the question resolved in the negative.

DEBATE.TITLE: COMMONWEALTH SCIENTIFIC AND INDUSTRIAL RESEACH ORGANISATION

PROCTEXT.PARA: Annual Report 1980-81
Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats take the opportunity of the presentation of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation annual report for 1980-81 to look with some jaundice at the Government's apparent withdrawal, as demonstrated in this report, from research into renewable energy resources, especially solar and wind power. One has to read well into this report to find out that what I say is the case. In the early part of the report soothing generalities indicate that all is well. Renewable energy resources will get their share of attention, funding and staff. For instance, on page 30 it is stated:

SPEECH.PARA: A working party's study has led to the identification of six areas of energy research appropriate to an expanded CSIRO effort in accord with the high priority afforded by the Executive to this aspect of its activities.

One of the six areas is renewable energy. From there I turn to page 33 of the report where again I find a list of renewable energy areas which are broad goals for CSIRO, including solar conversion, solar energy research, solar engineering units, solar energy storage, wind energy, and renewable energy resources engineering. So far so good. As one gets deeper and deeper into this document one finds the picture beginning to change. At page 110 the report states:
That the overall level of activity in energy R & D by CSIRO should certainly be maintained, and, if possible, increased, perhaps by internal redeployment of resources.
Turning to page 114 of the report, what do we find? We find this bald statement:
Under the heading 'Wind Energy', the Committee concluded that CSIRO's resources could be more effectively deployed elsewhere.
The Executive of CSIRO agrees. A little further on, on page 115, the report states:

Under the heading 'Solar Energy', the Committee concluded that resources presently devoted to large-scale solar engineering, photochemical solar energy storage and low energy greenhouses could now be deployed more appropriately on other energy programs. The Executive agrees.

We have a change of statement which we find most peculiar. What is happening? The Executive of CSIRO has apparently decided that its Organisation no longer needs to concern itself with renewable energy research. In the light or darkness of the present energy crisis in New South Wales and the Australian Capital Territory, and the predicted energy crisis in Victoria, this seems to us to be an extremely foolish decision.

What is now happening in CSIRO with regard to renewable energy research? My understanding is that most solar and wind energy research was carried out in the division of mechanical engineering. This was closed down on 1 September 1981 and a new division of energy technology was created. This new division does work similar to that done by the division of mechanical engineering except that now almost no work is done on solar energy, wind energy or biomass. The one person who worked full time on wind energy in the old division was told that he would be working full time on fossil fuel research in the new division. This was until the leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) in the other place put questions on the Notice Paper regarding renewable energy research in CSIRO. I understand that the person in CSIRO was told that he would be able to spend 25 per cent of his time on wind energy research. That is not much time but it is enough for Mr Hayden to be truthfully answered that someone is still working on wind energy research. That represents one quarter of a person.

This can be contrasted to a world scene in which solar and wind generators in the megawatt range have been operating successfully for some years in Europe, the United States of America and Japan. It is now estimated that the United States gets 7 per cent of all its energy needs from renewable resources, mostly from government-encouraged and subsidised passive solar heating facilities in homes and other buildings. The Southern California Edison company, one of the major electrical generating companies in the United States, and private enterprise, has dedicated itself to providing one third of its future additional generating capacity from renewable means. Its first major solar power station- Solar One-is now complete and ready to contribute not minuscule amounts of power but ten megawatts to the state grid. It uses 1800 mirrors to concentrate the sun 's rays on a boiler, the resulting steam being used to power conventional turbines.

Hawaii plans to generate 9 per cent of its total electricity needs from wind power by 1985 and is engaged in a wind farm project in which 20 machines will not provide minuscule amounts of power but 80 megawatts of power. That is almost half of what is proposed for the new billion dollar dam in South West Tasmania. These things are going on throughout the world. This is an established technology and instead of advancing within it we are retreating from it. In Australia, one of the world's most favourable locations for solar and wind power , we are persisting in a Rip van Winkle mentality in which our government and scientists at the policy level-because of stress at the policy level; other scientists are keen enough-seem determined to live in the past. No doubt this is an attitude which makes it possible for them to indulge in the comfortable state of learning nothing, considering nothing, and doing nothing.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Annual Report 1980-81

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I wish to raise a matter about which I have spoken before in the Senate. It is relevant as the next Budget is being considered. I want to make clear my view that there should be only one body in Australia responsible for the distribution of funds to arts bodies. That body is the Australia Council. As it states in its annual report, there are areas in the arts over which it has no control. The overall funding for the arts is a right and proper decision for the Federal Government but the method of distribution should be left to the Australia Council. It is not a job for Cabinet or the Federal Government.

The report makes it clear that it is not true to say that there was no increase in funding for the arts this financial year. In fact there has been an 11.2 per cent increase over the 1980-81 figure. These funds are being given in a rather eccentric fashion. There has been a 35 per cent increase in funding to the Australian National Gallery, a 10.3 per cent increase to the National Institute of Dramatic Arts, a 10 per cent increase to the Elizabethan Trust orchestras, the Australian Ballet and the Australian Opera and a 4.8 per cent increase to the Australian Film and Television School. These increases are offset by the fact that there has been no increase in the funds available to the Australia Council for general support for the arts, funds that go to most arts bodies in Australia. Worse still, because the cost of administration of the Australia Council, due to salary rises, rose by 10 per cent this year over last year it now amounts to $4.3m-the amount available for distribution to arts bodies has decreased in money terms, even allowing for the $800,000 supplementary grant made late last year. Of course this has created very real problems for most arts bodies.

What I think is disturbing in the arts community is the way in which particular bodies, the opera, ballet and trust orchestras, are singled out for direct funding by Cabinet-they get a substantial increase to keep pace with inflation- while all the other arts bodies get a sharp decrease in real terms. These individual votes are ultimately decided by Cabinet. I do not think this is an acceptable version of the arm's length system of administering the arts which is supposed to have been adopted here as well as in other countries. In my view the Government should decide the total amount available for the arts and leave it to the Australia Council-a body of experts set up for the purpose of developing policy-to decide the actual distribution of grants between the many competing applicants. This I think is essential. Cabinet neither is qualified to nor has it the time to make these grants. Worse still, it is terrible politics. People in ministerial positions tend to fancy themselves as latter-day Medicis, but making arts grants is very unrewarding politically. For every friend that one makes with a grant one makes 10 enemies among these people who did not get a grant but thought that they ought to have. It is important both for political reasons and for the proper administration of the arts that the Government should delegate to the Australia Council the full responsibility for distributing the funds made available to it by the Government. It will make the decisions and it will take any resentment from the arts community. That is a proper role for it. It is qualified for it and that is how we should leave it. The decision should be made by those having specialist knowledge of the art forms. That is the platform of the Liberal Party and it is a policy I think we should adhere to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australia Council 1981 annual report is about six months late. Perhaps the Government could explain to the Parliament why it is late. The report again reflects the difficulties that the Council has encountered in trying to maintain and develop its activities in the context of shrinking government support. On page 9 the report states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Council, like many other organisations in the current economic climate, is under pressure. It is facing increasing difficulty in supporting the many valuable and exciting initiatives brought before it, ranging from assistance for larger organisations to direct grants to individuals. The practical effects of financial stringencies have been visible in, for example, the awarding of fewer literary fellowships-down from 76 . . . in 1976-77 to 49 . . .

In real terms the Australia Council's funding has declined significantly over the last 6 1/2 years of the Fraser Government. That decline has been evident in all areas of the activity of the Australia Council. It has been evident also in the funding available to the Australian Opera, the Australian Ballet and the Australian Elizabethan Theatre Trust orchestras although, of course, I express the view that I think Senator Hamer was expressing when I came into the chamber that allocations to these organisations ought to be carried out by the Australia Council just as allocations to all other arts organisations and individuals are made.

During 1980-81 cuts in funding precipitated a crisis in the performing arts in Australia. The Council was forced to make an unpalatable choice of either allowing the erosion of support to individual artists to continue or to cut funding for the performing arts. It chose the latter and funds for a wide range of performing companies were cut. The Government knows what the effects of this action were. For a time it seemed that several theatre companies would close. Australian actors, writers and performers mobilised. Rallies were held around Australia on a day called Stage Crisis Day and a delegation of prominent Australian actors and writers came to Canberra to lobby with Government members for their case. It is a case which the Australian Labor Party believes is wholly justified.

As this annual report points out on page 9, Commonwealth Government support through the Australia Council represents only 20 per cent on average of the income of arts organisations. I think it ought to be stressed that artists and performing companies are not asking for handouts from government. They are seeking a level of subsidy which allows their entrepreneurial, economically productive activities to go on. Certainly, those involved in, for example, resource development or manufacturing industry or agriculture are not shy about asking for subsidies. They are not shy about asking for taxation concessions or infrastructure assistance. The Government has not been reluctant to grant assistance to these forms of economic activity. The arts, however, have an even stronger claim on public funds because of their contribution to the individual and commercial development of the nation, to our national image abroad and, of course, to the creation of employment.

Certainly, after the lobbying exercises by arts workers the Government made an additional allocation available to the Australia Council. The Government granted it an additional $809,000 late last year. However, it ought to be pointed out that $500,000 of the additional allocation was earmarked to reinforce the challenge grant scheme under which the Government agreed to grant $1 for every extra $3 raised by arts bodies from private enterprise. What this means, of course, is that unless private enterprise is forthcoming the Federal allocation set aside for matching private donations may not even be spent. It means also that money will go to those companies which are the most successful in raising funds privately rather than to those companies or individuals that have most need of it.

I put the Government on notice that the Labor Party does not believe that the Commonwealth Government's responsibility for arts funding can be shunted off to private enterprise. It is essential to maintain an adequate level of public subsidy to the arts. The fact that the level of support provided by the current government is inadequate is reflected throughout this report. I make it clear to the Government also that the Labor Party believes-as do some Government senators , particularly Senator Hamer-that all government subsidies for performing art companies should go through the Australia Council.

TALK.START.PARA: —All arts, not just the performing arts.

—Yes. While the so-called flagship companies-that is the Australian Opera and the Australian Ballet-provide high standards I point to the great success of other less traditional Australian performing companies such as the Sydney Dance Company or the Flying Fruit Fly Circus. These groups also achieve excellence and international recognition in their fields. They ought to be treated on an equal basis in terms of funding decisions with the opera and the ballet. Of course, in line with this philosophy I should point out that the Labor Party does not support an idea advocated by the current Minister responsible for the arts, the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, Mr Wilson; that is, the formation of a third national company, or flagship, as the Government likes to call it, in the form of a national drama company.

SPEECH.PARA: The Labor Party has reservations about the restructuring of the Australia Council which has been carried out recently. It seems to me that the restructuring will have the effect of centralising the administration, which could lead to-this is where we have reservations-a diminishing of the role of boards. Of course, their role has already been diminished through previous government changes to the Council. The recent reorganisation of the Australia Council was carried out without consultation with the arts community. For that reason alone I think we have to have reservations about its appropriateness. Bearing in mind the Council's statement of purpose on page 4 of its annual report, I believe that it is essential that the arts community be consulted on all major decisions affecting them. Part of the reason for the restructuring is to save money. It is a great shame that decisions such as these have to be made not on the grounds that they would bring benefit to the arts community but simply on the grounds of reducing expenditure.

The Council's report highlights the greater emphasis being placed on international activities and cultural exchange. I believe that most Australians would welcome such a move. I only regret that here again Budget cuts are limiting the Council's effectiveness. On page 13 the report states:

The stringent limits imposed by the Government's Overseas Visits Committee on trips abroad by Council representatives-only four visits were approved in 1980- 81-seriously impair the Council's ability to meet its international obligations.

I draw to the Council's attention a belief held by many artists in the Aboriginal community that their unique contribution to Australian culture is not being fully recognised. For example, I understand that two visiting Bulgarian poets who were guests at the Adelaide Festival recently stated publicly that they would have dearly loved the opportunity to meet Aboriginal writers and musicians while they were in Australia but they were not given the chance. I ask the Australia Council to ensure that the Aboriginal contribution to cultural exchange is not ignored in the future.

Other concerns expressed in the report which deserve comment are the inadequacy of training programs for artists and arts administrators, and concerns about the standards of governance of many Australian arts companies. There is not this evening the time to go into these areas except to say that they are concerns shared by the Labor Party.

Finally, I should like to acknowledge the fact that during the period covered by this annual report Professor Geoffrey Blainey finished his four-year term of appointment as the Chairman of the Australia Council. I should like to add my congratulations to Professor Blainey for the contribution he made to arts in Australia. I think the reviews of various activities by the Council which Professor Blainey instigated have been very useful and constructive in making availble to the Council information as to how Council can better pursue its objectives. I also note that during the course of the period covered by this report two outstanding board chairmen retired. I refer to Dr Bob Brissenden, who had been Chairman of the Literature Board, and Brian Sweeney, Chairman of the Theatre Board. I should also like to congratulate those two chairmen on the excellent work they carried out for theatre and literature during the period they were chairmen. It is no coincidence that the activities both of the Theatre board and of the Literature Board during that time have borne fruit in the success of the Australian film industry of which we are all so proud. My time has almost elapsed so I must finish my comments at this point.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: OECD: MANPOWER AND SOCIAL AFFAIRS COMMITTEE

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Text of Statement by Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator WALSH

TALK.START.PARA: —(Western Australia) (8.41)-I move:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

A good deal of the 10-page statement by the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs (Mr N. A. Brown) is devoted to the need for moderation in wage claims in order to prevent inflation soaring, with the consequential damage that it will do to economic growth and employment. We might well ask: 'What economic growth?' I will leave that matter for the present. What ought to be done, and what will be done by a Labor Government sometime within the next 18 months, is that employment and economic growth will be stimulated by more expansion in fiscal and monetary policies. It is true, I believe, that if that were done in isolation, inflation would very likely soar and the Government which resided over those circumstances would probably not survive the next election.

What a Labor Government will do, and only a Labor Government can do, is reach a national consensus and give leadership for a national consensus on a prices and incomes policy, something which is absolutely essential to stimulating economic growth and therefore reducing unemployment with acceptable rates of inflation. Because a Commonwealth government has almost no coercive power in the area of prices and incomes or social contract, or whatever one likes to call it, necessarily, such a policy rests upon consensus, and to achieve a consensus a government must have moral authority. Moral authority is precisely what this Government does not have and cannot ever have. How, for example, could any government, the Deputy Prime Minister of which still holds a 4 3/4 per cent housing loan, a government in which the Prime Minister's wife and her relatives have public finance at 4 1/2 per cent and a government which only last year established the conditions under which any person with a high off-farm income and a significant farming income may borrow $15,000 for two years, lend $10,000 for one year and receive a $4,500 cash bonus, half of which is free of tax, have any moral authority? Anyone who meets those requirements, and half the Fraser Cabinet meets those requirements, is able to do that through the income equalisation deposit scheme. Such a government, so tarnished by the self- interested actions of its own Ministers, cannot ever hope to have any moral authority.

The other point upon which I wish to touch briefly is this: The early part of the statement of the Minister is replete, as usual, with lies and wishful thinking about how relatively well the economy is going and how successful the Fraser Government has been in economic management. For example, on page 3 of his statement the Minister said:
Australia is on the right track in creating the conditions for reduction in unemployment.

That is patent nonsense. It is, however, consistent with such assertions as the one taken from the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development Survey , Australia, released in January 1982 which states:
Since 1978, real GDP has increased at more than twice the average rate for the OECD area as a whole . . .

Of course in the remainder of that OECD Economic Outlook, No. 30, of December 1981 the statistics actually show that in the 30 months from December 1978 to June 1981, the most recently available statistics, real gross domestic product in Australia increased by 7.1 per cent and in the OECD as a whole by 6 per cent. As I remarked yesterday, even the typical Country Party back bencher should realise that 7.1 is not more than double six. I received a complaint by way of letter today from Mr Stone, the Secretary to the Treasury, regarding the question which was asked on that matter yesterday and subsequent interjections. I do not have time to go into the substance of that matter now. I replied to Mr Stone by letter and I shall be releasing both Mr Stone's letter and my reply in the near future.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 11 March 1982 on motion by Senator Evans:
That the Senate take note of the paper.
Upon which Senator Sibraa had moved by way of amendment:
That all words after 'that' be omitted and the following substituted in place thereof:
(1) The Senate refer to the Joint Parliamentary Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence as a matter of urgency the following matters:
(a) The relevance of an aircraft carrier to Australia's current and perceived strategic environment;
(b) The role of an aircraft carrier in the Defence Force structure of Australia ;
(c) The effects of the purchase of an aircraft carrier on the future defence procurement program;
(2) The Committee be requested to report not later than 1 September 1982.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are considering a motion relating to the ministerial statement on the purchase of HMS Invincible to which Senator Sibraa has moved an amendment to refer a number of matters to the Joint Parliamentary Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence, namely the relevance of an aircraft carrier to Australia's current and perceived strategic environment, the role of an aircraft carrier in the Defence Force structure of Australia and the effects of the purchase of an aircraft carrier on the future defence procurement program . As the thrust of such an amendment is critical of the decision to acquire HMS Invincible and also of the strategic need for it, I will make a few comments, firstly, on the strategic situation; secondly, on the role of an aircraft carrier and HMS Invincible in particular in that role; and, finally, the suitability of the proposal by Senator Sibraa to refer the matter to a joint parliamentary committee.

SPEECH.PARA: We have to look at what our strategic requirements are. Too often, we have looked at what other people's strategic requirements are. In our forward defence planning we must look at what are the requirements for Australia. It is clear to me that there are four areas of strategic requirement for this country. The first is that we have a very great interest in the prevention of a global nuclear war. Whether we are a target or not, such a war would destroy civilisation as we know it. It must be our policy to do what we can to deter the outbreak of such a war. That is the justification, and the only justification, for our having joint communication facilities for operations with submarines in the North West Cape and joint facilities in Central Australia. Their role is to deter the outbreak of a global nuclear war and they are justified because it is in Australia's interest that such a war should be deterred. The Defence Force has no relevance to such a task although it might possibly have relevance in the aftermath of such a war.

The second strategic requirement we have is to defend our sea communications. We are one of the great overseas trading nations of the world. Virtually all our overseas trade is carried in ships and 95 per cent is carried in foreign flagships. We have also a considerable coastal trade. On a ton-mile basis, half our interstate trade is carried by sea in Australian flagships. Although some people manage to do it, I cannot conceive of a global non-nuclear war in which there will be submarine and aircraft attacks on sea communications. That does not seem credible to me. The manifest inability of the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation powers to defend the sea communications of the Atlantic makes it quite certain that if such a war broke out it would inevitably escalate into a nuclear war. So I do not see our requirement as being to defend sea communications in a worldwide war in which they are attacked. Nor do I see, even in a limited bilateral war between Australia and some other regional power, that our overseas trade would be seriously threatened because virtually all of it-95 per cent, as I said-is carried in foreign flagships, nearly all of which would be neutral. It would seem a very provocative and unnecessary action by a bilateral enemy of ours to attack neutral shipping. What our enemies would do, I think without doubt, if they had the capability would be to attack our coastal trade and certainly any military convoys we used. With our communications system and our defence needs as such we would have to have a substantial amount of movement by sea of military stores and men. They would be vulnerable to attack in the event of a bilateral war.
