The third strategic requirement that we have is to defend our territorial integrity. We do not want anyone else's territory but we have a right and a determination to defend what we have. Our country is under no immediate or even foreseeable external threat, but we must have in this country the military infrastructure by which we can build up the necessary defence forces in the time scale in which such a threat might arise. That, of course, is the argument for having the Army Reserve and comparable forces in the other services. But I think we should make it quite clear that we have in this country a wonderful strategic shield. While the archipelago of islands to our north is firmly held in friendly hands, there is no possible way in which an invasion of this country could be mounted. So it must be the first objective of our foreign policy and our defence policy to see that that island chain to our north, our strategic shield, remains firmly held in friendly hands. Our Defence Force must be equipped, if necessary, to intervene in those areas. Whether we want to intervene in particular circumstances will depend on those circumstances. But it must be an option available to the Government, otherwise the Defence Force is failing in its duty and its structure.

I give one example of when the Defence Force, which at the time was structured mainly as a component of allied forces, could not carry out a role it should have been able to carry out. During the period of the Whitlam Government, Australia was still responsible for the defence of Papua New Guinea and its internal security. You may remember, Mr Deputy President, that the island of Bougainville was in a state of near secession. The chiefs of staff at that time were asked whether, if we wished to put a battalion into Bougainville, we could do it. The answer they gave, perfectly properly, was that we had no amphibious assault capability or airborne assault capability. They said that we could put a battalion in but only if the airfield were firmly held in friendly hands. As it turned out, they did not need to put troops into Bougainville but they might have done. We must have a Defence Force that is capable of doing the things Australia might have to do on its own. That must be the guiding light of our Defence Force. That is shifting. I gave an example of where it failed and I will come later to the way in which an aircraft carrier fits into that role.

The final strategic requirement we have is that we must be able to defend and police our exclusive economic zone. We have declared the area 200 nautical miles around Australia, which is nearly as big as the whole continent of Australia. If we claim it we must be able to police it and, if necessary, deal with anyone who enters it without our permission. This is, at the moment, not a role for the Defence Force although it does assist. Sooner or later-the sooner the better-it will have to be taken over by the Defence Force and done properly. As I said, we must structure our Defence Force so that we are able to do the things we might have to do on our own without United States assistance, in particular. We must also, when looking at major equipments, be prepared to look 20 years ahead because major equipments such as HMS Invincible and the F18s will remain in service well into the next century. We must look ahead. We cannot look backwards .

How does a carrier fit in with those strategic requirements? Its first role is the defence of shipping and it contributes in two significant ways. The first threat that it might have to counter would probably be a threat from patrol boats firing missiles at our shipping. The carrier, by extending its radius by helicopters or possibly fixed wing aircraft well over the horizon, can probably counter patrol boats before they get into missile firing range. This is a very important defensive part of an operation of this type. Secondly, it is very important in the defence of our shipping against submarines, which, as I said earlier, could comprise our coastal shipping or our military convoys.

Some rather extraordinary remarks have been made in the Senate about anti- submarine warfare. I will just take a little time to explain how ships are defended against submarine attack. I think in the time scale that we are looking at-20 years ahead-we can reasonably assume that all the submarines which we are trying to counter will be diesel-electric submarines. They use their electric batteries when fully submerged and their diesels, for which they have to put an exhaust and an intake mast above the surface, to recharge their batteries and to give themselves mobility. Their range on batteries alone is extremely limited- only a couple of hundred miles. I do not think there is any likelihood in this time scale that any potential bilateral enemy, which is what I am talking about, is likely to have nuclear-powered submarines. There would be an entirely different problem if that arose. I will not deal with that because I think it is unlikely.

If one is trying to counter a diesel-electric submarine one has to look at its limitations. Dealing with this type of submarine is extraordinary like dealing with an insurgent war. I sometimes thought that if the Americans had had enough sense in Vietnam to put an experienced, anti-submarine warfare admiral in command of their insurgent operations they would have done a great deal better than they did with the generals they used. The parallels are irresistible. What one must do against diesel-electric submarines is, first of all, hamper their mobility. If one can fly aircraft patrols with radar over the area one will prevent them using diesel; they cannot recharge their batteries. One limits their mobility. If they get into an attack position one wants helicopters with sonar to detect the submarines in depth out from the convoy. Finally, one has ships which also provide sonar protection. All these have weapons too. The ships have the facilities for command and control to co-ordinate all the various elements of the defence against submarine attack.

Honourable senators can see how the various elements fit in. We use Orions or Trackers to harass the submarines, to restrict their mobility and to ensure that if they attack they do it in a low battery state. They are armed with sonobuoys which are very limited in capability. The development of sonobuoys has gone on more slowly than the development of quietness of submarines, but they have some limited use-they restrict the mobility of the submarine. As a localising device for attack they are almost valueless. They impose this hampering limit on the mobility of the submarine. That is the role of the fixed wing aircraft-whether carrier-based, in the case of HMAS Melbourne, or land-based. The helicopters necessarily have to be based on ships. The four FFGs which we are getting from America-two have arrived, two are under construction-can carry two helicopters each. They do not carry any at the moment. It is not clear yet what type of helicopters they are to be fitted with. Helicopters on escorts or destroyers are much more limited, both because of problems of maintenance and because they might become weather-bound in very heavy weather, than helicopters on a carrier. The role of the HMS Invincible, which could carry 22 or so helicopters, is obviously an enormous addition to the defensive power of this type of group.

The third type of attack, which I think is highly improbable, would be a sophisticated air attack with high performance aircraft using stand-off weapons. I do not think, in the scenario that I have painted, that is at all likely. If one wants to defend against that type of attack one has to go to something like an American carrier task group with a very large carrier, F14 aircraft with long range missiles, airborne early warning aircraft and electronic warfare aircraft. A carrier task force of that type is enormously powerful in defensive role but such a task force is well beyond our capability.

I come back to the point that I made initially: We must structure our defence force around the roles that we might have to perform on our own. That necessarily limits the war in terms of both scale and sophistication. If things are beyond our capability then we will have to rely on allies. Let us optimise our force for the things that we might have to do on our own. I think defence against this type of attack is not a thing which we could possibly cope with on our own. In any case, the Invincible would make a negligible contribution to that, except possibly with its jammers and its missiles. It would not be a significant contributor against that type of highly sophisticated attack. So much for the defence of shipping.

I turn to the other area which has received very little attention when people have talked about these ships-the problem of brush fire wars. I cited the possibility of intervention in Bougainville. I believe that in our strategic requirement we must have a capability to put relatively small forces into trouble areas. Normally, one would expect that there would be a request to the government concerned to act in co-operation with people in those areas. A mobile force, moved in fast in a few days, could be of enormous value in preventing troubles developing in our region that might in the long term erode our strategic situation. In the Invincible, which can carry a commando of troops, which has its own helicopters, which, if it is fitted with AV8Bs, will have a tactical strike capability-and in the HMAS Tobruk, which also carries about a commando of troops, vehicles and so on-we have the capability of having a mobile force which could, in my view, provide a very important element of our strategic requirements. It could not be used in that form without other support against highly sophisticated enemies. Probably the most important role of our Defence Force would not be operating in that sort of environment. In all our defence requirements we have to be quite clear about what sort of environment we are talking about. We do not want Rolls Royces to do a job that a Holden could do better. We must optimise our force for the role we think that it will perform. I think for this sort of role we need an Invincible type carrier which could provide a capability which could not be provided in any other way. This could be very significant in the defence of this country.

There have been a number of objections-firstly, to aircraft carriers in general and, secondly, to the Invincible in particular. I will deal with just a few of these. It is alleged that aircraft carriers are peculiarly vulnerable. I do not know why it is-I think it stems mainly from junior Royal Australian Air Force officers-but it has been a constant theme that aircraft carriers are particularly vulnerable. It was an article of faith among Air Force officers before the Second World War that an aircraft carrier could not possibly survive within range of shore-based bombing attack. One has only to look at the way in which the American Fifth Fleet dominated the Pacific and dominated shore-based Air Forces there to know that that was quite untrue. Just looking at this issue of vulnerability, over 200 aircraft carriers were operated by both sides in the Second World War. In the six years of the Second World War the number sunk by shore-based bombing attack was one-one out of 200 in six years. These were the vessels that, in those days-the same sort of confident statements about their being vulnerable are being said now-we were told could not possibly survive in the face of shore-based bombing attacks. That is one aspect of vulnerability.

Aircraft carriers have been used in virtually all the wars since the Second World War. As we all know, wars have been going on almost continuously. Although they have provided irreplaceable tactical air power none has been sunk or damaged in the 35 years since the Second World War.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the Melbourne?

— HMAS Melbourne damaged herself; she was not damaged by the enemy. That is a different problem. Some people may say: 'Ah, but that is referring to old fashioned bombing attacks. What about sea-skimming missiles?' Senator Mason in particular made some quite extraordinary remarks about this problem. Those missiles are obviously a way that a sophisticated, well-equipped enemy would attack shipping. It would use missiles fired from long range-say, 40 or 50 miles-flying about 20 feet above the surface of the water. They are difficult to counter, but they are by no means invulnerable. Defence against that type of attack-as I explain, honourable senators will see where an aircraft carrier fits in-would be, first of all, to push the offensive force-it has to be airborne-out so that the enemy cannot get within launch range. This is possible and is relatively easy if the launch vehicle is a patrol boat. It cannot be done , of course, if the launch vehicle is a submarine. I think that in the environment which I have painted it is most unlikely that potential enemies would be launching this type of missile from submarines.

SPEECH.PARA: The second defence would be by using intercept sets, jammers and decoy launchers to ensure that the missiles launched by the enemy were rendered ineffective. This is what Churchill called the wizzard war. It depends a lot on factors such as how well we know the capabilities of the missiles, how effective our equipment is and how good our co-ordination is. That is where a ship such as the Invincible comes in. All the ships will have intercept sets, jammers and decoy launchers. Tight co-ordination is essential if that defence is to be efficient. That cannot be done from a small ship. It would not have the space or the equipment. At the moment the Australian Navy has no ship that can effectively co-ordinate defence against that type of attack. The Invincible can and does. That deals with the question of vulnerability.

The second matter that has been raised is that the aircraft carrier would not be available and what is the use of having just one. The first thing I should say is that an aircraft carrier, even while being overhauled, never goes beyond 48 hours notice for operations. Secondly, our intelligence would be very bad if we cannot predict the need a long way ahead. It is the job of intelligence forces to see that our forces are readied before the need arises. In the sort of eventualities that I am talking about, particularly in the brushfire war area, our intelligence should certainly be adequate to ensure that the ship is available when and where required.

The third objection to aircraft carriers-the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Hayden, was very eloquent on this-is that they need a large number of escorts to protect them. Mr Hayden managed, by counting the costs of the escorts, to get the bill for the Invincible up to $2,000m. This is a very perverse way of looking at a naval force. It is like looking at an Army division. It is similar to a proposal to re-equip the artillery and in the costs of the artillery one counts in the costs of the three brigades of infantry which are associated with divisional artillery. A naval task group normally operates a number of ships together. They are collectively offensive and defensive. The carrier adds very considerably to both the offensive and defensive capability of the force. If the aircraft carrier were not there a number of other ships would be required to replace its capability. In some cases it would be quite impossible to do so.

These more general objection to carriers have also turned into particular objections to the Invincible. I am glad that Senator Evans has come into the chamber because, when checking through the Hansard report, I saw some rather astonishing statements made by him in his earlier discussion on this motion. I wish to deal with them very briefly. I do not think that he quite thoroughly read his brief. Looking at the various objections to the Invincible in particular, the first relates to the cost of the ship. The cost of the ship-it has been quoted to us in pounds sterling and it depends on the exchange rate- looks like being about $300m sail-away. That would be less than the cost of a new FFG frigate from America and substantially less than the cost of such a ship built in Australia. We are getting the Invincible for less than the cost of a newly built frigate. When one considers the capability of the ship-it carries 22 helicopters alone whereas the frigate would carry two-one can see that it is not a high cost; it is a tremendous bargain.

TALK.START.PARA: —You know as well as we all do that it will cost much more than that.

—I said that it was the sail-away cost of the ship. I will come to the cost of the equipment in a moment. I am glad that Senator Evans interjected. It shows that he is paying attention. He made some rather odd remarks-I did not understand his second point-about the range being below our requirements. It is true that the present range of the Invincible for North Atlantic operation is below our staff requirement, but there is no difficulty in carrying an additional 450 tonnes of fuel which will bring it within the staff requirements which we lay down. That would cause a drop of something like half a knot in her speed which, by the way, is 31 knots, not 18 knots as Senator Mason seemed to believe. Senator Evans also said that the sea dart missile system in the Invincible was not inter-operate with Melbourne's old radar systems. I am sorry that he has left the chamber because no one could have possibly assumed that it was supposed to be. There is no way that the Melbourne's radar system would have been working with the sea dart of the Invincible. The Invincible's radar systems , I hasten to say, are perfectly adequate for the control and direction of her missile system.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Evans also made some rather odd remarks, which quite honestly I could not understand, about the IFF and navigation aids which were to be fitted in the ship. Having re-read his speech, I do not think that can make any sense at all. He also said that the radars in the Invincible would need changing if she were fitted with Sea Harriers. She is carrying Sea Harriers now and no change of radar is needed to operate those aircraft.

The next point for which the Invincible was criticised was that her accommodation was substandard. Senator Mason said this. As a matter of fact, that could not be more untrue. Her accommodation will be the most luxurious of any warship in the Australian Navy. It was also alleged that the ship was not air conditioned. That is just pure fantasy. It was further said-this is the sort of nonsense that has been said in what I thought was a thoroughly dishonest campaign to denigrate the ship-that her crew was 1,300. In fact it is 900, which is 300 less than the Melbourne. It was said that the ship was not compatible with our existing ships. Operationally there is no difficulty. She is fully compatible with all the other ships. The only ones with which she will not be compatible are the FFGs, which are being built in America, which initially will not be fitted with a data link so that their own internal automatic data system can link into other ships in the fleet. The Invincible will be capable of operating with all the other ships in the Australian Fleet. Those FFGs will be fitted when their American sister ships are so fitted and it will be done in the next year or so. The delay has nothing to do with the requirements of financial stringency. It is solely because the Americans have not yet decided which data link system to fit. When they decide our ships will be fitted. Logistically the ship will have some extra equipments which are not in current service with the Australian Navy. I do not think those will provide any great difficulties logistically.

Finally, I wish to refer to the question of whether this is a suitable subject to be considered by a parliamentary committee. Parliament here, under our Westminster system, traditionally does not interfere directly, unlike the American system, in the purchase of equipment. I think that is very much more satisfactory than the American system of parliamentary committees and the Senate making, in effect, equipment decisions because they do not have the information. Let us consider the problem of vulnerability about which people have been talking. Let us take one example-that is, the vulnerability to sea skimming missiles. One would have to know before one could decide whether a ship was vulnerable-there is no way that a parliamentary committee could ever be told this-what the performance and method of homing were, where were the sea skimming missiles, how effective the intercept sets were, how effective the jammers were and how effective the decoy systems were.

There is no way that a parliamentary committee with the best will in the world, and even if it were fully qualified for the subject, could possibly make useful judgments on such matters. I do not think that anything useful will come out of this proposed referral to the Joint Parliamentary Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence. Not only will nothing useful come out; it will also do active harm. Service morale is a thing about which this Parliament should be very concerned. There were difficulties with the Fleet Air Arm when the question of whether the Melbourne was to be replaced was in the air. The Government has now made a decision to replace the Melbourne, but for it to appear to the servicemen concerned, who have their careers to look to and their futures to consider, that the whole thing has been thrown back in the melting pot, I believe, will do a great disservice to the efficiency of our Defence Force. Therefore, I strongly recommend that this amendment be rejected.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will speak briefly in this debate on behalf of the Government because the Government is deeply concerned by the proposition that the decision which it made recently to go ahead with the purchase of the H.M.S. Invincible should be referred to a parliamentary committee with a view to reopening the whole question and, as Senator Hamer said, perhaps having some effect on the morale of the Royal Australian Navy in relation to such a major equipment purchase which the Government has decided upon. It certainly is a rather new development for it to be proposed to the parliament that matters of this kind, which are very much matters of expert and discussion and in relation to which, of course, a good deal of highly classified information is required to make a decision of this sort, should be brought into the arena of a parliamentary committee. For those reasons the Government believes that this amendment should be rejected by the Senate and hopes that it will be.

SPEECH.PARA: However, I would like to raise a few matters although I believe that Senator Hamer, in the valuable contribution that he made, dealt with most of the arguments that were raised against the decision by the Government. The Government, in considering this very important decision, gave very earnest and lengthy consideration to all the arguments that I heard before the decision was announced and have heard since the decision was announced. It was not a decision that the Government took lightly or hastily. Although the matter was decided finally only a few weeks ago, it has been given very close consideration within Government-not just by the present Cabinet-for quite a period. The decision followed years of comprehensive study. In 1980 the Government announced that it would acquire a ship to replace the Melbourne and that, in principle, it would have the sort of capabilities that the Invincible offers. So, the decision to have a sea-borne platform, as it is referred to in general terms, has been included in the long term defence planning of the Government, and the decision to purchase the Invincible was taken simply because the opportunity presented itself to obtain a vessel of this capability and character at a very cheap price . We took advantage of that golden opportunity. I emphasise that the decision was not to have this vessel as anything additional to our defence program.

As I said, the matter has been under consideration for some time and our long term defence planning, which we are following, made provision for the acquisition of such a capability. The concern we had was whether we would have been able to afford to purchase equipment of this calibre, size and expense had it not been for the opportunity presented by the British Government to purchase the Invincible at a very low price. Any alternative that we could see in the years ahead as a replacement for the Melbourne would have been purchased at a very high price, which would have been a very considerable addition to our program costs as we are estimating them; whereas the purchase of the Invincible, certainly with some readjustments to costs at an earlier stage than we had perhaps planned, will be possible within the program that has been provided for.

There have been some suggestions-I think Senator Evans took up this point-that the purchase is contrary to views expressed in the Defence Force capabilities paper of 1981. That view was based upon a misreading of the paper because it simply dealt with priorities for additional capability over and above those that were present and planned for our defence forces. That paper was written on the basis that a new carrier would be acquired and it simply talked about priorities in addition to that. There is nothing inconsistent between that paper and the decision to purchase this carrier.

The Invincible, of course, is a highly modern, highly sophisticated and highly successful piece of equipment. It is not something which is being built or which has to be proven. It is already in operation and has proved very successful in exercises in which it has been engaged. It was rather surprising that Senator MacGibbon should have said that senior officers of the Navy do not appreciate the vulnerability of capital chips of this kind in a missile age. He suggested that that was the reason that the British Government was selling the Invincible. But, of course, the British Navy is building two sister ships to the Invincible, which it is keeping, and would dearly love to have kept this carrier, as we know . It was only because of other enormous defence expenditures that the British Government decided to assure that this ship ever came on the market at all. It is certainly not for reasons of the kind suggested by Senator MacGibbon that the British Navy and senior naval officers wanted to dispose of the vessel.

As I have said, Senator Hamer dealt with most of the arguments that have been presented both while the Cabinet was engaged in making its recent decision and since. All of those matters were given very close consideration by Cabinet in coming to its decision. Few other decisions in which I have participated have engaged the Cabinet in such a lengthy and detailed consideration as this decision. I emphasise the very great attention that was paid to all the arguments before the decision was made.

The relevance of the maritime power for Australia is obvious. On an average day there are about 195 merchant ships in our ports and about 175 in transit to and from Australia. In fact, I am told that today there are 294 merchant ships in our ports so that gives some indication of what the total number could be on any one day. The passage of these ships to and from Australia is, of course, of vital importance to us as is the passage of vessels on our coastal trade. There is some view that our trade routes need only be protected off our ports as this will be where enemy submarines will be concentrated. In the early stages of conflict the enemy may be expected to concentrate its efforts there. But defences close to Australia should drive the submarines further away and protection will be required at greater distances. With the development of ocean surveillance systems, the submarines problems of intercepting mid-ocean shipping have eased. This factor leads to an increased requirement for mid-ocean protection. That is one of the major reasons for our acquiring this carrier and points to the value of the particular vessel that we have obtained.

Certainly, air power is fundamental to maritime operations. But it can be provided both by shore-based and seaborne aircraft. The value of shore-based aircraft to Australia's maritime defence will remain of particular importance for as far ahead as one can see. The carrier will provide the government of the day with additional options, particularly in areas further from our shores and remote from military airfields. As I said, there is this very large overseas shipping component. If we were involved in a conflict we would have to provide protection, probably, for convoys coming to our shores. This is where the particular importance of having a vessel such as the Invincible becomes obvious. When the ship arrives in Australia in 1984 it will be immediately available for operations. It will be capable of operating anti-submarine helicopters and acting as a task group command ship. Six Sea King helicopters which were previously operated from HMAS Melbourne are already available. A further two will be delivered with the ship and an order for a further one is planned. The Invincible will certainly be able to provide a much more effective and economical operation of these helicopters. The Invincible was designed to carry 14 Sea King types but could carry up to 22 aircraft if all deck parking were used.

The other important aspect of the Invincible is as a command ship. The control of maritime operations, of course, with air, surface and submarine units with a variety of weapons is a complex task. The speed of modern warfare demands fast and accurate command decisions. Destroyers and frigates can carry out some supporting command functions, but they cannot provide the facilities necessary for task group command. Invincible has exactly those facilities. The Invincible carries an area defence missile system capable of contributing to the defence of itself and ships in company with it. This, of course, bears on the question of vulnerability. I do not propose to add anything to the detailed and interesting comments that Senator Hamer has made on this subject. But it is important to emphasise in this regard-when one comes to debate the particular types of defence facilities it has-that the Invincible will be operated as part of a group, the collective defences of which will exceed the individual capabilities of any unit. It is the task group concept of a number of vessels which one has to look at to see what the defences of the whole group are and not just what the defences of one ship in it may be.

It has been suggested that more ships would be required to provide this protection support, but that is just not true. These ships already exist in the Royal Australian Navy. Their primary purpose is not to defend the carrier but to provide with it the mix of capabilities required for the maritime operations of the kind to which I have referred. The Invincible can embark a battalion group with equipment for a limited period. This troop lift capability provides a useful extension to that in other ships available to the Royal Australian Navy. In peacetime this capability can offer a spin-off in the event of natural disasters when evacuation or assistance on a large scale is necessary.

I think it has been shown clearly that the Invincible has proved herself as a powerful and effective warship. Her capabilities will complement those of existing and planned ships and aircraft. Together with destroyers, frigates, submarines and aircraft such as the F111, the F18 and the P3, the carrier will contribute to a balanced Australian maritime force. Let their be no doubt that the possession of this ship in the Australian Defence Force will be a powerful factor in the perceptions of any future potential enemy in our area and thus an important element in our deterrent posture.

I believe that there has been, as I said, a great deal of consideration given to the decision to acquire this vessel. I believe that there has been a very full public explanation by the Government of the reasons why it came to this decision. It is a decision which was made after very lengthy consideration going back years. The decision to have a capability of this kind within the Australian Defence Force has been included in our planning for the future. A golden opportunity has been presented to us with the offer of this vessel at a remarkably low price. We have been able to acquire it without making any major additions to the planning costs in our defence program in the coming years. For all these reasons, the Government believes very strongly that the right decision has been made. Absolutely no good purpose will come from a parliamentary committee reviewing the whole subject as is proposed in this motion. I trust that the Senate will reject it.
Amendment agreed to.
Motion, as amended, agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Thomas Sen A.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Martyr and in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, I present the forty- fifth general report of the Joint Parliamentary Committee on Public Works. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a tabling statement relating to the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-

This general report reviews the activity of the Committee during 1981. The report includes a reference to departments improving the standard of their submissions. We have set out in the report some key factors which should be included in the departmental submissions. These include:
The need for the proposed work;
the alternative solutions which have been examined prior to the decision to proceed with the work;
an indication of the priority of the work in relation to other planned works by the Department;
details of any cost-benefit studies;
details of any environmental studies;
information of negotiations or discussions with other departments, state and local authorities, companies, unions and the public in relation to the work.
In relation to environmental factors, the Committee has signalled its intention to more fully examine compliance with the Environmental Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act.

The Committee is frequently advised that proposed works require urgent attention, early completion of the works being necessitated by certain factors. Responsible departments should co-ordinate their planning and resource allocation with a view to giving the Committee sufficient time to publicise its enquiry, for interested groups and organisations to provide submissions and for the Committee to hold public hearings and report to Parliament.

It appears to the Committee that the works become urgent because of lack of foresight and a lack of timely commitment in the Government of departmental decision making and administrative/budgeting machinery.

Also in this general report is a section dealing with the construction of airport works which pre-empted consideration by the Committee. Authorisation and completion of these works without investigation by the Committee was a matter of concern.

On a brighter note, the Committee observed the adoption of its recommendations in respect to defence housing. Full and regular consultation now appears to be taking place between service families and the Department of Defence, the Department of Administrative Services and the Department of Housing and Construction on the needs and problems of occupants of defence housing.

The Committee has commented on the Commonwealth's contribution to the National Heritage. The Committee believes the Commonwealth expenditure in designing and constructing new buildings to complement historic buildings or areas should be recognised and that the public should be made aware of the Commonwealth's contribution.

The committee has drawn to the attention of the Government the need to clarify further the precise definition of a public work as noted in sections 5 and 18 of the Public Works Committee Act. The question of the definition of a public work arose over the proposed construction of an oceanographic research vessel for CSIRO.
1981 was a busy year for the Committee with 12 reports being presented, and some 54 meetings being held in the year.
The works examined totalled $207.9 million with works costing $190.45 million being recommended for construction by the Committee.
The work load on committee members and staff has been heavy, and as Chairman I wish to record my thanks to them.
During the year, the vice-chairman, Senator Jean Melzer, retired and the Committee wishes her well for the future.
Additionally, on behalf of the Committee, I now place on record acknowledgment of the help and assistance received from departments, particularly the Department of Housing and Construction.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Robertson)-by leave-agreed to:
That intervening business be postponed until after consideration of General Business, Order of the Day No. 168.
Debate resumed from 23 March, on motion by Senator Evans:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Whips on both sides for their courtesy in enabling me to speak on this matter. I will almost certainly be in Africa at the conclusion of the Inter-Parliamentary Union meetings and will not, therefore, be able to record my vote or take proper part in the further stage of this Bill. I desire, therefore, to put on record my views on the subject on which I am well known to have held views for many years. I seek leave to take the unusual course of incorporating this speech in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

I make it clear that I have for a number of years supported the concept of a fixed term Parliament, originally enunciated by Senator David Hamer in this Parliament and subsequently incorporated in this Bill. I have also expressed a number of criticisms of the terms of the Bill. Two of my three major concerns have now been overcome by the proposed amendments which Senator Evans has announced he is making to this Bill.

Consequently I believe this Bill, as amended, deserves to be given a second reading by the Senate and I will vote for that second reading if present. Defects in the Bill can be remedied at the Committee stage. If absent I make it clear that I will not be paired in opposition to the second reading. As to decisions that may occur in the Committee stages or on the third reading I am aware of Senator Hamer's attitude to the Bill, which accords with mine, and I leave it to his discretion to determine whether I should be paired in such divisions.

I am aware of the general argument which Senator Hamer will be raising in his second reading speech and warmly support his views. I believe the fixed term proposals provide a realistic practical solution to the type of deadlocks and crises that have poisoned the political atmosphere since 1975 and that, if adopted, the issues of Senate powers over supply will fade into insignificance as there would really be no benefit for Oppositions to deny moneys to Governments when such action cannot bring down the Government. Consequently I see the section of the Bill (Clause 8) which seeks to remove the Senate's supply power (or reduce it according to Senator Evan's latest amendment) as quite extraneous to the Bill and most likely to heighten political anomosities, leading to the defeat of a referendum. I believe these provisions were a later embellishment, by the Labor Caucus, on the Evans Bill and trust they can be removed rather than jeopardize the success of this reform.

I might say that, in any ideal climate, I would cheerfully see the removal of the Senate's ultimate power to refuse supply or defeat money bills. I do not see it as essential to the Senate's real work, as a house of review of legislation and as a powerful investigatory House. It is a weapon altogether too potent and destructive, a blunt instrument which may be used at any time by the politically ambitious-usually residing in the House of Representatives. I do not regard the use of this weapon in 1975 as a sign of Senate power but rather of weakness. I well remember the pressure in 1975 came from Opposition leaders in the House of Representatives and those residing in the Senate were overborne by the weight of numbers. The Senate has since suffered much calumny from its use and and only years of positive work by the Senate since 1975 has restored its prestige.

But unfortunately we do not have an ideal world and we cannot ignore the fact that many political leaders have painted themselves with corners over the controversies of 1975. It is a roadblock on dispassionate constitutional thinking and should be avoided. Moreover various State leaders will readily fear the worst if alteration of Senate powers is suggested.

Since 1975 I have endeavoured to promote widespread discussion of constitutional reforms and to seek concerns across the political barriers. As a patron of the Committee for Constitutional Change I have sought new ideas and solutions to seemingly insoluble constitutional attitudes and I regard Senator Evans Bill as a serious and genuine attempt to provide solutions.

It is important for us to recognise the haphazard nature of many of our constitutional provisions and the need for early consideration of reform. I do not see, as a practical proposal, any 'new' constitution emerging and I believe that those who attack such proposals are really setting up their own Aunt Sallies just to knock them down. But undoubtedly the division of powers in Australia is not well matched with present national responsibilities and there is an overwhelming case for renewal and amendment of many aspects of our Constitution. It is not a sacred and immutable document and the Australian people should see in the 1977 referendum results an encouraging development in fluidity of opinion. The shame is that the initiative has not since been maintained.

Among the haphazard aspects of our constitution stands the double dissolution provisions (Section 57) which were used in 1975 to break a deadlock. You will recall the odd circumstance that the new Prime Minister, Malcolm Fraser was granted a double dissolution only because there were defeated Bills of the Whitlam Goverment that were made the basis of that dissolution-yet Mr Fraser had not the slightest intention or re-presenting any of those Bills. If they had not been defeated and laid aside, no double dissolution would have occurred and the Senate would not have been required to face the people after bringing down a government. It is clearly an unsatisfactory, random situation calling for change and indeed I have always doubted the constitutionality of the use of those Bills . Recent statements of our High Court have strongly suggested that it might well look into the proper use of a power by the executive (or a Governor-General). As we know, in 1975 the Chief Justice chose to give his personal advice to the Governor-General (a highly dubious course of action) and the crisis of 1975 was not in fact litigated before the High Court.

In the arguments about 1975, there is usually a simplistic answer delivered by those who applaud the exercise of Senate power over supply-it enabled the people to vote and they rejected the Whitlam Government at the election. Of course it cannot be said that the people voted in 1975 on the basis of the constitutional argument. As one clearly involved in that election I express the firm belief that the people did not vote generally on constitutional arguments but on the basic argument as to which Government would prove to be the better economic manager.

But leaving that argument aside, I believe that it is no solution to have more elections. Responsible government involves governments being in a position to make responsible and sometime unpalatable decisions. They must often impose restrictions, extra taxation and incur temporary unpopularity because of long term national interests. The case for four year terms of Parliament (instead of three years) is indeed based essentially on the need for security of government and its ability to make more responsible decisions. It is a reform that should also come. Consequently I have always rejected the facile arguments that appeal to the people, the 'Gallop Poll' mentality, are the solution to problems. Governments should have security of tensure (unless they lose support of the majority in the lower House) and this Bill is largely predicated on that basis.

One other haphazard constitutional provision deserves a mention. The existing Constituion gives no guarantee of continued simultaneous elections of both Houses. It only takes an early election of this Parliament to throw the Houses out of alignment again. It is clear that the people already resent the excessive number of elections in this country, remember that since Federation, we have had an average 2.4 years duration for each Parliament. Recall also that in 1977, while the referndum on simultaneous elections became befogged in the peripheral States and was lost, it enjoyed the support of 62% of the vote over the whole of Australia. If handled more wisely in the earlier stages, it undoubtedly would be the law today. The Evans Bill, as one of its benefits, will secure simultaneous elections of both Houses of Federal Parliament.

Since 1975 we, the Politicians of Australia have so far failed to secure constitutional compromises that would have majority support in Australia. We have not been prepared to accept genuine compromises and I am sorry that a Federal Liberal CP Government has not fought harder at a time when it had majorities in both Houses. At the Constitutional Convention meetings, much rhetoric and heat has been wasted on supporting the rival 'Whitlam' and 'Court' proposals for alteration of Senate powers and resolving deadlocks. Neither has a ghostly chance of acceptance at a referendum by a constitutional majority of Australians. The 'Whitlam' proposal denudes the Senate of its power over money bills and immediately raises a coalition of foes. The 'Court' proposal is little better. True is provides an automatic double dissolution on refusal of money bill and is not dependent on fortuitous and dubious 'double dissolution' bills. It also removes the Governor-General's discretion. But it is based on the fallacy that a Government, elected by the people can be brought down at any convenient time (by that, convenient to an Opposition) and that a popular vote solves any problems. There remains a very real possibility that an Opposition, fed by ambition, will again exercise its powers and do a reverse 1975 action. Imagine the absurdity that Mr Hayden, using his Senate members, might deny supply to the Government, be offered a commission as Prime Minister and then use the Fraser Government's defeated bills as a basis for a double dissolution. A practical solution must be found to avoid continued crises that might ultimately destroy democracy in this country.

Senator Evans' Bill therefore requires serious consideration by the Senate and the Parliament generally to see if it can provide an acceptable practical solution. One major effect of his fixed terms proposal is to remove a Prime Minister's extra power to call for early elections with all the insecurity and economic disruption that it involves. Many times we have seen business, organisations and people generally unable to make decisions over 9 months or so because of the possible use of this tactic. It is not one that the USA has to fear. It is not inherent in responsible government that Prime Ministers enjoy such a power and it would be for the real economic growth of this country that such tactics be brought to an end.

Senator Austin Lewis has contributed to this debate with a paper which sets out arguments against the fixed terms proposals. I give him credit for a thoughtful examination and explanation of his opposition. But I reject his view that the proposals removes 'an essential element of responsible government' or that under the Bill 'a weak and debilitated government could be kept in office till the end of its appointed term, unable to carry out its major policies, and unable to resolve the situation'. The problems of dissident Government MP's changing a Government without recourse to the people occur under the present system, for example Gorton's replacement by McMahon was not confirmed by a vote of the people. The problems Senator Lewis sees can well occur now but there is no inherent right of Governments to enjoy the tactical weapons they enjoy today any more than Senate Opposition should be able to bring down Governments without being responsible to the people, as they can do today.
The arguments raised by Senator Lewis and the Attorney General Senator Durack against the fixed term proposal are hypothetical and unreal but they will be dealt with in more detail by Senator Hamer.

Turning to the terms of the Bill I say that there were indeed defects in Senator Evans' original Bill and in part they are overcome. His original proposal, somewhat complex, to restore the fixed dates after an extraordinary House of Representatives election would have robbed the fixed term of much of its validity and enabled Governments to connive in reducing Senate terms. The new proposal, which means that after an extraordinary House of Representatives election, the new Parliament will only serve out the balance of the fixed term is much better. It will discourage 'adventures' in the House of Representatives and discourage dissident groups from forcing earlier elections thus making for stability. Senator Evans' second change, the removal of the provision for a joint sitting of the Houses as an alternative for a double dissolution is welcomed. With large majorities in the House of Representatives and little or no majorities in the Senate (due to proportionate representation) the House of Representatives would always win.

The third variation of the Evans Bill is less happy. He now proposes to import a distinction in respect to 'major Bills', whatever that may mean and reserve the Senate's power over them only. I have not seen the drafted proposals and reserve final comment. However, I cannot see how this distinction could be sustained. Who would decide which bills were 'indispensible to a Government's capacity to govern', the Opposition or the Government? One must await the form of the amendments but one cannot but ask whether a proposal should be endangered by the overlay of such a complex and probably unnecessary provision.

I trust that Government Senators will give careful attention to this Bill, putting aside the rhetoric, the 'excursions and alarums' and seeing whether it may indeed provide a real and practical remedy for the problems which at present add uncertainty and danger to our Constitutional position.
Debate (on motion by Senator Robertson) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: ABORIGINAL LAND RIGHTS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1982

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill returned from the House of Representatives without amendment.

DEBATE.TITLE: STAGING OF UNITED STATES B52 AIRCRAFT THROUGH AUSTRALIA

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in the opinion of the Senate, the Agreement dated 11 March 1981 between the Governments of the United States of America and Australia on the staging of United States Air Force B-52 aircraft through Australia should be renegotiated-

(a) to include a new article reading 'No aircraft carrying nuclear weapons shall use any facility in Australia or based in Australia without the prior agreement in writing of the Australian Government,';

(b) to secure amendment of article (VII) of the Agreement to require approval by the Australian Government of developments affecting the staging operations, rather than consultations on such developments; and
(c) to review article (II) to secure the location of the B-52 aircraft and their support aircraft away from Darwin to a location well removed from major population centres of Australia.

The effect of this motion is to indicate a view of the Senate on the agreement Australia has with the United States over the basing of the American B52 bombers in this country. There are three things sought by the motion. Firstly, the agreement should be renegotiated to include a new article which will read:
No aircraft carrying nuclear weapons shall use any facility in Australia or . . .
I would like to add the word 'be' to make this read correctly. It will then read :
or be based in Australia without the prior agreement in writing of the Australian Government.
I seek leave to include the word 'be'.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —This really amounts to a stronger wording of the agreement so that if there is any extension of the role of these aircraft which are, after all, nuclear bombers this must be done in consultation with the Government of Australia. We are told that the present role amounts to training and reconnaissance, but the time could come, with very little warning, in which Australia might be required to stage through B52s carrying nuclear warheads and engage in missions to deliver them against a specific enemy. That would, of course, involve serious risks to this country. Our participation in that greater effort would make us a nuclear target, if we are not already. That would be the case with Darwin because of the fact that the B52s use Darwin when they are coming through Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: There is little point in debating the rights, wrongs and theories of such a possible conflict. There are those in the community who say we should never contemplate such an engagement, that we should never agree to any co-operation with the United States if indeed there were an all-out war. Other people say we ought to support our major ally in such desperate circumstances for the United States, the world and, indeed, ourselves. I submit that that debate, no matter how worthy it is, has nothing whatsoever to do with the rights and wrongs of this motion. I must stress that the Australian Democrats do not see this motion as any kind of paranoid attack against the United States, as anti-United States feeling or anything of that kind. I renounce in advance any cliches we may hear later in this debate to that effect. This really comes down to a matter of sovereignty, a matter of Australia's own right to do what it wants to do and our own responsibilities as a democratic sovereign country to decide our own affairs .

It is for that reason that I have suggested in the motion that the Senate might quote as its opinion that this question of nuclear arms should be written into the agreement, which is not the case now. The only guarantee, such as we have, is, I understand, a verbal agreement between the Minister for Foreign Affairs ( Mr Street) and the American Secretary of State, Mr Haig. We are given to understand that this is recorded in the form of an unsigned minute which was shown to the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden). The Australian Democrats do not believe that this is sufficient and that there is no reason in the world why this very important, indeed this crucial and basic, question of the upgrading of role to nuclear weapons should not be included in a reasonable formal agreement with another country. I cannot see any reason why there should be any objection to it from that other country. Surely our citizens would applaud that.

We must look at what might or might not happen in war. That simply cannot be forecast. We have no way of assessing the circumstances in which it might happen and it is pointless and futile to try to predict them. We in this country, as in the other democracies, elect a government with certain policies to make those decisions for us. While the Australian people continue to elect governments which support the United States alliance, this question of upgrading of role must fairly be a responsibility of government. However, we do not have elected governments so that other powers, even the most friendly ones, can operate within our territory independently of our government in such important regards. We believe that it is essential that this whole question of upgrading of nuclear weapons should be a matter of government decision.

The second part of the motion seeks to secure amendment of article VII of the agreement to require approval by the Australian Government of developments affecting the staging operations rather than consultations on such developments. To clarify that I will read article VII of the agreement. It states:

Arrangements shall be made for consultations to ensure that the Government of Australia has full and timely information about strategic and operational developments relevant to B52 staging operations through Darwin.

I believe, and the Australian Democrats believe, that it is most important that this should be clarified. It is a matter of concern in basic relationships between small and large partners that there should be a liberal and just series of terms-as just terms as possible-from the larger partner to the smaller partner. This would certainly relieve the fears of many people about the B52 matter and improve United States-Australian relationships. I believe that it would have an important value in that latter regard also. It is a fact that during the intervening months since I gave notice of this motion the world has moved gradually towards a more perilous situation. There is a new policy in the United States. Many people in that country, including Senator Kennedy and Senator Tsongas, are speaking outrightly about this. These people are not on the left wing fringes; they are responsible senators of the Republican and Democrat parties in the United States. They, themselves, are seriously concerned about the prospects of nuclear war. All I say is that the Australian Democrats believe that the situation has not improved with regard to this agreement since the time I originally gave notice of this motion. To the contrary, it is fairly obvious that the risks of nuclear war or nuclear engagement are much greater than they were previously.

The third matter dealt with in the motion is the review of Article 2 to secure the location of the B52 aircraft and their support aircraft away from Darwin to a location well removed from major population centres of Australia. As honourable senators who have been in Darwin would know Darwin Airport, which is also a defence airfield, is virtually a part of the city. It is also a considerable distance from the Indian Ocean, which is the indicated area of surveillance for the B52 flights. This seems something of a mystery to us. We would have thought that if surveillance of the Indian Ocean were the whole purpose of this operation it would be a very good thing if the aircraft could have been located somewhere closer. Perhaps some co-operation between the United States Government and the Australian Government would have expedited that.

It has been suggested that there would seem to be good reason for the revival and upgrading of the existing Royal Australian Air Force base at Learmonth in Western Australia for that purpose. I have never heard from the Government-I do not think any of us have-why that base was not considered, the reasons against it. Last year I met a number of United States congressmen familiar with the B52 situation. They were rather interested in this matter too. They said as far as they knew Learmonth had never been considered. Some of those congressmen and senators were on the relevant committees. I would have thought that our Government may have at least gone to the United States Government and said: 'We are going to have the B52s. It would be a very good idea to have them much closer to the area we want to keep under surveillance. We have this mothballed airfield at Learmonth which could be upgraded, perhaps with some financial assistance from the United States'. That would have had the effect of giving Australia a much better and much more powerful potential defence situation in the west where we need it. After all, that is where I would have thought a defensive strike into the Indian Ocean would have been most beneficially placed- at Learmonth, not at Darwin. I will be interested to hear from the Government, if Government senators take any part at all in this debate, the reasons against that choice because it would seem to be an excellent idea.

In the past the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) has made the point repeatedly that our co-operation with the United States in the Indian Ocean is a very important consideration for the United States. I can see that in a way it could be a very important consideration for us but I wonder whether the Prime Minister's view of the United States image of that situation is illusory. I refer to the Centre for Strategic and International Studies Washington Paper for 1981, Paper 87: Geopolitics and Maritime Power, which I recently scanned. In chapter 2 'The Indian Ocean and the Persian Gulf' Australia scarcely rates a mention. There is one reference only on page 27 where an international force for the Persian Gulf, specifically in Turkey, is discussed. There is this single reference:
Britain has contributed a token force and Australia could also help.

This is a fairly authoritative American study background paper. That is the only comment made on Australia's position. That of course might change with this agreement. Our degree of concern is that this agreement, like all such things, tends to be sanctified by the passing of time. That is the last major point I would like to make on this matter. When these matters are left, time passes and it becomes more and more difficult to amend or adjust them in the way they should be adjusted. That is our degree of concern with this agreement.

Finally, I reiterate that to the Democrats this is not a matter of global politics, not a matter of one's view of global war and not a matter of bias towards any zonal area-whether it be the United States or the Soviet Union-but purely a matter of Australia's right to decide its own affairs and the reasonable courtesy that we feel should be extended to Australia by one of our neighbours and a friend. I think one should expect from a friend courtesy, consideration and an agreement which can be read as meaning something but not containing matters such as Article (VII), which I will read again. It states:

Arrangements shall be made for consultations to ensure that the Government of Australia has full and timely information about strategic and operational developments relevant to B-52 staging operations through Australia.

We suggest that this is not enough. There is at least a case for the Senate making a statement on this matter. All we are asking for is that it be stated that in the opinion of the Senate this agreement should be renegotiated. We feel that there is a clear case for that. I commend the motion to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Messner) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to amend my notice of motion so as to refer the matters contained in it to two Senate standing committees.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) That the following matters be referred to the Standing Committee on National Resources:
Animal welfare in Australia in relation to:
(a) Interstate and overseas commerce in animals; and
(b) codes of practice of animal husbandry for all species.
(2) That the following matters be referred to the Standing Committee on Science and the Environment:
Animal welfare in Australia in relation to:
(a) wildlife protection and harvesting;
(b) animal experimentation; and
(c) the use of animals in sport.
I ask leave of the Senate to incorporate my speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

In introducing this measure, the Democrats are taking the initiative to develop safeguards and guidelines for the treatment of animals of all species found on the Australian continent on which the human race has an effect, both the relationship for economic gain or entertainment.
All commercial animals and pets would fit into this category, and also those animals upon which humans by virtue of their actions, have a significant effect including wildlife species.
It has been our policy to extend care and concern to animals in a meaningful form and we have an animal rights policy balloted and approved by our members which says in the preamble:

'While man is, or should be, responsible for the welfare of all life on the planet, he is himself both part of that life and dependent on it for his survival. He shares with other higher animals both consciousness and sensitivity to pain. A difference in species does not, any more than a difference in race, justify a limitation to this respect for other animals, or his concern about the responsiveness to their suffering. Animals do not have a vote, but concerned people do. The Democrats must present strongly and clearly and advanced and enlightened policy on animal welfare'.

Now as a positive step to put that principle into effect, this motion will see a select committee appointed which will look into all aspects of animal welfare and where it finds deficiencies will recommend the means needed to overcome them .
It is important that uniformity be applied to Animal Welfare, across the nation and that response to pressure groups be balanced and not just an ad hoc reaction to a particular situation.

It is important that all areas of animal lives are included. The Select Committee will be expected to inquire into all areas where animal treatment has become almost traditional because of the time which the treatment or procedures has been practised. It is essential that unnecessary suffering of animals be prevented.

We feel sure that most commercial animal breeders have an affectionate regard for the animals under their care and would cooperate with reasonable controls and suggestions to reduce stress or pain inflicted on their animals. Many will welcome help in identifying procedures which can be moderated or changed to the advantage of their animals. Particularly as they realise that the Select Committee is giving an evenhanded view balancing the requests from Animal Liberationists where necessary, with the practical considerations of animal husbandry.
The particular references listed in the motion ensure that the inquiry will cover most important areas of animal concern in particular:

(A) Overseas and interstate trade and commerce in animals: Transportation of stock animals in Australia is a seriously neglected area of animal welfare (any farmer will tell you how the cattle arrive with tails badly damaged from friction against the back of a truck, permanent sores forming on the hip from jolting and bruising for hour after hour, and animals with crippling foot injuries due to improper flooring.)

Animal production loss in each state differs but in general there is no stipulation that animals shall only travel for a certain number of hours. There is no requirement which makes one person responsible for the animals at each point of the journey and so responsibility for injury and death is abnegated or denied. Local abbatoirs are closing down with the result that stock animals are being transported further and further across state borders making the issue a federal matter. Horses for instance may be loaded in Queensland, travel 2 or 3 days in a truck as it is being loaded in various points then stand 2 days in a sale yard at Homebush without food or water to be trucked out that evening to a knackery. This apart from the obvious cruelty involved, is also economic disaster because the farmer loses money in sick and injured livestock. A large component of which is bruising alone. In 1975 there was a loss of $20 million per annum from bruised carcasses and this does not include death, weightloss, height damage or contamination of carcasses. An inquiry is urgently needed into ways of supervising journeys of stock animals, of improving sale yard conditions , or relating the types of transport used in moving animals to prevent unnecessary injury and stress and of defining the responsibility of sellers, transporters, buyers, auctioneers and agents.

A subject which has caused public outcry is the shipping of live animals overseas for slaughter. For instance last year over 100 horses were sent to Japan to be fattened and killed for eating and 5.7 million sheep were exported live mostly to the Middle East. (Conditions under which the sheep travel are quite appalling; three sheep crowded into an area of one square metre; Hygiene problems such as the decks cannot be kept clean and the problem of disposing of sick and dead sheep during the voyage.

On arrival in the Middle East the animals are held in very crude conditions and the ritual slaughter means that the animals have their throats cut without prior stunning. We must have the regulations to ensure that if we do send Australian sheep overseas that their suffering is reduced to a minimum during the journey and when they are slaughtered.

The British Veterinarian Association policy is that animals should be slaughtered as near as possible to the point of production and this is certainly not happening with the overseas trade in livestock.

(B.) Wildlife Protection and Harvesting: It is estimated that at present about 30 Australian native species are threatened with extinction. An endangered species act is needed for the protection of the habitat of these species and we urgently need scientific research to find out the extent of the range of each endangered species and the factors which threaten their continued survival.

Australia is a signatory to the International Agreement-C.I.T.E.S. (Convention on International Trade of Endangered Species). We need funding to set up a monitoring service to prevent wildlife being smuggled out of the country and to police illegal traffic.

The Federal Government is breaking down the prohibition on kangaroo exports which was established by the Whitlam Government. The Australian Government has been making strong representations to the U.S. Government requesting that it lift its ban on importing kangaroo skins and products and this was done so as of 29 May 1981. Recently, the E.E.C. overwhelmingly decided to ban the importation of seal skins and products and this was particularly important in terms of the world wide reaction to the annual seal hunt in Canada.

Rural surveys of some blocks of north-west New South Wales during mid-1981 showed a sharp drop in kangaroo numbers since the 1980 survey. The red kangaroo' s numbers have dropped from 8 million in 1980 to 7 million in 1981.

Poaching is widespread and because overseas sales are lucrative the temptation could arise to harvest these animals and eventually extinction could occur for some species. In this respect more well trained rangers are needed to patrol the kangaroo population and ensure that such a situation does not arise.

(C.) Animal Experiments: Perhaps one of the most disturbing aspects of all animal welfare matters in Australia is the use of animals for experiments. Although many questions have been asked in State and Federal Parliament over the years we still have no figures available as to how many animals are being used in experiments in this country, what types of animals are being used or for what sorts of research. There is virtually no legislation to protect animals used in experiments.

The various State Acts are totally inadequate, therefore we have a situation where anything can be done to a dog or a cat behind closed laboratory doors without the researcher being answerable to anyone except his own peers.

The National Health and Medical Research Council does have a code of practice to govern the use of animals in experiments which states that 'procedures likely to cause pain of more than a trivial extent must not be carried out without the administration of an anaesthetic'. However, this code is, we believe, not being enforced. We are appreciative of honourable members (such as Ralph Jacobi) who have raised these questions from time to time. We believe this is a bipartisan matter of moral and ethical concern which should not be related to party politics.
What is (urgently) needed is a system which is publicly accountable such as that in Great Britain where statistics are collected by the Home Office and it is known how many animals are used.

No animals should have to suffer pain in any experiment as modern analgesic and anesthetics are now more sophisticated. The Government must encourage the use and development of alternative techniques and animal welfare representatives should be represented on committees involved with animal experiments within the research establishment (as is the case in Sweden).

(D) Codes of Practice of Animal Husbandry for all Species: Recently there has been much publicity about the keeping of hens in confined cages all their lives to produce eggs cheaply. Up to 4 hens can be crowded into a cage with a sloping wire floor where each hen has a quarto page space in which it lives virtually its whole life being constantly jostled by its companions. Pigs also are crowded indoors on cement or slashed floors, they are fed on artificial foods, never knowing sun, fresh air or exercise. As long ago as 1965 the Bramble Report, a committe of agricultural experts in Britain stated that even animals that were kept indoors for generation after generation did not lose their instincts to scratch in the soil, to make a dust bath etc.

I would like to stress that draft codes of practice just prepared by the Sub- Committee on Animal Welfare within the Australian Agricultural Council-a hasty response to agitation by animal liberation groups-totally neglect the most essential feature of factory farming; there is no statement in the code of practice on pig welfare which deals with the ethological or behavioural means of the animal. Many eminent scientists such as Dr Van Putten of Holland who have made a life-long study of pigs have stated that if an animal is permanently confined frustration may be expressed in disease or death. For instance pigs suffer heart attacks and ulcers and there is the sudden death syndrome of poultry, the cause of which is still not known.
The transport and slaughter is doubly traumatic because these animals are not accustomed to outdoor environment.

In Europe there are parliamentary committees examining these questions. Animals are voiceless but there are many people who will vote on their behalf. These people are seriously concerned with the way in which animals are treated as machines and not as living, feeling, sentient creatures capable of knowing pain and emotion.
(E) Animals in Sport: Finally, I want to make reference to animals in sport. Senators will recall the recent outcry about rodeo events such as calf-roping.

A calf may be travelling at 30 or 40 kilometres an hour when it is busted or suddenly thrown by a rope tightened around its neck. Overseas studies have shown a calf roped even once suffers injury such as bruising of the larynx and rupturing and haemorrhaging of muscles possibly paralysis.

Other sporting activities using animals are also of concern. The use of the whip in horse racing should be investigated and extraordinary events such as wild cow milking, greasy pig chasing ought to be assessed. There is also the problem of indiscriminate shooting of wildlife. All these issues must be investigated.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate for its indulgence. The reason that I changed the wording of my motion to refer to two standing committees is that the Senate is creaking along at the moment with too many select committees. I think every honourable senator is on one committee or more and would know the burden that that system is placing on the Senate and its resources. I have been persuaded-I did not need much persuasion-that it would be unfair to press the creation of another select committee on to the Senate. The chairmen and the members of the two standing committees were gracious enough to say that they would increase the loads on them and their committees in order to take on those terms of reference. I sincerely thank those chairmen and members of those Senate committees for their co-operation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I quite briefly indicate the Australian Labor Party's very strong support for Senator Chipp's motion. I suspect that in an ideal world we might have preferred the matters which are the subject of his motion to have been integrated into a single reference to a single committee. After all, the basic principles at stake here about animal welfare are in fact common to the terms of reference proposed for the separate committees. It is a realistic division of labour in terms of resources available and it may well have been that without this proposed division of labour it may not have been proved practicable for the reference to be made at all. On that basis we support not only the principle of a Senate inquiry into animal welfare but also the particular procedures that are proposed tonight. I think there is a disposition to regard animal welfare issues as curiously the preserve and preoccupation of little old ladies in tennis shoes but I think it ought to be appreciated--
—Tennis shoes?

—Perhaps sandshoes, to acknowledge Senator Chipp's continued robust interest in that sport. I think it ought to be acknowledged that animal welfare is increasingly being perceived by a great many people in this community , spread across a great many occupational groups and other interest groups. There is a growing awareness that in talking about animal welfare we are talking about something that is very much a legitimate preoccupation for ordinary, concerned citizens. I think there is a growing appreciation that the basic issue involved in the campaigning of increasingly visible animal welfare lobby groups is a very basic issue of suffering which deserves attention and compassion by all civilised human beings.

SPEECH.PARA: To disregard the suffering of animals simply because they are not human is to perpetuate, in many ways, the prejudice that has brought about their present situation. Some people treat living and suffering creatures-I will indicate in a moment some of the contexts in which that suffering does take place-as if they simply did not matter, just as in earlier times racists treated people of other races-I fear it is still the case in some places today-as though they did not matter. This is a point that has been made very successfully and very effectively by Professor Peter Singer of Monash University who has been one of the world leaders in developing an articulated consciousness, on the part of Western societies at least, in animal welfare and, as he has described it, animal liberation. I think it is important to get rid of the lingering prejudices that so many of us have against taking seriously the interests of lives and beings of a different species.

There are innumerable areas in which animal suffering is regrettably an omnipresent reality. There is the area of experimentation.
