Of course I do not mean all scientific experimentation but the undoubtedly quite considerable unnecessary experimentation that takes place in medical schools, colleges of pharmacology and a whole variety of other research establishments, but more particularly teaching establishments around the nation. Issues arise with which we are all familiar in the context of the transport of animals, especially live sheep. There is the even more obnoxious phenomenon that again we are regrettably all too familiar with of cosmetic testing of animals through the application of the various dosage tests that are applied and which are really quite grotesque in their implications for the suffering of the beings in question.

There is the question of slaughtering methods in the context of certain ritual killing in particular which does not allow for initial stunning of the beasts in question. There are methods of hunting, especially of kangaroos, which has given rise to other kinds of concern in that context. There are animal husbandry practices, particularly in respect of pigs and poultry and, to a lesser extent but perhaps increasingly, various methods of cattle raising. There is the question of the use of animals in sport. In this respect one cannot help but notice the controversy and outcry which quite legitimately arose in the context of the rodeo which was held in Melbourne and subsequently in Sydney. There are even questions that arise, and I think deserve some attention, so far as vermin control methods are concerned. I do not want to unnecessarily extend this recitation of the contexts in which I believe man has demonstrated its inhumanity to other species. However I do want to say that I, in common with Senator Chipp who has moved this motion, and other honourable senators and members in this place, abhor cruelty. I abhor needless violence. I abhor undue pain and I abhor it, perhaps even more strenuously, where those events are occasioned by commercial motives, by cost cutting or reasons of that kind.

For all those reasons I think it is very important for the Senate to acknowledge the initiative that has been taken by the Australian Democrats, and indeed by other parliamentarians in support of the Democrats, in response to what is clearly a growing concern in the community. I know that we cannot realistically expect, given the timetable of present projects of the committees in question, very quick responses to be made by the committees. However, the passage of Senator Chipp's motion tonight at least will mean that these matters are now on the agendas of the respective committees. It will mean that projects can be set in train, that perhaps some research can be prompted or stimulated and that submissions can be sought. In the months ahead-perhaps some time ahead- when it becomes possible for the committees to devote their whole attention to these matters, I am sure that they will do a very careful and very responsible job of treating systematically, carefully and in many ways for the first time in Australia's history what I believe is an issue of very great importance indeed. Accordingly I commend Senator Chipp's motion and recommend it to the favourable attention of the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Government I also commend the motion to the Senate.
—You are not closing the debate, are you?

—No, I am not. The motion was moved by Senator Chipp. I do not wish to prolong the debate as many items are before us but the inquiry is one which will be of considerable interest to many Australians. I note the reason for the reference being divided in the manner that it has. This is an acknowledgement of the reality of the work borne by committees and of the difficulty of doing all of the desirable things that members of this legislative chamber would like to do. I would like to thank members of the two committees that have been mentioned, the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources and the Senate Standing Committee on Science and the Environment, for the fact that they are interested and are prepared to pick up these references which are the subject of this motion.

SPEECH.PARA: It is known to all honourable senators that a reference which looks simple and short will involve a great deal of detailed inquiry, a great deal of evidence and a lot of time and effort on the part of honourable senators. It is an indication of the importance which is placed on this subject that the two references have been accepted by the committees. I commend the motion to the chamber. I hope that it will produce a useful result for Australia and a diminution of the sorts of problems and difficulties that Senator Evans, I think on behalf of us all, has said that we abhor.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I feel I should say a few words about this motion. Events in the chamber have really overcome us tonight. On checking with the people who arrange the business in this chamber after 8 o'clock I thought that this matter would not come on until a much later hour. However, events have transpired and we now find that Senator Chipp has moved an amendment to his original motion that a Senate select committee be set up. I was not made aware of that. I am a member of the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources. I was not aware that Senator Chipp's motion was going to be amended and that part of the reference would be sent to the National Resources Committee . That is all news to me. When I walked into the chamber I was not even aware that that had happened. However I guess that that is what the Senate will agree to. I do not know how the motion has been divided, which part will be referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Science and the Environment and which part will be referred to the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources. I am interested to know-I have not had time to look at the Notice Paper because I did not know the text of Senator Chipp's amendment-whether his party has a member on either of those committees. I know that they have not got a member on the National Resources Committee. Perhaps he can tell me whether a member of his party is on the other Committee.
—Yes, we have.

—That is all right. Therefore the Australian Democrats are going to play some part in the inquiry. No doubt in a week or two more will be said in other places about what has transpired tonight. I have risen in this chamber on many occasions and expressed my abhorrence at the cruelty that has been meted out in the transport of livestock, particularly the transport of live horses to Japan. One of the first matters I raised in this chamber a couple of years ago was the cruelty being meted out to live horses being tranported by ship from Melbourne to Japan. Because of the public outcry those horses had to be unloaded in Sydney and taken care of by the Royal Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals at great cost to that organisation. I have yet to be able to find out whether those people shipping those horses and, no doubt, making a profit out of them ever compensated the RSPCA for what it cost it to care for those horses in its custody on whatever property it was able to find on which to agist them and give them the necessary care in or near Sydney.

SPEECH.PARA: The other matter that I raised which caused great concern to the RSPCA inspectors concerned the time that a planeload of horses was being loaded at Tullamarine Airport and being transported to Japan by an American air freight company known as the Flying Tigers. When the RSPCA inspectors went to Tullamarine they were refused permission to inspect the conditions in which those horses would have to live during the time that they would be transported from Tullamarine to Japan. Of course, we know that people who engage in this sort of profit-making business are not concerned with the welfare of animals. All that they are concerned with is the making of a quick buck.

I suppose I could rightly say that apart from Senator Thomas in this chamber I have had a closer association with animals and their welfare than any other honourable senator, having been born and bred in the country, having been a shearer for 21 years and having handled many thousands of live sheep, having worked in abbatoirs and having been a poultry farmer for some 11 years. I have a great deal of experience in the handling of livestock and the way in which they ought to be cared for. One of the things that disturbs me about people who have as much concern as I do for the welfare of animals is where they may be misinformed in the care of live animals, particularly in the poultry industry. Now that we are concerned with splitting up this public inquiry between the two committees I hope that these people will be duly advised through the Press that the inquiry is taking place, that they will be able to come along to each of those committees, make public submissions and put their point of view. I hope that those people who have an opposite point of view will come along and put their view also. When the findings come down I hope that the committees will be able to satisfy the people who share my concern for the treatment of animals in Australia, whether they be domestic animals or the semi-wild animals which are being tranported out of this country so some people can make a quick dollar. When the recommendations come down I hope that they will embody some strict recommendations to the Government so that we can lay at rest for all time the possibility of ill-treatment of animals and ensure that the people who have charge of live animals care for them in the proper way.

I am greatly concerned also about the transporting of sheep and cattle by road and sometimes by rail-although they are better cared for by rail-to abbatoirs. As one drives along the highways of this country one comes across three-decker transporters. Because of the haste of the driver in trying to get from point A to point B he slews the vehicle around corners and it is not long before the weaker sheep or cattle are crowded into a corner and trampled down by the stronger ones. On some occasions one can see legs and heads sticking out of the vehicle. No doubt this causes great concern to animal lovers. As I said earlier, I hope that when the committees bring down their reports they recommend very stringent regulations for the transport and care of live animals.

They ought also to look at the care of domestic animals. Whilst a lot of criticism has been levelled at the commercial poultry farmers about battery hens I venture to say-I say this with some credibility-that much more cruelty is meted out to laying fowls in backyards where people keep them in small pens, particularly in wintertime, when they are bogged in at least a foot of mud in some places and are fed on kitchen scraps. That is also something about which people should show some concern. They ought to be concerned about people who neglect cats and dogs. People buy pets for their children at Christmastime. When the animals grow to a bit of a size and they have to be fed and looked after they turn them out in the street. That is why we have an overabundance, particularly of cats which in turn molest the bird life of Australia. All of these things should be given consideration.

I have not seen the new terms of reference which have been put before the Senate tonight. But I hope-and I say this with all sincerity-that when the Committees both bring down reports the Government takes immediate heed of those reports, whichever government is in power. The way things are going it might well be our government. We could be in government very soon. Of course we have great animal lovers on our side of the chamber. Senator Mulvihill is one such animal lover. He repeatedly stands in his place in this chamber and talks about the cruelty to animals. He tries to do something for their welfare. I conclude by repeating that this is a worth while reference. I hope that it serves a good purpose and that people on both sides of the chamber will be happy at the outcome of the public inquiry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Thomas Sen A.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly I apologise to the other members of the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources, of which I am chairman. I discussed this matter with each of the members of that Committee but , like Senator Chipp and other senators, I did not expect this matter to come on for debate tonight. I was hoping to have a meeting of the Committee and then to discuss with Senator Chipp the terms of our reference. I am very pleased to have this reference. I reiterate for the benefit of Senator McLaren that Item (a) of the motion states:

SPEECH.PARA: interstate and overseas commerce in animals;
Item (d) states:
codes of practice of animal husbandry for all species;

The remaining three items are being referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Science and the Environment. In that regard I apologise to the other members of the Committee although they were aware of this possibility. I am particularly pleased to have this reference. I have been involved in stud sheep all my life. I am a third generation stud sheep breeder. It has been very much in my interest to make sure that the sheep that have been under my charge have been well looked after. This applies to most people who handle stock.

I would like to try to offset some of the slight emotionalism which was brought into the debate by some previous speakers. As far as I know, apart from some of those odd people whom Senator Evans mentioned regarding experimentation with animals, everybody who makes a living from animals has a great deal of interest in the health of those animals. Farmers in particular who rely a great deal for their income from wool and meat would be in dire straits if the animals that they had charge of were not in very good health. Quite often the degree of the health of the animals is outside the farmers' control through weather conditions and many other situations. But I assure honourable senators that, if animals get any setback at all during the early part of their lives they are of no commercial value whatsoever to a stud sheep breeder. To that degree I certainly have a great deal of interest in the subject.

I acknowledge the particular interest that Senator McLaren has shown in this subject. His interest is well known. One of the other members of my Committee, Senator Bjelke-Petersen, is well known in rural areas in Queensland. She certainly would be able to contribute a great deal to our discussions as well. Of course, Senator Watson gets around Tasmania pretty often. He would bring quite a degree of learned knowledge for the Committee's considerations. I am sure that the amount of evidence that this inquiry will attract because of the great deal of interest in Australia on the subject will make the inquiry a very rewarding one.

The Senate Standing Committee on National Resources that I chair is currently involved in an inquiry. We hope to finish that inquiry towards the end of this year. It is a matter for the Committee to determine its own priorities as to the time it will be able to take on this inquiry. I hope it will be done fairly quickly and fairly expeditiously.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I briefly want to thank all those who participated in the debate. To allay the fears in Senator McLaren's mind, I explain that I was told about 10 minutes before this matter came on that it did not have an earthly chance of getting on tonight and probably not on the next General Business night. As the honourable senator would know, sometimes things happen in this chamber-not often, but sometimes-with a speed that we do not anticipate.
—With the speed of light.
—Not often.

—Yes, and not often. There were discussions with Senator Thomas and Senator Jessop. I know, after having had it explained to me by them, the workload in front of these committees, and it is enormous. Because of that I, being the sponsor of this motion, am deeply grateful to them for taking on this additional burden. I know that people such as Senator Evans who spoke in the debate are equally grateful. I thank the Senate and those honourable senators.
