DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Queensland Local Government Elections-Commonwealth Home Loans-Victorian Elections: Social Security Leaflets-Estimates Committees

PROCTEXT.PARA: Queensland Local Government Elections-Commonwealth Home Loans-Victorian Elections: Social Security Leaflets-Estimates Committees

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —It now being 10.22 p.m., I believe it would suit the convenience of honourable senators if I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

TALK.START.PARA: —On Saturday the people of Queensland go to the polls to vote in local government elections. One of the local authorities is the Brisbane City Council. The election for this Council is a very important one . The Brisbane City Council is a major local government authority providing services for approximately three quarters of a million people. The people of Brisbane have been ably represented by a Labor council for the past 21 years. The composition of the Council at present is 11 Labor aldermen, Nine Liberal aldermen and one National Party alderman. The National Party alderman was not elected as a National Party alderman. This lone National Party member is a defector from the Liberal Party and faces an uphill battle to retain his position on the Council.

SPEECH.PARA: For the first time, the National Party, in an attempt to extend its frontier from the rural areas of Queensland, is entering this election campaign for the Brisbane City Council. The National Party has not hesitated to spend freely from its ample cash reserves in trying to entice the voters of Brisbane to support its candidates. Nevertheless, I expect that its efforts will be in vain. But I ask tonight: How can the people of Brisbane expect the National Party or the Liberal Party to look after their interests at the local authority level? I ask this in view of the way that the National-Liberal Coalition Government in Queensland has attempted to emasculate the Brisbane City Council. In particular, the State Government has taken over two major revenue sources of the Council, namely, water supply and electricity supply. In doing so the costs to the Brisbane citizens have increased. It is worth noting in passing that electricity charges in Brisbane are expected to rise by 40 per cent in the next year because of the State Government's bias against Brisbane consumers.

But I would like to hear what the National and Liberal Party candidates have to say about their State colleagues withholding $47m of Commonwealth Grants Commission funds which should rightfully have gone to the City Council. During the Council election campaign, the National and Liberal party candidates have not cared to mention this vital issue which significantly affects the transport service of the City of Brisbane and the level of rates payable by the citizens of Brisbane. I have raised this matter in this place previously, and I will continue to raise it until the Queensland Government takes note of its responsibility to the people of Brisbane.

For those honourable senators who are interested in reading my earlier comments they are on pages 2548 to 2553 of the Senate Hansard of 25 November 1981. Briefly, however, the situation is this: Since late 1975 the Commonwealth Grants Commission has taken into account the cost of the Brisbane City Council's transport undertakings in determining the grant to Queensland as a claimant State. Since that time, the State Government has received a total of $65m from the Commonwealth Grants Commission due to metropolitan road transport being included in Queensland's assessed needs. However, in the same period, the State Government has made only $18m available to the Brisbane City Council for transport-a shortfall of $47m. When I raised this matter in this chamber last November my comments were reported in the Brisbane Courier-Mail. The report stated that I had said that $47m earmarked by the Commonwealth Grants Commission for metropolitan road transport in Brisbane had been deliberately withheld by the State Government.

I would stress that I did not use the term 'earmarked' in my speech because the Grants Commission does not earmark funds which it recommends should be payable to States. However, since certain funds were given to the State Government because of the Brisbane City Council's transport undertakings, I do not think that anyone could logically argue that morally the money does not belong to the Brisbane City Council and the people of Brisbane. As a result of the Courier- Mail report to which I referred, questions were asked in the Queensland State Parliament. In response, the Queensland Treasurer, Dr Edwards, said he believed that my statements were not correct but he would ask for further information and make a public statement on the matter that afternoon. He said that on 26 November 1981. I checked with his office not long ago and I was informed that no such statement was forthcoming. Obviously, Dr Edwards found that my statements were correct and, clearly, the Queensland Government has no justification for its actions in withholding $47m from the Brisbane City Council.

I raise this matter again tonight because I believe that it is important that the issue should be aired again before the Council election on Saturday. The Liberal and National Council candidates are promising the world. But at the same time, their colleagues in the State Government are ham-stringing and cheating the Brisbane City Council and the people of Brisbane. The interests of the people of Brisbane would not be looked after by candidates who will not stand up for the rights of those whom they purport to represent.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise a matter on the adjournment debate tonight which I spoke about at some length on 12 November last year when we were debating, in the Committee stage, Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1981, and that is the matter of cheap home loans to Liberal and National Country Party Ministers. Of course, the fact that I raised it here then attracted the attention of quite a lot of people in Australia. I raised the matter some years ago but because interest rates on housing loans were not very high nobody took any notice of it, but now that interest rates are going through the roof many people are very concerned that well-paid members of parliament, particularly Ministers-some of the highest paid people in the Commonwealth-are able to get dirt cheap home loans for a 45 year term. So much furore was created over that matter which I raised on 12 November that the next day the front page of the Adelaide News stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Ministers accused. Storm over cheap home loans claim.

The newspaper went on to quote chapter and verse what took place in this chamber on the night before. I give great credit to the correspondent, Warwick Costin, for exposing to the people at large just what some of these Liberal/Country Party Ministers-and these are Country Party Ministers we are talking about-will do to get a cheap buck at the expense of the under-privileged people in this community. On 16 February this year, the day the Parliament resumed, I put a question to Senator Messner. I said:

I preface my question to the Minister representing the Minister for the Capital Territory by reminding him of the debate during the Committee stage of the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1981 on 12 November last year dealing with the expenditure for the Capital Territory. It was then revealed that the Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Anthony, and the Minister for Primary Industry, Mr Nixon, had been given 45-year term home loans by the Liberal-National Country Party Government at fixed interest rates of 4.75 per cent and 6.25 per cent per annum respectively. In view of the public outcry at this very selective, favourable treatment for two Ministers of this Government, I now ask the Minister: Firstly, has either Minister or have both of the aforementioned Ministers divested themselves of these loans since I raised the matter in Committee; and secondly, if the answer is that they have not, will the Government now extend the same generous, long term, low interest rate loans to the many thousands of young couples who are now in desperate straits trying to maintain a roof over the heads of their families?
In reply Senator Messner said:

Of course, the problem here is that having been reminded by Senator McLaren of the debate that occurred last November I have not had the opportunity of consulting with my colleague as to the current state of play. At this point all I can offer to do is to consult with Mr Hodgman and bring down an early reply for Senator McLaren.

That question was asked on 16 February. Today is 25 March. I was handed a partial reply to my question. Nearly every day on which the Senate has sat this session I have presented petitions from concerned citizens, complaining about the privilege loans of which these two highly paid gentlemen were in receipt and asking that the same generous terms be extended to many people who are in desperate straits trying to get a roof over their heads. Last week the Government announced a home loans package which it says will benefit many people . In my view and in the view of all my colleagues, whilst it may benefit some, it will disadvantage more than it will advantage. The bank interest rate on home loans is going up by another one per cent but the reply I received to my question indicates that one of the Ministers to whom I have referred will escape .

What really annoyed me was that when Mr Fry, the honourable member for Fraser, asked a question on 18 November of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser), the Prime Minister tried cheaply to discredit Mr Fry and Mr Morrison who had also, not as members of parliament but as citizens of the Australian Capital Territory , availed themselves of cheap loans. He tried to use that as an excuse for Mr Anthony and Mr Nixon also having cheap loans. Despite the fact that both Mr Fry and Mr Morrison took points of order, Mr Fraser still tried to belittle them. The document that Senator Guilfoyle tabled in the parliament during the consideration of the Appropriation Bills proved to one and all that these people had paid off their loans before they were elected to the Parliament. Yet the Prime Minister still stooped to that low trick of trying to implicate them in the same way as his two chums, the Country Party Ministers, are implicated. On Tuesday of this week, 23 March, my leader, Senator Button, received an answer to Question No. 1613 which he had placed on notice. The question stated:
Senator Button asked the Minister representing the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 24 November 1981:

Have either Mr Anthony or Mr Nixon at any time since the taking out of their respective Commonwealth home loan mortgages lent money out at interest to any person or organisation, for any substantial period of time; if so, what are the details of such loans.
An answer was provided by the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Carrick. It stated:
The Prime Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator' s question:
I refer the honourable senator to my answer to Question No. 1153 on 23 February 1982 (Hansard, page 287) . . .
The answer to which the Minister referred was given to Senator Walsh who had asked:

(1) Did the former Member for Boothby, the Hon. J. McLeay, while a member of the Ministry inform the Prime Minister that McLeay Brothers Pty Ltd or any other McLeay family business enterprise was in financial difficulties; if so, on what date.
(2) If he did not do so, did he breach the Government's guidelines on declaration of pecuniary interests.

Senator Button was referred to that answer. It has nothing to do with cheap home loans but it was fobbed off as an answer. He was also referred to an answer given to a question without notice in the House of Representatives on 18 November and to question No. 1153 asked in February 1982. That was in the Senate Hansard but I do not have that with me. That had nothing at all to do with these cheap home loans either. That is the way the Prime Minister has tried to duck out of this issue, to try to explain away why he sanctioned these cheap loans. He did not give them to these two chaps because they gave them to themselves when they were then Ministers for the Interior. That department has now been changed; it is now the Department of Administrative Services. One of the excuses that Mr Fraser used for these people getting these cheap home loans was that they had to spend a long time in Canberra and that they were parted from their families. So they of all people-Ministers, mind you-should have cheap government homes in Canberra at low interest rates! Of course we know that Mr Anthony was not living in that home for quite a lengthy period because he let it out to a Mr Stallings who is one of those people who are now well known to have been members of the Central Intelligence Agency. One of the purposes of Senator Walsh's question, and of some of mine at various times, was to find out whether those people are allowed to let out government homes which they are buying at cheap rates, and in particular, to let them out to a member of the CIA and get a high rent for them while they are buying those homes at a very cheap interest rate on a long term loan.

Of course the other thing that now comes to mind is: How does Mr Anthony- because he is the one who still has the loan, I will refer to him-get on with this house, as a Minister? This relates to Mr Nixon also. Do they declare those homes as their home base and then every time they go away from Canberra get the travelling allowance to which members of parliament are entitled-under the Remuneration Tribunal guidelines members of parliament have to declare where their home base is-or do they declare their home base as being where they live? If they do that, Mr Fraser's argument is knocked flat because they are not using these places they have in Canberra as homes. Mr Anthony was using his place for quite a period as a money-making venture by letting it out to a member of the CIA. I will refer in a short time to the answer I received today from Senator Messner but I first want to quote a couple of extracts from newspapers. An article in the Canberra Times of Tuesday 2 March is headed 'Ministers' house loans', and states:
Low-interest housing loans held by two Government Ministers in the ACT should be repaid, Senator Reid (Lib, ACT) said yesterday.
'I personally think it would be preferable if both ministers concerned repaid the loans and refinanced their houses in another way,' she said on radio station 2CN.
But she said the ministers could not be forced to repay what were 'quite legal mortgages and quite legal interest rates.'
Nobody doubts the fact that they are legal, but they are morally wrong in the minds of many people. The article went on to say:
The Minister for Primary--
The article does not say 'Industry'--
Mr Nixon, has recently paid off his loan, at a fixed interest rate of 6.25 per cent, according to a spokesman for Mr Nixon.
The Minister for Trade and Resources, Mr Anthony, was still repaying his loan at 4.75 per cent a spokesman for Mr Anthony said.

Of course we know that Mr Anthony is on record in regard to this matter. In my haste to get here tonight it looks as though I have left his statement behind. It was made in an article in the Clancy column of the National Times. Mr Anthony is quoted as having said that he has no intention of paying off his loan. That is most unfortunate. As I said, as the Deputy Prime Minister he is on one of the highest salaries it is possible for any person in the Parliament to receive, and he also receives one of the highest travelling allowances. I received an answer today from Senator Messner. I am at a loss to know why it was not given to me when we first came back, in view of what is embodied in it.
I quote the answer:

TALK.START.PARA: —On 16 February 1982 Senator McLaren asked a question without notice seeking information relating to Government Home Loans. The Minister for the Capital Territory has supplied the following information in reply to the honourable senator's question:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) The Minister for Primary Industry (Mr P. J. Nixon) discharged his Commonwealth of Australia loan in December 1981.

That is one good thing that has come out of the vigilance of members of the Opposition on Estimates committees and their bringing the matter before the Committee of the Whole. At least we have forced Mr Nixon to pay off his home loan. After many years he has come to see the light. I do not know who forced him to do it. I have been told that there was quite a dispute in East Gippsland among the Country Party members who are desperate to retain a State seat there. The dogs were barking that the Country Party was in trouble if it was going to indulge in things such as this to help its Ministers in the Federal Parliament. That might have been one of the reasons-I do not know how true it is-he got busy and paid it off. The answer continues:
(2) Mr Anthony and Mr Nixon purchased their government-built houses with the assistance of fixed interest rate Commonwealth of Australia mortgages in December 1964 and August 1970.

Before September 1974 all Commonwealth of Australia mortgage documents relating to the purchase of government houses in Canberra made no provision for variation of the interest rate that was applicable at the date a mortgage was granted. It was recognised that this was an anomaly and after September 1974 all new applicants to buy their government houses were required to enter into mortgages with variable interest rates.

Of course, we all know that it was a Labor Government that changed that. We were in government in 1974. The Labor Government was not going to stand by and see Ministers of the Crown or anybody else getting these very favourable interest rates. No doubt people on some very high salaries in Canberra also availed themselves of those low interest rates. The answer goes on to say:
Under existing law it was not legally possible to vary mortgages entered into by mortgagors, including Mr Nixon and Mr Anthony, before that date.

The Minister for the Capital Territory (Mr Hodgman) said, of course, that it was not legally possible. Of course, it would have been morally possible for them to pay off those cheap loans. The answer goes on:
Since 1974 government housing loans have been made available to low income earners on generous terms and conditions.
Nobody disputes the decision that the loans ought to be made available to low income earners. I am in full agreement with that. The answer continues:

Such loans currently commence at an interest rate of 5 3/4% (effective) per annum, with this rate escalating by 1/2% per annum until the full non- concessional rate of 11 3/4% (effective) is reached. Where a mortgagor can demonstrate that the annual increase would cause undue hardship escalations may be deferred.

We find that these people, who were financially disadvantaged and were able to get one of these long term, low interest rate home loans in 1974 at 5 3/4 per cent, with the half per cent per annum escalation would now be paying 9 3/4 per cent on their home loans. Yet we find that that interest rate is nearly the double the rate that Mr Anthony is still paying on the loan which he refuses to pay off. I ask: Is that justice? What will the young people of this country think when I acquaint them with this? I will be contacting all of the people who have signed those petitions and sent them to me-I have presented them in Parliament-because I have kept a copy of their names. I will be sending Mr Hodgman's answer to them. I am sure that they will not be very happy. I hope that when the Press picks this up the Liberal Government, and particularly the Country Party candidates, in Victoria will not be too happy either.

The people in Victoria have to make a decision about whether they will vote into office next week members of the Country Party who condone the Deputy Prime Minister, who is a member of the National Country Party, availing himself of this long term, low interest loan when he can well afford to pay it out. As my colleague Senator Walsh said in a Press release, we wonder how much of this money which he has got at low interest rates he has invested in some other way at a very high interest rate. As Senator Walsh, would say if he were here speaking on this matter, this is double dipping. Of course, we see this is nothing new when we have a look at some of the other things that have been going on. Senator Walsh has raised those matters on many occasions; I have no need to raise them here tonight. Again I place on record my disgust that the Deputy Prime Minister of Australia still has available to him this 45-year home loan. He has paid very little of it off in the time he has had it. He is still availing himself of the loan at 4 3/4 per cent per annum interest while the other people in Canberra who have taken out loans since 1974-even those people who are financially disadvantaged-have to pay double that interest rate. This is something that just will not go away. It will not be swept under the carpet whilst I remain in this place.

Of course, I will have to tell the people who are sending these petitions that they will have to alter them. I am sure that, when we return here after the three week break, plenty of people will still be petitioning the Parliament through me to call on Mr Anthony to do the decent thing for once in his life and to pay out that loan. I hope that these petitions will have the same effect on him as they had on Mr Nixon. At least the people who signed those petitions will be happy to know that they have forced one of those jackals into the position of having to pay off the loan. I hope we will be able to do this through one avenue that is available to the electors of this country. I hope that by petitioning the Parliament we will finally force the Deputy Prime Minister at least to have some degree of moral standard and pay back that loan which in my view he is not entitled to at the rate of interest he is paying.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not keep the Senate long. I apologise for speaking in the adjournment debate. In particular I apologise to the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) who believes that any honourable senator who speaks after 10.30 p.m. on a Thursday is speaking in the dead of night. But I did try to raise the matter on which I wish to speak earlier in the evening. It was due to the effort of Senator Chaney and his colleagues that I was unable to do so.

SPEECH.PARA: Members of the Opposition in the other place today received calls in their electoral offices from pensioners in Victoria who had received with their pension cheques what can be only described as an advertisement for the Victorian State Government booklet purporting to outline the benefits available for pensioners provided by the Victorian Government. We in the Opposition thought this was a bit rich although we should not have been surprised that this sort of activity would go on just before the Victorian election. In recent weeks, of course, we have seen the Minister for Housing, Mr McVeigh, setting off on a $300 ,000 advertising campaign for the Government's new, rather belated and inefficient housing assistance program-advertisements which are being broadcast on radio and television. A disproportionate amount of the money which is available to be spent on that advertising campaign is, of course, being spent in Victoria where there just happens to be an election coming up in a couple of weeks, an election in which, according to the polls in this country, the Liberals are in some difficulty.

We have also seen the Minister for Social Security on another occasion spending a considerable amount of money-again something over $300,000-on an advertising campaign when he was indulging in industrial warfare with one of the trade unions in his Department-the Administrative and Clerical Officers Association. That was one of the matters I raised in what Senator Chaney called the dead of the night a couple of weeks ago. First of all, I would like to contrast this behaviour with the behaviour of the Government since 1975. The Government has, in fact, cut advertising of social security benefits in this country by some 50 per cent since 1975. The publicity budget has gone down by 50 per cent in real terms. The Department has been reluctant to use the most effective means of advertising its pensions and benefits-particularly the disadvantaged health card -on radio and television. It is only too willing now to use this media to advertise its housing policy for electoral purposes. Now we also have the Department including with its cheques to pensioners a document advertising the services available to pensioners from the Victorian Government. It is not unusual, of course, for the Department of Social Security to advertise benefits that are made available by State departments. In fact, a booklet called 'More help for pensioners' has been distributed for many years. The booklet lists the social security benefits that are available from the Department of Social Security in each State and benefits which are available from the Victorian Government and other State governments. It is a detailed booklet which gives in straight terms what is available. But what has been advertised now by Senator Chaney and by the Department of Social Security in conjunction with the Victorian department is I believe a much more blatantly political document. The document started off by stating: 'A Message to Victoria's Pensioners', and concludes: 'Lindsay Thompson, Premier and Treasurer of Victoria'. The document states:
Victoria's 430 000 pensioners have collectively made a tremendous contribution to this State's current prosperity.
The Victorian Government is committed to caring for pensioners by ensuring that the living standards of Victoria's pensioners are maintained.
This booklet 'Benefits for Pensioners from the Victorian Government', is the most comprehensive booklet of its kind, produced by any Government in Australia.
It is our way of explaining, clearly and concisely, the range of benefits available to you for both your use and needs.

I have no objection to the production of such a document. I think that the more documents that are available and the more adverising that is carried out to let pensioners know their rights the better. The problem I have is with the timing. I believe that Victorian pensioners have deserved to know their rights from the Victorian Government and the Commonwealth Government for many years. But there has been no such effort to make this information available in either the bland form made available by the Department of Social Security or in the more political language of the Department of the Premier and the Department of the Treasury in Victoria until there is an impending election. The Victorian Government, under Mr Thompson, realising that it is in some difficulties, has prepared a document presenting itself in the best light, in a political way, to the pensioners of Victoria. And what better way to distribute this document than with the assistance of its Federal colleagues, the Liberal-National Country Party Government, which is in power in Canberra.

I believe this is a futile exercise. The Minister probably realises it is a futile exercise too. I think that the electors of this country-particularly in Victoria-as they are the ones who are involved at the moment-will not fall for a trick like this and will not be convinced to vote for the Victorian Government merely because it and its Federal colleagues have produced a document of this type. It is important that all the electors of Victoria, not only pensioners, know how the Federal Government and the Federal Minister is willing to use his Department for what is blatantly a political propaganda exercise just before an election. I believe that the timing is appalling. One can imagine the screams that would have occurred in this place if a Federal Labor Government had indulged in such activities just before an election in, say, New South Wales or Tasmania. We are told, of course, that originally it was planned to include the whole document in the pension mail-out, but it was too big. We are told that arrangements were made by bureaucrats and not by the Minister, Senator Chaney, to distribute the document which has gone out today. We are told that this was an apolitical decision, that in fact it was nothing to do with the Minister and was arranged through officials.

However, it has come to my knowledge that the Minister signed not just one but two letters to his Victorian counterpart authorising that this be done at a time when he and his Victorian counterpart knew that a Victorian State election was imminent. We also understand that the intention was to send out approximately twice as many of the cards which went out today but there was some difficulty with printing and getting them in with the cheques. As I say, I merely raise this matter to draw the attention of the Parliament and the people of Victoria to the tactics in which the Government will indulge. That just adds to the list of abuses of the information services of the Government-in particular, the Department of Social Services in this case-for political purposes. The Government is always complaining about the information services of previous Federal governments and certain State governments and about the activities of information services in various States and governments of its opponents. I find it rather strange that this Government should indulge in this sort of activity because I believe it should have learned from the backfire of last week's announcement by Mr McVeigh.

I merely raise this matter to put on record the depth to which the present Government will go to assist its colleagues who are in such desperate straits in Victoria. The Government will not succeed. People are not conned by this sort of thing. People understand the political process sufficiently to know what is going on. It is about time the Government learned that the people understand, and it should understand that it cannot get away with this sort of thing without its being raised and exposed in this place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Since Senator Grimes has gone to some trouble to put on the record, as he puts it, various sins and omissions of mine, it is unfortunately necessary for me to put on record my rejection of the charges that he has laid. The main points that seemed to come through his wildly political statements tonight are that, firstly , the Federal Minister is prepared to use his Department for political purposes. If one analyses what Senator Grimes said, it is clear that his basic concern is the question of the timing of the inclusion of a slip which went out with some of the pension cheques in Victoria this week. For the purpose of keeping the record clear, I would like to repeat that the slip, which was included in approximately 100,000 pension cheques which went out this week, reads as follows :

SPEECH.PARA: A new booklet giving full details of all pensioner benefits provided by the Government of Victoria is now available at all post offices.

The message is a short and simple one of three lines, indicating that a booklet giving details of all pensioner benefits is available at the nearest post office . The complaint is made that this is being done with an eye to the Victorian elections and that in some way I have caused that to happen in an attempt to be of assistance to my Victorian Liberal colleagues. I simply reject that. I will set out the history of this matter, which I trust will satisfy the record, if not Senator Grimes, that there was no political intervention on my part. I had no part in making a decision, political or otherwise. The matter was one which indeed picked up the sorts of concerns which only two nights ago Senator Grimes was expressing so vehemently in the Senate chamber. I would like to refer to what Senator Grimes said two nights ago when he was complaining about other advertising by this Government and about a lack of effort by this Government to draw the attention of pensioners to their entitlements. I read from page 1073 of the Senate Hansard. Senator Grimes said:

In 1973 the Henderson Commission of Inquiry in to Poverty found that there were some 17,000 poor householders who were entitled to social services who were not receiving them whether through-to quote the report-'ignorance or pride'. The Task Force on Departmental Information which reported to the Government last year found that socio-economic and information disadvantage usually go together and have a mutually aggravating effect on each other. People in these areas just do not know what is available to them. The means used by the Government to make information available to them is just not getting the information through.
Later in the same speech, Senator Grimes said:
On the other hand, the Government is refusing to publicise, by the use of this media-
He was referring to television-
at other times during the year, benefits that are vital to the most needy.
He went on to say, in referring to my Department, that Mr McVeigh had said:
If you want to accuse me of helping people, so be it.
Senator Grimes then said:

That is something of which we could never, in the same context, accuse Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle, Senator Chaney or the present Government when we look at the publicity budget that is devoted to social security recipients in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —That would be all right if it was the Federal Department doing it.

—I will come to the question of the Federal Department. Senator Grimes read into the record a summary of what is contained in the information which we are indicating to pensioners is available. The booklet points out that there is a clear and concise explanation of the range of benefits available to pensioners for their use and needs and then sets out some of the things which are available. The booklet contains more detail on these matters which are of interest to pensioners. So there is no concern from either side of this chamber, it would seem to me, on the principle that we should be trying to inform pensioners of their entitlements.
—What about the timing?

—I will come to the timing too. Senator Grimes expressed concern that many forms of advertising do not get through to pensioners and he pointed to his concern about the decline in the social security publicity expenditure. Let me refer very quickly to the record of social security publicity expenditure . In the last year of the Labor Government $1.185m was spent on advertising by the Department of Social Security. Of that, over $850,000 was specifically related to advertising of Medibank. For the next four years the budget for the Department of Social Security for publicity purposes ranged from $459,917 through some minor declines, but still over $400,000, to $487,000 in 1979-80. In 1980-81 the budget was over $1m, of which half a million dollars approximately was for the International Year of Disabled Persons. This year, 1981-82, the budgeted amount was $1.174m, which included $416,000 for IYDP. However, the Government subsequently devoted $176,000 additional to advertising the Disadvantaged Persons Health Scheme and $100,000 to advertising pension increases and new pension limits late last year. An amount of $400,000 was spent on advertising relating to the industrial dispute and $50,000 went on other increases in costs. That makes a total of $1.9m. I have been quoted recently as saying: 'You are damned if you do and you are damned if you don't in the Department of Social Security'. When we started spending money advertising the Disadvantaged Persons Health Scheme, one Labor shadow Minister told us that we were using government money for propaganda. Another said that we were not advertising the program sufficiently to make it available to the people who need it. Quite frankly, I suggest that we get down to the facts. The facts show a very considerable recent increase in the attempts of the Department to get through in ways about which I would have thought there was largely no argument.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me turn now to the question of how this particular exercise came about and how the timing came about, because I wish to meet the points which were raised by Senator Grimes. The proposal actually had its origin in a suggestion from a Labor member of Parliament in Victoria made in 1980 in the House of Assembly in that State. I have with me an extract from the Hansard of the Victorian Parliament. It is the Hansard of 16 April 1980. Mr Gavin, the member for Coburg, said:

A list of all available concessions for pensioners could cut out the anomalies that exist. From memory, either on the first or second day of this sessional period the Treasurer said he would try to have such a list compiled. If the Treasurer made that commitment I ask him to stand by it. Members of Parliament should know what concessions are available, and what categories of pensioners are entitled to receive concessions.
He then referred to lists being available and to the fact that they were not up to date, and continued:

Pensioners have done enough for society and should be given any possible benefits. The production of such a list might cost money but it would be of assistance. I hope the Treasurer will note my comments and answer them.
In the same debate on the same day, Mr Thompson, who was not then the Treasurer- -

TALK.START.PARA: —It has taken them two years to organise it.
—I am grateful for the continued assistance of Senator Gietzelt, but I would prefer him to let me do it in my own way in my own time. Mr Thompson , responding, said:

SPEECH.PARA: There is a good case for bringing out a document which explains clearly to all honourable members exactly what concessions are available for the various classes of pensioners so that they can answer the many queries about pensioners' concessions. Meanwhile, the Government will be taking care to ensure that all people receiving benefits under this legislation will be notified . . .

In fact, it was from that debate in 1980 that this booklet eventually emerged. The Government promptly set about asking all Victorian departments to marshal the information which related to benefits available to pensioners in the State of Victoria. For reasons which have not been explained to me in detail-my information comes simply from a telephone call, because I knew nothing of this background until this matter blew up this afternoon-I was advised this afternoon that the collation of that material continued until about August of last year and that the production of a booklet was then commenced.

The booklet was not completed until later in the year, or early this year, but in December my Department was approached by the Victorian Department and asked about means of getting this booklet out to pensioners. There were discussions about the possibility of the booklet itself being distributed. Indeed, that was a matter which was investigated in the earlier part of this year by the public servants involved, but was found not to be a practicable proposition. It was then decided that a card insert could be enclosed with cheques-clearly, that is physically possible-simply advising pensioners of the availability of the booklet.

That action by departmental officers resulted in further action being taken on 4 March 1982 by officers, who put to the Acting Director-General of Social Services a recommendation to proceed with arrangements for the inclusion of the insert in cheque envelopes. Because of the complexities which were involved in the production and enveloping of hundreds of thousands of cheques, the first available pay-day which could be used for the insertion was 25 March. The dimension of the job was such that it was not possible to do them all in one batch and a decision was taken to spread the insertion over two or more paydays, commencing with that of 25 March 1982. In line with standard practice, the Acting Director-General determined that the request was in accordance with departmental guidelines, and approved it.

That summary omits my own part in this matter, which I would wish to be quite clear to this chamber, albeit empty, so at least it will be on record. I was referred to in this process. I had no part in the events which I have described, but let me now describe those in which I did play a part.
On approximately 27 January, I received a letter dated 20 January from the Acting Treasurer of Victoria, Mr W. A. Borthwick, who wrote to me in these terms :

At the direction of the Treasurer, the Honourable L. H. S. Thompson, M.P., a booklet has been prepared detailing concessions available to pensioners from the Government of Victoria. It is now necessary to distribute the booklet to each pensioner.

I have been informed that your Department will, with your consent, arrange to mail the booklet with the pension cheque sent to each pensioner. Therefore, I am writing to seek your agreement to your Department providing the necessary assistance. In this way you will preserve the confidentiality of the pensioner and may, hopefully, alert some persons to an existing right or concession of which they are not aware.
Yours sincerely, W. A. Borthwick
That was the first I had heard of this proposal. I wrote on the letter:
Dept-if this has been arranged early confirmation please

initialled it and dated it 27 January. On 11 February, I signed a form of acknowledgment-it is one of the two letters referred to by Senator Grimes in his statement-prepared by my Department in these terms:
I wish to acknowledge receipt of your letter of 20 January 1982 concerning the distribution of a booklet detailing concessions available to pensioners from the Government of Victoria.
I will write to you on this matter as soon as possible.
Yours sincerely

I had nothing further to do with this matter until, on 11 March, I received a reply prepared by my Department, with respect to which there had been no consultation with me. That reply was signed by me and sent to Mr Thompson. It is in these terms:
Dear Mr Thompson

I am replying to the honourable W. A. Borthwick's letter of 20 January 1982, which he wrote whilst Acting Treasurer, regarding the distribution of a booklet with pension cheques issued by my Department.

Because of the operational impact on time-critical cheque issues, I do not normally favour the forwarding of material with cheques. However, approval is granted from time to time for material to be inserted with cheques and each request is considered separately.

I am advised that contact was made between officers of our Departments and a test run revealed the impracticality of attempting to enclose the booklet with pension cheques. A substantial proposal to enclose a card insert informing pensioners that the booklet is available from Post Offices and Social Security Regional Offices has been considered by my Department and has been approved by my Director-General. I understand that subject to the cards being available the distribution will take place over two paydays namely 25 March 1982 and 9 April 1982.

I was presented with this draft making it clear that a decision had been made administratively with respect to the distribution. I had not seen the booklet. I had had no part in any of the discussions which led up to that point. However, I did, on the day that I signed that letter, which was 11 March-it was dispatched and dated on 12 March-speak with him about it. One of us-I do not recollect who- raised the fact that between those two dates of distribution there was an election. I did not feel, in light of the fact that the decision had been taken in the way that it was and in light of the sort of material being enclosed, that it was my job to try to change the decision which had been taken administratively. I cheerfully acknowledge that I was aware that this was going out and of the relevant dates. I can now advise the Senate that approximately 100,000 cards went out today and something like a quarter of a million cards will go out in a couple of weeks time. That, of course, is a period after the Victorian election. I suggest that if I were seeking to make some political point it would not have quite fallen out in that pattern.

I am sorry to hold the Senate for such a long time, but I do feel that the honest management of my Department by me has been impugned. I wish simply to make sure that a reasonably full explanation of what occurred is before the Senate. With respect to the use of direct mailing, and accepting that there is a problem in getting information to the less privileged people in the community, it has become a quite accepted practice that we use the income maintenance system which provides payments to nearly two million less well off Australians as a means of getting information to them. The previous Government-I am not criticising it in saying this-commenced the practice with respect to Medibank Private where information about it was provided through the pension system in this way.

Let me give honourable senators an example of the sorts of things which have been done since that time to provide information to less advantaged Australians. The Department has despatched information on the Perth City Council housebound readers library service. That is something which obviously was not sent to pensioners in Victoria, New South Wales or anywhere else. It was sent to pensioners in Perth who might use that service. We sent out a notice from the Tasmanian Branch of the Reserve Bank of Australia about cheque encashment facilities for pensioners-a very relevant problem for pensioners. We sent out notices from the Queensland Consumer Affairs Council, with reference to consumer education programs directed at low income consumers, the Commonwealth Department of Education regarding the secondary allowance scheme, and the Commonwealth Department of Health regarding information on health insurance for fringe beneficiaries. With respect to the State of Victoria in 1980, we have on a number of occasions sent out, on behalf of the Victorian Roads Safety and Traffic Authority, a leaflet entitled 'Pedestrians, be seen, be safe'.

That is the administrative background under which my officers who dealt with this matter were dealing. I do not appreciate having their bona fides impugned in this place by Senator Grimes. I do not believe their bona fides should be impugned. He, of course, impugned me. But I think that the summary that I have given has indicated that my part in this was not one that shows any political interference at all or any decision being made on the basis of the politics of the coming election.

I think it is important that people are able to trust the government and what it does. In the administration of my Department I try to ensure that there are no abuses. I do not believe that the actions of the officers of my Department or , indeed, my own actions can be impugned in the way that they have been. Certainly, they cannot be impugned fairly. So, I reject the points which have been made by Senator Grimes on behalf of the Opposition tonight. I wish that politics in Australia were conducted on a level where there might be some attempt to ascertain what the full facts of the matters are before speeches are circulated to the media in advance of their being made in this place and before statements are made which I believe reflect on my integrity. I reject the imputations and regret that they have been made in the manner in which they have .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I seek leave to make a personal explanation. I claim to have been misrepresented.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I had no intention of replying until I heard Senator Chaney's last words when he said that speeches I made in this place tonight were circulated to the Press before I made them. That is not true. I had no prepared speeches. I spoke from no notes and nothing of that type was circulated to the Press at all. Senator Chaney's statement is in keeping with other statements that he has made of that kind.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not wish to get too involved in this debate. We have heard Senator Grimes this evening and we have heard Senator Chaney's explanation which superficially establishes the fact that he and his Department did take certain steps to increase the knowledge of social security beneficiaries of some of the activities of the Federal Department. The fact that the Minister has given us such detailed information indicates that he is concerned at the criticism raised by Senator Grimes on behalf of the Opposition. If we were to isolate it may be there would be more value in what Senator Chaney said. But we are, after all, living in a political climate in which the Victorian Government is conceded by all political commentators to be somewhat besieged, beleaguered and on the defensive. Even Ministers of that Government are conceding that the Australian Labor Party could probably win the election by 48 per cent to 52 per cent. That is one of the Minister's own assessments made in discussion with a commentator only a few days ago.

SPEECH.PARA: I think the Opposition would still have to take the view that it was an injudicious thing for the Department or the Minister not to recognise the political pitfalls that emerged as a result of the decisions that may have been taken. I do not dispute that the process began in 1980 and that the due processes proceeded over the intervening 18 months or two years to the point where they were ready to be sent out to those in receipt of social security payments.

Surely it is the responsibility of departmental heads, as indeed it is of the Minister, to recognise and concede that in an election period, when political interest is heightened, when people are looking for issues on which to contest an election and are watching carefully the attitude taken by political parties and governments in respect of the contest that takes place during an election period, the Opposition is entitled to say that nothing would have been lost if those leaflets had been sent out in a fortnight's time. No criticism could have been levelled at the Department or the Minister. But to give approval for 100, 000 leaflets to be included in Commonwealth envelopes certainly leaves the impression that there was connivance or an attitude that the Opposition believes does or could affect an election result. This would happen particularly when we know that a decision was made in respect to the housing package, which decision had the effect again of using Commonwealth resources for the purpose of popularising election candidates in Victoria.

The amalgamation of those two incidents has certainly created a reaction by the Opposition. After all, the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Newman) and the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr McVeigh) have defended the expenditure of funds in respect to that housing package out of proportion to the amount of total moneys that were allocated in that instance. This occurred in the fortnight before the election took place.

We are all aware that, in the sort of political climate in which there is a contest of the type we have seen in Victoria over the last weeks, it is the role of the Opposition to examine closely what the Victorian Government and its counterpart, the Federal Government, are doing. The Opposition has drawn the conclusion that there has been some collusion and we take exception to it in respect to housing as indeed we have taken exception with respect to social security payments. I would have thought that on reflection the Minister would probably concede that it would have been better to have left the exercise to be carried into effect after the Victorian election rather than in the week or ten days immediately preceding it. A procedure has been introduced. If the Minister is approached by the New South Wales Government, will he make the same facilities available? Will it be the practice, the tradition, the procedure which the Federal Government will adopt with respect to all of the other States?

Senator Grimes has made the point-certainly we on this side of the chamber will always take the view-that it is the responsibility of government to communicate to beneficiaries all of the benefits that are available to them. I am sorry that the Minister feels that he, personally, has been put in the firing line. He has to concede that, in the electoral climate in Victoria in which his own party is likely to be defeated, every action which is taken by a Federal department or a Federal Minister will be closely examined by the Opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I will not delay the Senate. Senator Grimes returned to the chamber and said that he did not distribute copies of his speech. I accept the word of an honourable senator who tells me that. I merely wish to put on the record that the reason I suggested he did was that Simon Nasht who interviewed me during the dinner recess told me that he had Senator Grimes's speech. I do not accuse Mr Nasht of untruths. He probably had a copy of the Press release and used the wrong word. I wish Senator Grimes to know the basis of the comment, and I accept his denial of it.

—I understand that an announcement is about to be made changing the sitting days of the Estimates committees. Today we agreed that the Estimates committees would sit on Mondays, Thursdays, and Fridays if required. Estimates Committees G and H will certainly be sitting on the Friday. I understand that it is intended to swap the sitting days of Committee A and Committee D. I make it quite clear here and now that I, as a member of Committee D, do not wish to have my days swapped around. I voted with the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Button) when he moved that we should not sit on those days. People who objected to sitting on these days had the opportunity then to vote against the proposal. I do not care what the majority of the Committee said or how it was lobbied. So far as I am concerned, the Senate agreed that the Estimates committees should sit on particular days and those are the days on which they should be sitting. If any private arrangements are to be made they should be made with the consent of the Senate. I object strongly to private arrangements being made.
—You want to discuss that with your own party. It is your own senator, Senator Evans. Discuss it with him.

—I do not know what Senator Walters is talking about but I am talking about Senate Estimates Committee D and there is no Senator Evans on it. Senator Walters can make her Liberal objection later. I am objecting to something real and Senator Evans does not come into it at all. So far as I am concerned, I am a member of Estimates Committee D and the Senate agreed for that Committee to sit on particular days. If private arrangements have been made they should have been made with the consent of the Senate as a whole. As a member of Estimates Committee D I object to flying from Perth on a Sunday to attend a meeting on the following Monday. It does not suit me to have the Committee meet on that Monday. Therefore, I am lodging my objection now. Senator Walters had the opportunity to object at the time this matter came before the Senate. She could have voted against certain sitting days. I wish to lodge my objection.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that I should make a brief explanation in response to the objection which has just been recorded. As the Chairman of Senate Estimates Committee A I was asked by the whole of the Committee at a meeting this evening to see whether it was possible to arrange for a swap to be made to a day which would enable more than half the Committee to be present. I sought to arrange that with any of the three committees which were due to sit on the Thursday rather than the Monday. I was informed later, after consultation with the membership of Estimates Committee D, that a swap would be made. I am grateful to the majority, apparently, of the members of Committee D who have enabled Committee A to sit with more than half its members present. I am sorry if that has adversely affected one member. It was done, might I add, primarily at the request of one of the members of his party.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate stands adjourned until Tuesday, 20 April 1982, at 1.45 p.m. I remind honorable senators that Estimates Committees B, C and D will be meeting on Monday, 19 April 1982, at 10. 30 a.m.

INTERJECT.PARA: Senate adjourned at 11.28 p.m.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following answers to questions were circulated:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McClelland Sen The Hon D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Finance upon notice on 17 February 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Government directed the Minister's Department to pay the salary increases granted in December 1981 by the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission from funds already allocated for this financial year.
(2) What impact will this direction have on the Department's ongoing programs.
(3) What programs will have to be curtailed or dropped.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) to (3) The Government has given no direction to the effect indicated.

Departments were advised on 5 February 1982 by the Public Service Board Instruction No. 1982/6 of the decision of the Full Bench of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission relating to salary increases in the clerical/ administrative, second division, clerical assistant and keyboard positions in the Australian Public Service.
This instruction also included advice that departments should make every effort to absorb the increases from within their relevant appropriation.

Particulars of savings made on existing appropriations, including any which involve reduction of funds available to particular programs, are given in the Statement of Savings submitted to the Parliament accompanying Appropriation Bills (No. 3) and (No. 4).
The amounts sought in these Bills have also been contained to the extent practicable, but provide for continuation of essential activities.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 18 February 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Will the Government draw article 8 of the nuclear safeguards agreement between Australia and the United States of America to the attention of the United States Government and, in particular, to the attention of the U.S. Energy Secretary, Mr James Edwards. (See the National Times of 10-16 January 1982, article entitled 'NT uranium may end in warheads'.)

(2) Will the Government monitor the whereabouts of all plutonium in spent commercial nuclear fuel in the United States; if not will the Government cease exports of uranium to the United States immediately.
(3) Would the Government cease export of uranium to the United States as soon as the nuclear safeguards agreement is dishonoured.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) In October 1981 the Australian Embassy in Washington expressed to the United States Administration its concern about any possibility of plutonium separated from spent nuclear fuel from civil nuclear power stations being used for nuclear weapons. The Government drew the attention of United States officials to the fact that the bilateral agreement between Australia and the United States Concerning Peaceful Uses of Nuclear Energy provides for the peaceful non-explosive use of all items subject to the agreement. United States Department of Energy officials advised our Embassy in Washington that our points would be registered with the US Secretary of Energy Mr James Edwards. The bilateral agreement between Australia and the United States excludes the possibility of any nuclear material supplied from Australia under the agreement being used in warheads in the United States or in any other country.

(2) No. The Government has accepted the responsibility to ensure through the negotiation of bilateral nuclear safeguards agreements that nuclear material supplied by Australia under those agreements is used exclusively for peaceful, non-explosive purposes. In the case of the United States the relevant Agreement is that concerning peaceful uses of nuclear energy signed on 5 July 1979.

(3) Australia does not enter into treaty commitments on the asssumption that they will be dishonoured. As with all of Australia's nuclear safeguards agreements that with the United States of America provides for sanctions such as suspension of further transfers in the event of non-compliance with stipulated obligations of the agreement including the prohibition of explosive or military application of the items supplied under the Agreement.
See also answer to House of Representatives Question No. 3672 in Hansard of 18 February 1982 page 411.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 18 February 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Who is responsible for policing Australian nuclear safeguards policy in countries that are not signatories to the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty.
(2) What methods are employed to detect and prevent diversion of nuclear material for unauthorised enrichment or reprocessing in these countries, and how effective are these methods.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) All non nuclear weapon states, that is all countries other than the five existing nuclear weapon states recognised by the Non-Proliferation Treaty ( NPT), which are not parties to the NPT are not eligible to receive Australian uranium or to enter into bilateral nuclear safeguards agreements with Australia. The question does not, therefore, arise for such countries.

Nuclear weapon states retain the right to use nuclear material for weapons as well as for peaceful purposes. Australian policy requires that we may export only to those nuclear weapon states whether or not they are parties to the NPT, which give Australia an assurance that the nuclear material we may supply for peaceful purposes is not diverted to military or explosive purposes and accept that the material be covered by International Atomic Energy Agency safeguards. Australia has entered into bilateral nuclear safeguards agreements with Britain and the United States which are parties to the NPT and France which is not a party to the NPT. Our agreements with these three countries as with all of our bilateral nuclear safeguards agreements meet Australia's policy requirements including the incorporation of Australia's prior consent rights over retransfers , reprocessing and high enrichment. Nuclear material supplied by Australia under the agreements with these countries is subject to IAEA safeguards which provide assurance that the uranium we may supply for peaceful purposes is not diverted to explosive or military purposes.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McClelland Sen The Hon D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Finance, upon notice, on 25 February 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: Does portability of superannuation apply for officers transferring from the Commonwealth to State Public Services or local government authorities; if so, what are the details; and if not what measures, if any, have been taken to institute such a scheme.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Since 1971 there has been provision in the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme for the preservation of superannuation rights, in certain circumstances, of persons moving between Commonwealth employment and other employment, including employment with a State of local government authority.
For a person leaving the Commonwealth scheme, preservation may be effected by means of:
(a) the payment of a transfer value (a lump sum that includes an employer component) to an approved scheme; or
(b) where the person does not become a member of an approved scheme, a deferred benefit (generally a pension payable on age retirement, invalidity or death).
An approved scheme is one where the employing authority has entered into a reciprocal arrangement involving the payment of transfer values between schemes.

Although many State university schemes are approved schemes for the purposes of the preservation arrangements under the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme, most State Governments have so far been unwilling to enter into preservation arrangements with the Commonwealth that would facilitate the payment of transfer values between schemes. Consequently, where officers meeting the requirements for preservation elect to preserve their Commonwealth superannuation rights on transfer to State or local government employment, their only recourse is to accept eligibility for the deferred benefit alternative.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 16 February 1982 (Hansard, page 9) Senator McLaren asked a question without notice seeking information relating to government home loans. The Minister for the Capital Territory has supplied the following information in reply to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Minister for Primary Industry (Mr P. J. Nixon) discharged his Commonwealth of Australia loan in December 1981.
(2) Mr Anthony and Mr Nixon purchased their government-built houses with the assistance of fixed interest-rate Commonwealth of Australia mortgages in December 1964 and August 1970.

Before September 1974 all Commonwealth of Australia mortgage documents relating to the purchase of government houses in Canberra made no provision for variation of the interest rate that was applicable at the date a mortgage was granted. It was recognised that this was an anomaly and after September 1974 all new applicants to buy their government houses were required to enter into mortgages with variable interest rates. Under existing law it was not legally possible to vary mortgages entered into by mortgagors, including Mr Nixon and Mr Anthony, before that date.

Since 1974 government housing loans have been made available to low income earners on generous terms and conditions. such loans currently commence at an interest rate of 5 3/4 per cent (effective) per annum, with this rate escalating by 1/2 per cent per annum until the full non-concessional rate of 11 3/4 per cent (effective) is reached. Where a mortgagor can demonstrate that the annual increase would cause undue hardship escalations may be deferred.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 18 February 1982 (Hansard, page 141), Senator Keeffe asked me a question without notice, in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry in the Senate. His question concerned the 10 per cent of Japanese beef tenders usually allocated to the private quota.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Primary Industry has supplied the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

In response to the senator's question concerning what control the Government has over beef exports to Japan, I would point out that such exports are subject to all the requirements of the Exports (Meat) Regulations and conditions and restrictions imposed by the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation on the licensed exporter. The Government has no control over the handling, distribution or sale of the beef in Japan. That is a matter for the relevant Japanese authorities.

I wish to reiterate that all imports of beef into Japan are subject to a global import quota. The annual level of the quota is set by the Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries (MAFF) in consultation with the Ministry of International Trade and Industry (MITI). The quota comprises a general quota which is usually around 85 per cent of the total quota and various special quotas accounting for the rest. These special quotas comprise those for Okinawa , boiled beef, school lunches, hotels, ship and airline stores.

The general quota is split into two segments, 90 per cent of which is handled by the Livestock Industry Promotion Corporation (LIPC), a Japanese Government organisation, and 10 per cent by private importers.

The private quota is allocated by MITI on advice of MAFF, to end-users in the ratio of 70 per cent to the All Japan Meat Traders' Co-operative Federation, 20 per cent to the Japan Ham and Sausage Processors' Co-operative Association and 10 per cent to the Japan Meat Canners' Association. The quota is allocated amongst a set number of designated importing companies who sell the meat to the above-listed end-users according to the entirlement which these groups hold. The meat purchased for the private quota may be sourced from any country approved by the Japanese authorities including Australia.
